charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Live Below The Line is a campaigning and fundraising event that runs from May to June, with the Hunger Project. The UoL Oxfam Society are partaking in the challenge between the 4th-8th May! Living on £1 a day for all food and drink.

With a group effort we hope to raise more than £500 to support Oxfam's work - 82p of every £1 donated going directly to saving lives in emergencies, especially the recent devastating Nepal Earthquake. This is important for us, it's going to be a challenge, but we're hoping to make a difference - no matter how big or small! Every £1 donated will be matched by the UK government! Just click on Gift Aid when you donate.

Join in! It's a brilliant way to raise awareness of world hunger and food poverty in the UK, and change your perspective about how other people live around the world! For more information follow the links below...

http://www.thehungerproject.co.uk/getinvolved/live-below-the-line/

http://www.oxfam.org.uk/get-involved/fundraising/fundraising-events/live-below-line-2014

Thank you for your support!

Hi everyone, thanks for having a look at our just giving page!

We're attempting our very own live below the line challenge from the 24th till the 28th November, where we as members of Warwick-Oxfam-Outreach will be raising money for Oxfam and awareness for their new campaign "even it up" - demanding a fairer world and an end to inequality. 

If you can support us by donating or sharing our message that would be great!

Thanks from woxfamily! :)

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Our walk starts and finishes at Taunton Castle. We will walk 6 Kilometres to the end of Longrun Meadow and back, carrying 20 kilos of water between us.

This is in solidarity with poor people in Africa, who have to carry the same amount of water the same distance every day.
This not only wastes a lot of time for people, particularly women, it is also tiring and very often the water collected is from surface pools and not clean or healthy.

The money raised will go towards an Oxfam project to provide clean and safe water close to peoples homes.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
We're the Oxfam Group at Cambridge University, and we're taking a play, Rights of Passage, to the Edinburgh Fringe. This inspiring play tells the stories, in their own words, of three LGBT refugees.

As well as raising awareness of this important issue, we are using the play as an opportunity to raise money for Oxfam. Any donation you are able to give, however big or small, will make a huge difference to Oxfam's work with some of the most vulnerable people across the world, including their vital support for refugees.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
As of 2018, 1.2 billion people, or 16% of the global population survive on les than $1.25 per day. The current Yemen crisis, for example, has left over 8 million people facing acute hunger.

Its issues like these that The Great Oxfam Challenge seeks to eliminate. The money you donate will go to supplying necessities, such as safe food and water, to those in crisis.

On the 26th of July, 2018, we, a group of twelve 16 year olds, working with the National Citizen Service, will be performing a series of outlandish challenges in Kingston.

As we hit our fundraising targets, the challenges are as follows:

£20: the dizzy water challenge

£50: blindfold makeup challenge

£80: dyeing our hair green

£100: tinned food roulette challenge

£150: cream pie throwing

£200: the water balloon challenge

£300: eating dried bugs

£400: custard wellies challenge

£500: baked bean on head challenge

£1000: mystery challenge

We will be filming every moment of the chaos and uploading the evidence to Facebook and Instagram.

So get donating for some quality entertainment!
title: The Great Oxfam Challenge

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Oxfam has 4 teams in the affected areas (Leyte and Samar) providing household level water purification. Oxfam is delivering sanitation kits to 10,000 people this week, and is working with others to help get food markets back up and functioning, as well as getting cash into the hands of the most vulnerable.

Water and sanitation equipment is arriving into the country, which will be immediately taken to affected areas.

 

Oxfam looks to provide 500,000 people safe and clean water, tents and tarpaulins for emergency shelter. Oxfam will be supporting households rebuild their farming and fishing businesses, at the same time getting markets up and running so that food is available again in local shops.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
You’ve probably seen all the headlines about Oxfam. The story that’s not being told is that of the thousands of people who aren’t being helped to improve their lives because of the actions of a few individuals. Oxfam has lost £16 million in individual donations because of these people but those who are affected are those who need help the most. I’ve worked with Oxfam and I know that their work to help with clean water, education and agriculture makes an enormous difference.

I’m cycling 100 miles (with a few hills!) with Prudential Ride London at the of July to raise  money for Oxfam. Please help if you can.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
100km walk in 30 hours in the South Downs National Park: 13-15 July 2018

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page for this epic 100km challenge.  Am I crazy? Probably! Do I need your help and support? Definitely!

At school, we regularly raise money for so many charities through bake sales, raffles, quizzes etc but this one is massive!!

It will be a huge personal challenge to be able to complete the 100km walk: starting at 6am on the Saturday morning and walking all day and night until we finish, hopefully before midday on Sunday.  I walk in the hills and mountains as you all know and usually small day walks and the occasional Duke of Edinburgh trek over 2 days, but this goes way beyond that experience.

I would love for you to sponsor me to contribute towards our team target of £3000. So please click to donate as much as you can afford.  We have to raise the money before July so the charity will let us take part.  We will be walking over the weekend of 13-15 July 2018.

story:
Collectively we have decided to take part in the Trailwalker 2018 event. This is a 100km foot race through the South Downs National Park using trails and dirt tracks but also must be completed in under 30 hours. This is going to be an enormous challenge for us all but we are looking forward to having the opportunity to make a difference in whatever way we can. We will all be raising money for Oxfam, who are actively trying to reduce poverty, hunger and social injustice on a global scale. We have all been fortunate enough to have been put in a position where we can strive towards achieving our dreams in a sporting and academic capacity, however not everyone is this fortunate. We believe that everyone everywhere, should have the right to reach their potential and that poverty should not be a limiting factor in determining the level of success people can achieve, but unfortunately it is. By donating, you will not only be motivating us to run/walk/crawl 100km, you will be directly working to combat injustice and inequality on a globe scale.

The reason for creating this page is my passion for the charity, Oxfam. Oxfam support over 94 countries across the world, providing security, clean water and the tools and equipment needed for everyone to live a healthy and fulfilled life. Oxfam support those facing poverty and every penny raised will go directly to supporting those in need of Oxfam.

I am a Psychology student at Plymouth University and I have been given the amazing opportunity to potentially steward for Oxfam. This will mean I work at some of the most popular festivals throughout the summer and ensure everything runs smoothly. As well as becoming a steward, I wanted to help Oxfam further, by deciding to fundraise £200 I will be able to pay for 24 water wells to be drilled and built. This means clean water will be provided for over 20 communities, something we take for granted, but many desperately need.

Thank you so much for reading this and having a look at my page. Please consider donating and if you do donate, thank you so much!!

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
I’m on my mission to give aids to the people who are suffering and to make them live their best life in this world.

As we all know, majority of people globally struggles to survive for their life which includes suffered kids, oppressed women, and families living in extreme poverty. Refugees are fleeing away from their unstable countries to seek for asylum, they are in need for survival kits and health treatments. So, I’m planning to start a charity drive to help them as much as I possibly could. In order to execute this mission,

I’ll contribute 20% of what I’ve received from my graphic design service, to charity.


I believe in power of giving. “If you contribute more, you’ll get more in return.”


Please help me to reach my target and dig deep now. There will be lots of opportunities for you to support me and get the benefits at the same time.

Oxfam is one of the world’s largest charity organization and I’m very proud to be one of their supporter in contributing whatever I’ve got to make this world a better place to live. So, I would like to take this opportunity to personally invite anyone of you who are reading this post to contribute a part of your value for the cause. 

This is the least thing I could do to pay my contribution to the world. Even though my graphic design service could not help directly in terms giving aid or manpower, but I’ve always wanted to contribute some portion of my services for charity. So, this is my way to be the part of making others living their best life in this world. My goal is to raise as much as possible for the charity drive by raising my service standards to the best quality as possible.

What inspires me to do the charity drive is by looking inspiring from big entrepreneurs out there giving away their life and money to help others. Bill Gates is one of the people I am inspired by, whom donated most of his wealth for charity reasons around the globe. I do realize that I’m not that so called a big company to donate most of my wealth to charity. But I believe that with every small step I’ve made, I could make a difference in someone’s life.

I chose Oxfam as my charity platform because they are doing a great job on giving aids to the needs out there in all around the world. Oxfam is a movement of millions of people, all working towards one goal – an end to poverty for everyone. I believe on what they believed, “In a world rich in resources, poverty isn’t inevitable.” I feel that I’m not the one whom need the most from the resources, so I think I should give my part to someone who need it the most. Oxfam believe that everyone should be able to eat, drink, earn and learn as much as we do. 

Through Oxfam and their partners, 4.3 million people got access to clean water, 2 million people got food, cash or vouchers to survive a crisis, and 1.7 million women were supported to exercise their rights. They couldn't have done it without someone like us. 

On average for every £1 donated to Oxfam, they invest 84p on their humanitarian, development and campaigning work. They invest 8p to raise further funds, and they invest 8p on support and running costs such as paying the salaries of staff who work all year round to deliver their work and who ensure they are effective and accountable.

To conclude and to mention it again, the idea behind the charity drive is to cut off 20% from every income I’ve received from my graphic design service and donating them to charity. So, obviously, the more I get, the more I will give in return and more people I could contribute to. This is my goal. All donation will go straight to my profile at JustGiving.com and will be donated to Oxfam. 

Thank you for all you support!

Regards,
Azri Omar

Me again. I'm running the London Marathon for Oxfam on Sunday. This year, things are tougher for them, and the projects they fund, for reasons I'm sure you know about. The photomontage shows me in 2004, 2005, 2007, 2015, 2016 & 2017.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Hey everyone 

Thanks for visiting our Just Giving page! We are a team of four women who are willing to undertake the endurance of the 100K Oxfam TrailWalker Challenge through the South Downs from the Queen Elizabeth County Park in Hampshire, starting at 6am on the 14 July to trek day and night non-stop until we reach Brighton! The event is timed and we plan to finish in sub-24 hours so we can be in Brighton for breakfast! 

This will be the ultimate challenge for our team as we have never undergone an ultra before! Made up of runners, hikers, trailwalkers and cyclists, though our outdoor activity styles are different we all share a love of a challenge and a passion for life. This challenge will definitely be our toughest to date but we are excited to be part of it and work to become Trailwalker Legends!! To hike, walk and run solid for 24 hours will test us to our limits of mental and physical strength. The route was set by The Gurka Signals over 30 years ago as the ultimate test of teamwork and endurance for new recruits with a total ascent of 2,500m - the equivalent of Ben Nevis and Snowdonia combined - this will be no walk in the park. To achieve this challenge we will be training for months to make sure we are Trailwalker fit and to make you all an Oxfam proud!

For more information about the challenge check out Oxfam's website https://www.oxfam.org.uk/Trailwalker. We aim to raise a minumum of £1400 which will provide live-saving hygiene kits to protect 241 parents and children in Niger from waterbourne disease. Kits include water purification tablets, safe water storage, cups and soap. £1650 would provide safe drinking water for 1,650 people. Clean water is an essential for life and should be a basic human right. Please help us make that happen. 

Thank you 

Hannah, Louise, Carrie and Tilly

story:
The What:

The Mongol Rally 2018 – a 10,000 mile journey across 20 countries starting in London and Finishing in Ulan Ude, Russia (just outside Mongolia as they quite rightly decided they were not keen on of loads of rubbish cars being left on the Steppe...) There are only three rules to this rally: 1) our car must be cheap, rubbish, inappropriate and have an engine no bigger than 1,000cc, 2) we're completely on our own, with no support, and 3) we're raising money for charity.

The Who:

Three humanitarian aid workers, raising money for Oxfam and Cool Earth (the official Charity of the Mongol Rally 2018.

The When:

Departing from London on Friday 13th July (yes, we see the irony...) and hoping to arrive at the finish line sometime towards the end of August.

The How:

In our trusted steed - a 1988 Bedford Bambi (if you don’t know just how unsuitable this is for long distance off road travel, see here: http://www.bedfordrascal.com/bambi.html)

The Name:

'Live to Drive, Drive to Die' - without question, the funniest, stupidest slogan we've seen painted on a minibus taxi on our travels. Not necessarily a life creed we subscribe to... But it makes us chuckle.

The Why:

The most important part…

While going on an adventure is fun, even if you hate your friends by the end of it, there should always be a better reason too. This is why we are fundraising for Oxfam.

As humanitarians who work around the world with various organisations, we have listened to, watched and discussed the scandals that have affected the charity sector over the recent months. What has happened in many places is indefensible, yet, without adequate resources the issue will not be solved, and more importantly – it will be the beneficiaries and communities in which Oxfam work that will be affected, and that is truly unacceptable.

So, we should explain why we’re raising funds for Oxfam…

Oxfam lost 7,000 private donors in the first week of the recent news stories. Multiple government agencies paused or suspended funding, sometimes to on-going programmes, and it is this response that we want to address.

It’s both the reaction and the consequence that are problematic.

The reaction to Oxfam was a kneejerk one, because aid is an easy target.

Reactions should be proportionate. Hold those responsible to account, force change in working environments and practices, resource properly to enable those working to do it to the highest standards; and that only addresses the reaction.

What about the consequence? It will be hard to measure, but there is one thing we can say for sure:

Those thousands of private donations that give invaluable unrestricted funding to the organisation will make it harder to rectify the mistakes of the past, not easier. When government agencies stop projects half way through, there won’t be anyone else to fill the gap and those families affected by conflict, natural disasters and poverty will suffer.

The reaction doesn’t help, it makes it worse, it makes it worse for the staff in country offices around the world, it makes it worse for those communities they are helping, and it makes it worse for those beneficiaries who stop receiving the assistance they need to survive.

As such, we are asking you to stand with us as humanitarians, as people who care about other people, as people who want to alleviate suffering where it exists and support the incredible work that Oxfam continue to do. They have done amazing work all over the world, now is not the time to walk away, now is the time to stand up and be counted, while they make the changes they need to, to be an even better organisation than the one they already are.

So, please give generously! And, to follow our progress, check out our Instagram: livetodrivedrivetodie

story:
The idea of this page is to enable you to donate excess credit from your PAYG mobile phone account to an excellent cause. You can do this by texting OXFA70 £n to 70070, where n is 1,2,3,4,5, or 10. So to donate £10, you'd text OXFA70 £10 to 70070.

You'll receive an acknowledgement text which includes a link so that taxpayers can Gift Aid their donation. You'll also be offered a choice between anonymity and having your contact details passed on. Please choose anonymity - I don't want to know who is donating, I just want you to donate to my chosen cause!

100% of text donations and of any Gift Aid goes to the charity. It isn't restricted to PAYG; for Pay Monthly, the donation is added to your next invoice. It is open to users of all UK mobile networks, and the admin is done by JustTextGiving. 

You can also donate by card using the purple 'Donate' link on this page if you prefer, and a small service fee is deducted from your donation.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Starting on the 1st March I'm going to be giving up alcohol for at least a month. Possibly longer! I'm a big fan of beer so this is a huge thing for me! I'll admit that it's not totally for selfless reasons. I'd like to be a bit more healthy and not spend my money on beer all the time, but I thought why not make it a thing and raise some money for Oxfam in the process!

Oxfam is a global movement of millions of people who share the belief that, in a world rich in resources, poverty isn't inevitable. In just 15 years, extreme poverty has been halved. 15 more years and we can end it for good.

Being a volunteer of Oxfam for a number of years now they were the obvious choice as I'm fully aware of the amazing work they do for people in extreme poverty. Sponsor me today and 82p of every pound you donate goes goes directly to emergency, development and campaigning work.

It would be amazing to raise at least 200 pounds as this would pay: -
To train 4 family's to grow their own food or,
For 320 mosquito nets for children or,
To drill 24 wells for clean safe drinking water.

Please donate as little or as much as you can afford, thank you.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
I grew up in Mexico City and my family still live there. As you will know, Mexico has now been hit by three devastating earthquakes in recent weeks which killed more than 250 people and injured 700 more.

I am blessed to be able to say that all my close family and friends are safe, however it wasn’t until they described to me the current situation that I realised the scale of the devastation suffered by my home city and country.

Thousands of families have lost their homes including friends of my mum, but the most affected people are those in the most deprived communities who have lost everything and are in desperate need of help.

A lot of my friends and relatives have been actively providing support and volunteering around the city and it makes me sad to be so far away at this time and not being able to be there to do my bit. That is why I decided to start a fund and give up some of my time over the next three months to raise money. I have chosen to raise money for Oxfam who have created a dedicated ‘Earthquake in Mexico’ fund, which will be 100% used for support services and relief and recovery efforts for affected areas.

We are so lucky to live in a country where we are safe from natural disasters like those recently seen in Mexico and in the Caribbean, as well as to benefit from the basic safety net provided by the welfare state.

If you can spare a bit money and would like to donate through my just giving page then I will be very grateful. If you would like to find out a bit more or would like to help me with my fundraising endeavors I’d love to hear from you.

Many thanks Maribel

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
IF WE RAISE £1000 ON THIS PAGE FOR OXFAM; ME AND JOE WILL DO A SPONSORED PARACHUTE JUMP AND WE'LL DYE OUR HAIR PURPLE. (the colour of the Oxjam brand).


A new type of music festival that is part of Oxfam’s rich musical history. This one will be held in our own very local town! Tunbridge Wells.

Oxjam started 2006 with the aim of creating a network of music-loving people across the UK, all united by a shared goal – to raise money to fight poverty and suffering around the world.

It’s a community festival run by volunteers and made up of multi-venue festivals and gigs taking place across the UK throughout October. It’s all about supporting independent music venues and providing a platform for up and coming musical talent while raising money to fight poverty and inequality worldwide. Now that’s something we can all get behind.

Since 2006 we’ve gone on to host more than 60,000 musicians playing to an audience of 1.5 million people, and have helped break bands such as Everything Everything, Foals, Young Fathers and Drenge. We’ve also had backing from the likes of Metronomy, Annie Mac, Mr Jukes and Fatboy Slim.

Facebook: www.facebook.com/OxjamTW/

Instagram: www.instagram.com/oxjamtunbridgewells/

Twitter: twitter.com/OxjamTW

TICKET LINK: po.st/OXJAMTW

Local Music. Global Impact.

story:
On the 13th of July 2018, I will be taking part in the Trailwalker. The aim is to walk 100km of the South Downs Way in 24 hours with a team of 3 others. That means hiking through the night, depriving ourselves of sleep, living off sugary snacks and caring for our feet like our lives depend on the absence of blisters.

We've started training already, putting in the km's along parts of the route and so far our feet remain mostly intact. That said, our longest hike so far was 35km, which is a third of the event. Gulp.

The event is organised by Oxfam and ran in conjunction with the Gurkhha Welfare Trust, so proceeds will be split between two very worthy organisations.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Why am I running my first ever marathon? I ask myself this every time my alarm goes off to go for a run at 5:30am...

When my alarm goes off I wake up in the knowledge that I have access to food, clean water, and have a job to earn a wage. For lots of people around the world they do not have this same access.

Often people are stuck in poverty or crisis due to factors out of their control. Take the 665,000 Rohingya refugees who have fled their homes, fleeing after 7,000 of their friends and families were killed in one month. 
That's 7,000 people killed in the time it took for you to open your advent calendar this Christmas

And why?  Because in 1948 when Myanmar was granted independence Rohyinga people were not granted citizenship, even though they had been living there for generations, ignored just because of who they are. Not what they have done, or anything else. Simply for being themselves.

So this is what brings me to run the London Marathon for Oxfam. While I recognise I am lucky to be in the position I am, I recognise this is largely attributed to factors out of my control, just given to me through my luck of upbringing. Is this fair?

Many people are stuck in poverty just because of where they happened to pop out into the world and catch their first breath; faced with many factors out of their control.

 Oxfam recognises there are many routes/reasons to poverty and tirelessly works to alleviate them and bring people out of poverty. Constantly refocusing and changing it's campaigns to the latest crisis or need. Oxfam are currently on the ground helping the Rohingya people, and have currently touched base with 185,000 providing access to clean water and food. 

So I hope by running the marathon I am able to raise money and help people get out of poverty and have a basic standard of life that we all deserve.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.




****UPDATE*******

The last few weeks there have been shocking revelations about Oxfam UK in the press. I have read and reviewed all the information carefully, and I am still proud to be running the marathon for Oxfam UK.

Here are my reasons:

1)    It won’t be Oxfam which suffers from fundraising cuts it will be the people most vulnerable caught in crisis

2)    Oxfam is in a unique position to shape the future of the Aid industry and stamp out abuse

Oxfam is one of the largest most recognised charities in the world, it is now in the spotlight and will continue to be in the spotlight. By continuing to support Oxfam, we can push Oxfam to set a gold standard in safe guarding, and best practices in vulnerable situations to ensure this never happens again. We don’t need Oxfam just for the charity it can give, we need Oxfam for it’s unique position it now finds itself in to drive real change.

3)    The horrendous actions of the minority shouldn’t punish the good work of the majority

9 people have been accused of sexual misconduct out of a global organisation of 10,000 employees. The rest of these 10,000 people are just as shocked as we are. If we applied fundraising cuts like those proposed to Oxfam to Hollywood following the Harvey Weinstein scandal film screenings would be empty and DVD shelves bare. 

An interesting article on the psychology of outrage and shift in severity can be read here https://www.ft.com/content/5954a160-1240-11e8-8cb6-b9ccc4c4dbb

“Righteous outrage is a powerful weapon, and one that has smashed many barriers of injustice. We should pull the trigger of that weapon with care, not with abandon.”- Tim Harford, The Financial Times , 16/2/18

***********************

Thank you! - Team Perham

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Oxfam need our help to reach 500,000 people affected by Typhoon Haiyan.

Typhoon Haiyan, one of the strongest storms ever recorded, has struck the Philippines. Oxfam is ready to deploy water and sanitation materials to those affected.

Rapid assessment teams are on the ground to provide urgent emergency supplies and shelter on the islands of Samar, Leyte and Cebu where near-total devastation is reported.

Donate now to help Oxfam reach people with life-saving aid.

Every penny and pound really does count. £27 could provide 10 Oxfam buckets to help provide clean water. £50 could provide 100 emergency health kits.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Our names are Dylan, Henry and Sam. We are all seven years old in year three and we live in Christchurch in Dorset. 

We were very upset by the fact that 93,000 people have died in the Syrian civil war and wanted to do something to help. We kept on watching it on the news and although we know this isn't going to happen to us we did imagine what it would be like if 93,000 of us died or if we or our families had to run away from our house and leave our things.

So me Henry and Sam decided to do a fun run in October. We are doing lots of training so we get really good at running. We want to try to raise £50 each.

What's happening in Syria is terrible and the more people who know about it the better as we want to show the people of Syria that we have not forgotten about them and care about what is happening.

We want to stop bad injuries and deaths and want to raise the money to get a tent to help people and maybe help them to buy a house. We think Oxfam will help make things a bit better.

So we want to get people to sponsor us.

The Fun Run will take place between Southbourne and Bournemouth Pier in October half term. My little brother Rufus who is 6 will ride on his bike with us to help encourage us to keep on going too. Lily who is Henry's little sister will also ride along with us too. 

 

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
GBI Cycle Challenge - Luxembourg to Dusseldorf - DONE!

On 3rd July 2013, I took part in a cycling challenge from Luxembourg to Dusseldorf covering 402km over 3 days (Luxembourg, Belgium and Germany)

This is my longest bike challenge so far and did it to support Oxfam UK (Syria Crisis Appeal).

It was an amazing experience/ journey… Great views, New friends and raised money for Charity.

I can’t wait to do it again next year!!!

If anyone wants to join in, then the challenge will be to cycle from Budapest to Munich..

It’s a long way - but you will not regret it!

HUGE THANKS to everyone who has alread supported me..

You can still donate online or by texting SHEZ48 £10 (or whatever amount you like) to 70070. It's free, easy to set up and every penny goes to charity!

owner: Melinda Warby - Tyneside Rejects and the Lady
story:
Thanks very much for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page! Mug shots above...

In a moment of madness we all agreed to take part in Trailwalker 2018 for Oxfam and The Gurkhas Trust.  We will join many others between the 13-15th July 2018 to walk across the South Downs starting in Queen Elizabeth Country Park (near Petersfield, Hampshire) and ending on Brighton Race Course. All in under 30 hours.

Steve Perrins, Graeme Fletcher and James Mortimer are all fine, athletic specimens, ex-army and if it wasn't for me (and Steve's knees), I am sure they would be marching round in no time!  Sorry lads!

For my part, this is the first time that I have ever attempted anything like this. Training has begun in earnest and to save the ears of my fellow team members from my grumbles and groans on the way round, I will be putting a vast "Rocky training" play list together!

Now for the dough.... there will be many of you I am sure who would pay good money to see the Tyneside Rejects and the Lady go through this pain. I am pretty sure I won't be looking much like a lady by the end of it! Thankfully it will be dark!  ANY donations that you are able to give will be gratefully received and hugely appreciated.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.


Thank you all in advance for your generosity.

From

Steve, James, Graeme and Melinda (aka.. the Tyneside Rejects and the Lady)

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Each Trailwalker team pledges to raise £1,400 for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust as part of their challenge. Broken down between all 4 walking team members, this works out at just £350 per person!

The money will be used for many different causes such as providing live-saving hygiene kits to protect 241 parents and children in Niger from waterbourne disease. Kits include water purification tablets, safe water storage, cups and soap. It will also be used to fund a Gurkha Welfare Trust nurse for six months, helping to provide medical aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities and much much more. 

Please help us smash this target and pledge what you can. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page, I would like to share our journey and story with you all.

Our beautiful mummy’s chapter has sadly come to an end on earth, she went to sleep peacefully and beautifully on 26th January 2017. Her soul was returned to heaven to embrace her new journey as angel.

She had so much love and joy to give - she was selfless, courageous, strong, determined, kind and thoughtful. She has taught us so much about what it truly means to be a family and shown us the importance of loving the people that you meet in your life; be it your spouse, your children, your friends or a stranger in time of need. Her heart lives on through all of us and all those who have ever known her. 

In her final moments, we were with her every step of the way. She used all her strength to open her eyes and looked at us individually to say "I love you" and then a final "I love you all". She told us that she was going to sleep and tomorrow will be a better day.

She fought so hard and so well - sometimes things aren't meant to be and it’s ok because we’ve learnt to let her be free from the body that she was trapped in. Her last eye contacts was fixated on my dad and she used such energy to say "I love you" - A selfless act.

We are fundraising for our mummy’s favourite charity, she used to say the more charitable and kindness you can show and act on, one day you will return to the heavens above as an angel.

I will leave you with her words that she used to say to me: "It's ok to have good days and it's ok to have bad days - you're only human! 

In the end what pulls you through the tough times is the power of the mind. Take a chance even if the chances are slim it's still a chance, as long as you believe it you can do it, it will happen. Love your children, love your spouse, be kind to others, be kind to yourself. 

Even when the time does come, face it with bravery and dignity but don't face it alone. You're only going to sleep and if you're not afraid of going to sleep you're not afraid of anything else. 

This is not dying, this is just a beginning to a new journey and make every moment that you have a precious one too, think of happier times don't look back with sorrow and continue fighting to the very end. Stay in the moment, take one step and one day at a time and always try your best, never live a moment of regret."

Sleep well my gracious angel, I love you so much and I'm so proud of you - we all are. Your gorgeous smile and kind heart will always be in our memories. Love you mummy. Xxx

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

We would like to take this opportunity to ride in support of Oxfam. Some of us have been supporting the work of Oxfam for many years and now more than ever Oxfam needs all the support it can get. We believe it is critical for Oxfam to be able to continue it's vital crisis response and development work helping millions of people around the world who depend on it. We would like to emphasise that all the money you may donate will go directly to Oxfam. None of any money donated comes to us or is used to fund the ride.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
The devastating earthquakes and after shocks which have hit in Nepal in the last few weeks have left 8000 dead, 14000 injured, over 700,000 homeless and 8 million affected. Already a country battling poverty, Nepal is suffering immensly as a result. 

Although several thousand miles away, each and every one of us is still able to help out. For SURC , Nepal is a country close to many of our members adventuring hearts and so we've decided to get fundraising.

What is happening?
 
SURC (Southampton University Road Cycling club) are putting on 48-hour non-strop rollathon in support the Oxfam's Nepal Appeal to try and cycle the equivalent distance of Southampton to Kathmandu.  It’s taking place on 29-31st May on Campus.  We'll keep 8 sets of rollers constantly going by alternating riders with the intention of riding this massive distance. There will be music, lights, a big crowd and food/drinks to keep everyone going through the nights.

How can I get involved?

As you can imagine, SURC will need lots of people for this mammoth task, that is where you come in. If you can give just an hour of your time over the weekend that would be amazing. If you are free and around, I urge you to take part. The sign-up is here https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1eaWQQpZI98lyPqFtiZ6USzrJufIaDqeLTUIbv4suE9Y/viewform?usp=send_form.

If you can't make the weekend, then we'd love if it you wanted to make a donation directly to Oxfam through this website.

Thank you for you support.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
We are the Sir John Lawes School Oxfam Youth Action Group, a group of young people from ages 11 to 18 who campaign, fundraise and raise awareness for Oxfam. We are united by our desire to bring about social justice and help those who are suffering in the world.

Our current focus is on South Sudan, where fierce fighting has forced more than a million people from their homes. Oxfam has already reached 261,000 people at several locations across South Sudan with food, clean water, sanitation, and hygiene materials and training. They urgently need help from people like us to be able to offer assistance to more people and prevent the crisis from turning into a catastrophe.

We chose this project to work on as South Sudan is something of an unseen crisis, which isn't usually prominent in the media, and which many people in our school and the wider community may never have heard of before. As such, we set up a 'mock refugee camp' at our school one lunchtime to raise awareness amongst the student body.

We will be camping for the night at school, and would massively appreciate any donations, however big or small, that you are able to give. Together we really can make a difference.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thank you.

Susi, Dottie, Jack, Charlotte, Chloe, Kyran, Zoe, Miriam, Polly, Louis, Aimie, Meg, Lauren, Ellen, Lena and Cameron- the SJL Oxfam Youth Action Group

charity.description:
Money raised during Trailwalker goes to Oxfam, to fund their work tackling poverty and suffering.
Oxfam works in over 100 countries worldwide.
charity.name: Oxfam Trailwalker Japan
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

This year, we are taking part in a charity event – Oxfam Trailwalker 2014 (Japan).

Oxfam Trailwalker is a challenging endurance fundraising event in which teams of 4 complete a 43/100 km hike through mountainous terrain of over 1,200 meters elevation difference in 48 hours or less!

We believe it is meaningful to support the work of OXFAM with our fundraising activity and physical endeavours. The donations will be used to implement projects in many of the poorest regions of the world to help end poverty and provide vital relief following natural disasters and conflict. Please go to http://www.oxfam.jp/en/ for more information about OXFAM and details about how collected donations have been used.

It would be hard to achieve this all alone but we believe we can be successful as a team. Your participation and donation in this event will makes a real difference in the world.

We are training together, fund-raising together, sticking together and finishing together in this opportunity to do a greater good for society!

Please cheer us on and sponsor us now!

You may donate through http://JustGiving.com/arafo . Of course, cash donation is welcome as well. (we promise to turn your money in!)

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Today (February 12), the Disaster Emergency Committee has said that it's members would not be not be offering help to those affected by the recent floods in the UK. See Daily Express article.

As a result, Oxfam's Twitter and Facebook have been overwhelmed with seemingly outraged comments by users who say they will no longer donate to Oxfam.

We feel it is important to show Oxfam that this view definitely isn't shared by all, that we continue to support their work, and that they have made the right decision to put their resources where they are most needed -- which is why we have created this fundraising campaign!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. We were inspired by watching the London Marathon last year and set ourselves the challenge of running for the very first time in 2018. Oxfam helps fight against poverty around the world so as well as the personal challenge of running our first ever marathon, we will be driven by the thought that we are helping others live an easier life with the things that we take for granted...things like food, water, shelter and safety. We are just lucky to have been born poverty free...millions around the world, and even in the UK are not so lucky and by reaching our fundraising target (£2000 each for me and my husband Nick) we will be contributing £4000 to help fight poverty.

Please help us by giving as much as you can. Watch out for our fundraising events as well. We will be organising a Silent Disco and will publish details soon. Try and come along if you can.

charity.name: Oxfam
eventName: A Night With Sara Shahidi And Friends
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page for "A Night With Sara Shahidi And Friends".

Oxfam is a global movement of millions of people who share the belief that, in a world rich in resources, poverty isn't inevitable. In just 15 years, extreme poverty has been halved. 15 more years and we can end it for good.

Oxfam supports refugees by helping to provide life saving hygiene kits to stop the spread of disease, provide families with clean drinking water and help to build toilet and washing facilities for families made homeless. In Syria, Jordan and Lebanon, Oxfam provides life-saving clean water, sanitation and vital support for families who have lost everything.  In Greece, Italy, Serbia and Macedonia Oxfam provides water, food, clothes and personal hygiene kits, as well as longer term psychological and legal support. And around the world, Oxfam is making sure that people fleeing conflict have the life-saving essentials they need.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.  Running the London Marathon has always been on my bucket list and I'm so happy that I'm able to do this whilst raising money for a charity that I really believe are doing amazing things.

Oxfam helps support millions of people living in poverty around the world and are constantly helping those affected by humanitarian crises and natural disasters.  Not only do Oxfam provide emergency aid to those affected by wars and tragedies, they also work with local communities to set up irrigation systems, farming and training so that societies can become self-sufficient and break out of the poverty cycle. If anyone would like to learn more about the work that Oxfam do, please visit: www.oxfam.org.uk/what-we-do

It is estimated that half of the world (over 3 billion people) live on less than $2.50 a day and 80% of the world lives on less than $10 a day. Especially with the natural disasters that have recently occurred and the current conflicts going on in the world, it is so important that those of us who are able to, make an effort to help those who are so much less fortunate than ourselves.  Any contributions you can make to this very worthy cause would be greatly appreciated.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure.  Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails.  Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. It's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thanks,
Kami

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

In two weeks time, I will be running the Perth City to Surf 12km run to raise money to support the victims of the recent earthquakes in Lombok, Indonesia. I was on the nearby island of Bali at the time of the first earthquake and since then there have been a series of further earthquakes that have devastated north Lombok, as well as the neighbouring Gili islands. I have been lucky enough to spend two months in this beautiful part of the world and the locals are amongst the kindest and most humble people I've met.

So far, around 400 people have been killed, thousands of people have been injured, thousands of buildings destroyed and around 400,000 people have been made homeless. Oxfam are helping in the relief effort, providing urgently needed supplies to those affected. Any donations made will support Oxfam's emergency responses in Lombok and around the world.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Stourport High School has a long history of supporting worthy causes. Oxfam is just such an example and this year has launched a Nepal Appeal.

Nepal has recently been hit by two massive earthquakes and a landslide. It is a poor country with limited resources. We,as a country, have strong links with Nepal through our military association with the Gurkhas and as such the country needs our help.

On the 10th July students will be undertaking several sessions on Oxfam, the Gurkhas and Trailwalker (a charitable event set up to raise money for the Gurkha Welfare Trust and Oxfam). This will raise awareness and hopefully inspire students to get involved along with raising awareness of the wider world around them.

Any donation, large or small, will massively help us to reach our target.

Thanks in advance.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Oxfam Oxy-Gym has been set up for people who love a gym challenge or who just love challenges. The idea is to raise money through sports.

The Press Up is one of the best Chest, Shoulders and Arm building move's around, it show's both strength and endurance.

The Challenge
Start standing then go into the press up position, do one press up, then stand. Then back into the press up position, do two press ups and stand. Then back into the press up position and do three press ups and then on until failure. How many press ups can you get up to?

Nominate 3 people after the challenge, put your challenge on FaceBook for everyone to see.

Text OGPU 83 to 70070 to donate £3 now.

All money raised will go to Oxfam's Water and Sanitation projects.

Tukes are a group of ukulele enthusiasts who are excited to bring their modest talents to Henley-on-Thames for a busk on 25th August 2018, between 10:30 am and 12:30 pm, in the Market Square.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
We all did Trailwalker last year, coming in the top 50 of over 400 teams, and plan to get round, ideally a bit quicker, this year. We are all now over 50 so maybe we need to manage our expectations a bit!!!  We all joined the Army in 1987. Jon Cole, Jim Forest and I starting our careers at Sandhurst and Tol-Saheb as a recruit in Pokhara, Nepal.  Jon and Tol are still serving, but Jim and I are now both “civvies”.   Viasat are, as last year, kindly sponsoring our team strip.  Whilst this is a significant endurance event for us, it is about the Gurkha Welfare Trust and Oxfam and helping ex-servicemen and their families, and the people of Nepal. 

Nepal is one of the poorest countries in the world, and has suffered a great deal in the last few years.  It also has a long standing and close relationship with the UK and the British Army.  During my military career I was blessed to serve with Gurkhas, at home and on operations,  have been lucky enough to trek in Nepal and also settled many Gurkha soldiers and their families into Stafford, a new location for them as part of the Regiment I commanded back in 2007-2009.  Gurkhas are superb soldiers and officers and still provide a brigades worth of manpower to the Army.  

Thanks, Neil..

charity.name: Oxfam
eventName: Putting our heads together for Syria!
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our Oxfam JustGiving page.

Jay and I decided that Syrian refugees needed more help, obviously! What's going on in Syria is both horrific and totally unacceptable. No one deserves to have to flee for their lives, only to then find themselves stuck in 3rd world conditions because other countries don't know what to do with them. We chose UNICEF and Oxfam as they both have a great track records for helping refugees and those in crisis. If we raise enough on this Oxfam page and our UNICEF page, as a thank you and just for a little fun, WE'LL SHAVE OUR HEADS!!!

Thanks for the support :) please share! 

Lots of love, 

Marchie and Cheshire xx
title: Putting our heads together for Syria with Oxfam!

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Not known for shirking personal challenges and wanting to do my bit for society, I’ll be running the London Marathon 2019 in aid of Oxfam, a worldwide renowned charity respected for their fight against poverty, promotion of human rights and disaster relief assistance.

I aim to raise £2,000, so I would be grateful for every £\€ donated. 

———————————————————————

Da ich nicht dafür bekannt bin, mich vor Herausforderungen zu entziehen und meinen Beitrag für die Gesellschaft leisten möchte, werde ich 2019 den London Marathon mit einer Spendenaktion für die weltweit bekannte Stiftung Oxfam laufen. Sie ist für ihren Kampf gegen Armut, ihre Förderung der Menschenrechte und Einsatz in der Katastrophenhilfe bekannt. 

Ich möchte £2000 sammeln, deshalb wäre ich über jeden Euro/jedes Pfund sehr dankbar.

Wenn Sie ein deutsches Konto haben, ändern Sie bitte die Währung in Euro, damit Sie keine Gebühr zahlen müssen.

eventName: Mount Kilimanjaro Trek with Discover Adventure September 2018
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

In September 2018 I will be climbing to the Roof of Africa and the worlds tallest free standing mountain which stands at a height of 19,340 ft or the equivalent of 1018 Giraffes :)

The climb will take up to 8 days, walking/climbing for approximately 6-8 hours per day over very challenging and tough terrain/conditions.

Thank you so much for any donation of any amount in helping to bring an end to extreme global poverty and for aiding in my motivation to reach the top!

Best wishes and thanks again! Harvey x

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
UPDATE - Due to injury we are having to possibly postpone the walk for a year so this page will be kept up until then




Keeping this short because I'm lazy (not looking good so far), but our team of 4 are planning to walk 100km in one go taking around 26-28 hours. 

"Why am I doing this" is something I have said many times at 3am in the morning but this will be the first time I won't be blind drunk and I'm all about new experiences.

I think the biggest challenge will be will be trying not to well up over all the good things the money raised is going to fund. Well it would be if I wasn't walking 100km. 100km is f****** far. I can't even be bothered to drive 100km. I don't even think the proclaimers would walk 100km just to be the one who wakes up next to you. 

Also I've bought a new water bottle, some shoes and a 10mm pistol (in case it gets too bleak) so please donate because you have no idea how annoying hiking boot salesmen are. 

PS if anyone has ever wanted to break my legs now is ideal

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am going to be cycling 100 miles starting in Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park and finishing on The Mall in central London. 

I am hoping to raise £50 for Oxfam. For every £1 given to Oxfam, 82p goes directly to emergency, development and
campaigning work. I am hoping to help Oxfam in their work in the current Yemen crisis where millions of men, women and children are one step away from famine. A staggering 18.8 million people are in desperate need of help and my fundraising will hopefully help support Oxfam in supplying clean, safe water for drinking and washing.

charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

In Christmas of 2013 Foreign Concept, Stray and Xtrah got their heads  together and decided that rather than let some sought after unreleased music sit idle on their hard drives they would put it to use and offer people the chance to download the tracks whilst raising money for charity. 

This year Foreign Concept has gone one step further and we at Critical have all gone through the vaults and put an album together, again for a good cause. This time we have chosen Oxfam. Oxfam is a vibrant global movement of dedicated people fighting poverty. From saving lives and developing projects that put poor people in charge of their lives and livelihoods, to campaigning for change that lasts.

All monies go directly to the charity.  

Please give generously and enjoy the music!

Merry Christmas from all at Critical Music x

story:
While I am cycling across Cambridgeshire chasing steeples I'd like to be motivated by supporting a charity, albeit latest misconduct, still works in 90 countries in emergencies and making tremendous positive change providing help for people to get food and the essentials they need to survive and ensuring the most vulnerable are kept safe from harm.

Your contributions will give me determination and goal to finish the ride knowing that it is not just for fun or more likely to be pain with no gain.

I am part of the greater Arkessa team. Support us by supporting my cause or other causes that my team is cycling for.

charity.name: Oxfam
eventName: Barbara Walmsley's Boxfam Lady - October Fast
story:
As I'm sure you are aware this year has not been easy for Oxfam.  Of course, the behaviour of seven former Oxfam employees in Haiti was completely inexcusable and Oxfam has been the first to admit it. 

What we might remember is why Oxfam was there in the first place.  They were combatting a terrible cholera epidemic caused by people drinking polluted river water which killed nearly 8,000 Haitians over a period of two years, following the devastation created by an earthquake.    

As a result of the savage attacks by the majority of the press those of us who care passionately about the continuation of Oxfam's work are trying harder than ever to ensure that that works goes on.

I was overwhelmed by the many messages of support I received when the news broke.  People phoned, told me when they
met me they would continue to support Oxfam, some took extra donations into our shops and I even got flowers! 

Of course, Oxfam are having to cut back on projects and in other ways which is heart-breaking for the beneficiaries but it is still a strong and valued organisation and with 76 years' experience, is still doing wonderful and lifesaving work often in very dangerous situations.

In this 33rd year I need your generosity more than ever before.  So
please sponsor my cardboard friend who will be "fasting" with me for
28 hours at Sainsbury's on Friday 12th, Saturday 13th and Sunday 14th of October. 

Together we can still make the world a fairer place and give those who exist in grinding poverty a chance to help themselves.

Thank you for reading this letter and for your wonderful generosity in the
past.

With all good wishes

Yours hopefully

Barbara

ご覧いただき、有難うございます。

我々はオックスファム・トレイルウォーカーに参加します。

このイベントは４人1組のチームで参加する世界的に行われているウォーキング・イベントです。自分の体力に挑戦すると同時に、参加をきっかけに寄付金を集めて国際協力に貢献するというもうひとつの挑戦が用意された企画で、これまでに香港、オーストラリア、ニュージーランド、イギリス、オランダ、カナダ、ベルギー、アイルランドで開催され、日本でも2007年から毎年開催されています。


オックスファム・トレイルウォーカーへのご寄付は、

国際協力団体オックスファムの実施する途上国の紛争・災害時の緊急支援、教育・農業支援などの国際協力活動に使われ、人々が貧困から立ち上がるために役立てられています。特に2015年は東北復興支援として開催地を福島となっています。

皆さんのご理解、ご協力をお願い致します。

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
James Tricker, Joseph Iacobucci, Peter Crawley and myself are embarking on this LONG walk on July 14th 2018 through the South Downs from Queen Elizabeth Country Park all the way to Brighton.



We have a time limit of 30 hours in which to complete the task.


On the surface sounds easily doable however, we will be walking through the night will have to face varying weather conditions and sleep deprivation.


On top of this our preparation has been minimal (in typical fashion) so any spare pennies you might have that could help would be very much appreciated.



Wish us luck! x

story:
Welcome to our Roppongi Rockets Treadstone JustGiving page!

We are back! We are running 100k again in the upcoming 2014 Oxfam trailwalker (5/16 - 5/18). We came third in 2012 (time 17H36M), and this time we want to come first! If you share our enthusiasm with us, please donate.

The Treadstone team includes; AKB, BEN, HIKO, YODA, YUSHI (Support)

You can find us (Team #005) here; http://www.trailwalker.jp/fundrasing/teamlist/

Please support us to raise money for childran in need. We are donating the money to Oxfam, who use the donation to help to overcome poverty, provide better education for shildren, and fight against hunger around the world.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Thanks for visiting our Just Giving site - the simplest way to contribute to Team GR8 Britain.

Oxfam Trailwalker is a challenging endurance fundraising event in which Akira, David, Lucy and Chris from the British Embassy, Tokyo will complete a 100km trail through bush terrain in 48 hours. We will be starting at Odawara and heading to Yamanaka-ko, one of Mt Fuji's five lakes. The walk will be completed between 16-18 May 2014.

Money raised will be used to support Oxfam’s programmes around the world - any donation amount is appreciated.

Thanks!

Team GR8 Britain

story:
This year ( From May 16-18 2014) , We are going to challenge Oxfam Trail walker 2014 challenge in  Japan

Form Thomson Reuters Tokyo office with our team mate  We will walk 100 km within 48 hours for helping overcome poverty and injustice in the developing country

our team name is 

Saioh Ga Uma (Inscrutable are the ways of heaven)
it mean that we can not predict future but we can try our best !!

Here is our team name and members

Team name: ITWH  at Thomson Reuters 

Team Mate:  

Atsuo Watanabe （Sales Process Specialist: F&R) )
Akira Kojima ( Account Executive: Ad Media )
Andrew Cockburn ( Account Manager : F&R) )
Naomi Terada ( Client Specialist :F&R)

 

 To participate this charity walk event , each walker team need to collect the donation for helping  developing country. please help for the donation if you are interest in this charity event


Here is detail and our challenge

 

Oxfam Trail walker is the world's greatest team challenge to help overcome poverty and injustice.

This charity event has been very successful and has a great reputation in building team spirit and achievement throughout world.

 About Oxfam

http://www.trailwalker.jp/en/aboutus/event_information/

charity.name: Oxfam Trailwalker Japan
story:
We are going to challenge Oxfam Trail Walker 2014 in Japan which is part of an international series, with an incredible 17 events being held around the world in 11 countries.

Our team will walk 100 kilometers in 48 hours - in all weather and across some rough terrain. We will work together to all complete the distance within the time.

As part of this challenge, we are raising funds for Oxfam's life-saving work thorough this event and your donation would be greatly appreciated.

Your donation will be used to fund Oxfam's emergency work worldwide.

Thank you!

Team Information;

No.091 Cairn Terrier

Yoichi Higashihara

Yuri Hatakeyama

Marina Haniu

Mai Hasegawa

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

On 14 July, while the South Downs Way basks in glorious sunshine, three rather nervous walkers from Team Gin and Bear It will be walking 100km up and down its spine, running from Petersfield in the west to Brighton race course in the east. 100km in 25 degrees of heat. Inside 30 hours. A huge physical and mental challenge, raising money for Oxfam and The Ghurka Welfare Trust. 

Your support will help us find the strength we need to get to the finish line.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
I plan to take on 100km of the South Downs with three friends on the 13th July 2018, it will test us all physically and mentally. We will re-think our limits, surprise each other and we’ll help end poverty with every step. 

The challenge will involve a Total ascent of 2,500m –  the equivalent of Ben Nevis  and Snowdon combined and Distance of 100km – the equivalent  of 2.5 marathons, non-stop. 

We’re not the fittest team to enter this challenge, and we certainly won’t be the fastest! But we aim to raise awareness for this cause and challenge ourselves in the process. None of us have ever attempted anything like this before, so please don’t think this will be a walk in the park. We aim to earn your donation!

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
I will be running the half marathon (my first one!) in Queenstown, NZ on the 17th of November and I am not just doing this for myself, but I will be running for Oxfam!

Oxfam is a non-profit organization that fights poverty, works on long term development around the globe and is an emergency responder. When disaster strikes, Oxfam is there. They ensure that people get the
essentials to survive, the most vulnerable are kept safe and they help rebuild communities to come back stronger from disasters.

I'm really proud to run as part of the Oxfam team, and it would be great if you can sponsor me. Any donation, no matter how small, will be greatly appreciated and all proceeds will go directly to Oxfam to help them continue the amazing work they do to help so many worldwide!

Thank you so much! Your support means a lot to me and everybody from Oxfam!

Keri

#TeamOxfam

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
story:
Hey lovelies -  I would just personally like to take the time to say a huge thank you to you for helping in any way you can - It really means so much to me and I really do love taking on challenges which make a huge impact to others..... doing things together and being the change the world needs. 

When this challenge got put to me I personally had just finished marathon training and I thought - 'it's only a walk'! How wrong could one be?!

Thank you for taking time to read our story and visit our page.

We are the Rural Rockstars - 3 Farmers Wives and a Gamekeepers daughter - All lovers of the great outdoors, all lovely friends -  a fitting challenge to be out in the stunning English countryside in all it's glory.

So ...... When Sara decided we should all take on this challenge, we all thought... 'it's just a walk, what can be so hard about that'?!

Also some of the husbands did this challenge a few years back and the main driver is to beat their time!!!

This without question is a huge challenge - not physically, but mentally too. 100km hiking the Southdowns non stop and within a time period of 30 hours.

Our start time is 7am on Saturday 14th July and we will walk non stop with small pit stops for changes of socks, shoes and refuelling with our trusty support crew - i.e - husbands, friends and partners! 

We will walk through the dead of night and hope to be landing up in Brighton at the racecourse somewhere around 8am the following day!

We have been training hard and trying our best to get hours on our feet, our aim is to complete the challenge as a team of 4 within 25 hours.

Are we confident? YES

Are we a little bit scared? YES

Will we do it? YES

So we would greatly appreciate your support in helping us push to reach our target amount.... we can assure you that will give it our absolute best and we will be eternally grateful to you for any donation amount you could possibly spare.

The weather looks set to be fair, we have trained in very hot weather and we would like to think that it may just be fair to us - not too hot and not too wet - we can hope and pray! But this is England so who blooming knows! Luck of the draw and all that jazz!

Whatever the case, we are looking forward to sharing the journey which is set to test us to our limits for sure.

With much love and thanks in advance

Alex, Sara, Lucinda and Alison

xxxxx

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am raising money for Sightsavers because having recently had a cataract removed myself in the comfort of a UK hospital I want to raise awareness that there are 39 million blind people in the world, but 80 per cent of blindness could be prevented or cured.

That’s 31.2 million people who are blind when it could have been avoided. Sightsavers want to eliminate avoidable blindness and support people who are irreversibly blind or disabled to live independently.

And the red hair dye? A Secret Santa present that might help people "see" things differently!

Martin

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder but what if the beholder didn't have sight!?

Without eyesight I can only imagine how someone would feel... Angry, Devastated, Afraid, Frustrated, Isolated, Alone, Different, Lost, Confused.... These are just a few of the many emotions blind people and their parents feel when their child is diagnosed with a lifelong eye condition.

The beauty of this world is felt by the heart but seen by eyes. I believe no-one should be denied this independence, this basic human sense or jewel of the body, if something can be done to rectify it.

“There are only two ways to live your life. One is as though nothing is a miracle. The other is as though everything is a miracle” and I believe that every dream can come true with hard work and determination. My name is Sehrish Zafar and I am an entertainment journalist and a TV Presenter. I understand it is not easy to encourage people to think optimistically, so that's where my charismatic personality and charm can help inspire people to make a difference in the society.

I am currently a freelance TV Presenter for various UK asian channels; I host at many stage events: fashion, charity, political and award ceremonies especially within our community. I am a graduate of BA Business Management and an award holder of 'Miss Perfect' at college.

Other achievements include fundraising for charities like Save the Children, Ucare Foundation; working as an Events Director of Pakistan Youth Foundation - Organised dinner events for Pakistani politicians, protests against Burma and Gaza Killings, promoted local community cultural music events, visited House of Commons and Pakistan High Commission on many occasions to support our community.

As I have selflessly helped support the dreams of others and those of my community, I hope I will continue to receive the help and support I seek to fundraise for those in need the most. I am fasting in aid of Sightsavers and your generous support in this great cause will aid me to do more for the ones who need the help most. 

 

Sightsavers believes that no one should be blind from avoidable causes, and that people’s whose sight can’t be saved should live with dignity and independence.

 

Did you know?

There are 39 million blind people in the world

80% of blindness can be prevented or cured

Around 90% of visually impaired people live in the world’s poorest countries

So the problems Sightsavers are trying to tackle are pretty enormous.

 

So please dig deep and donate now.

 

Thank you,

Sehrish

 

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity and make sure Gift Aid is reclaimed on every eligible donation by a UK taxpayer. So it’s the most efficient way to donate - I raise more, whilst saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Sightsavers is 1 of my 2 chosen charities - it is an charity that works in developing countries to prevent blindness and restore sight by treating eye conditions such as cataracts, trachoma, refractive error and eye conditions caused by tropical diseases.  Your donation really can make a difference;

  • £4 could pay for a cataract operation to save a child going blind
  • £8 could pay for trachoma operations to stop 12 people going blind.
  • £12 could pay for treatment to prevent 2,184 people losing their sight to river blindness.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Hiii,

Those who know me already know my story for those who don't here it is....

I was diagnosed with right homonymous hemianopia. This is a visual field loss on the same side of both eyes. In my case it was caused by a stroke.

Although my sight cannot be regained there are people in 3rd world countries who are struggling with sight loss daily due to dirty water and surroundings.

We can actually help them!. 

All I ask is for people to donate as little as £2 to help save someone's sight.  

£12 - could protect 35 families from river blindness a year!

 £28 - Could pay for a  cataract operation and give someone their sight back! 

£140 - Could treat and protect an entire village from trachoma! 

Just a few examples of what your money could be doing.

Sightsavers Currently works in the following counties:

Bangladesh, Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Chad, Côte d’Ivoire, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ethiopia, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, India, Kenya, Liberia, Malawi, Mali, Mozambique, Nigeria, Pakistan, Republic of Congo, Senegal, Sierra Leone, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania, The Gambia, Togo, Uganda, Yemen, Zambia and Zimbabwe


Thank you in advance for anyone that donates it means more than words can express.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

80 per cent of all blindness could be prevented or cured. It is a staggering statistic: that’s over 31 million people, most of whom live in the poorest countries in the world. And with poverty being both a cause and effect of blindness, a cycle is created that can be hard for communities to break out of.

Sightsavers wants to eliminate avoidable blindness and get equality for people with disabilities. They help blind people to see, prevent others from going blind unnecessarily, and support people to live independently if their sight loss can’t be undone.

The causes of avoidable blindness go further than eye disease, so Sightsavers doesn’t just slap a sticking-plaster on the problem – they campaign to make a fairer world and change lives for the long term, helping to eliminate avoidable blindness and get equality for people with disabilities. Help us to support Sightsavers in this incredible cause.

eventName: Our Aotearoa Adventure: a long bike ride on the other side of the world.
story:
Earlier this year I had emergency eye surgery for a detached retina.  Thanks to the swift response and expertise of the eye unit where I was treated I have regained the sight in my right eye.  I'm still having problems with cataracts in my left eye but I know this will be sorted in due course with a relatively quick and easy operation.  The experience of temporary sight loss  made me appreciate how lucky I am to live in a country where we have access to free health care via the NHS.  Thousands of people in developing countries don't have this privilege and as a result cataracts or a detached retina can lead to permanent blindness resulting in a loss of independence, income and an inability to care for their families.  In the case of children these conditions can have a devastating impact on their future.  These and other eye conditions are easily preventable and treatable with access to funding and the expertise that we take for granted in the UK.  By donating to Sightsavers  you are helping the charity to work in some of the world's poorest areas to prevent and treat eye conditions that would otherwise lead to permanent blindness.

All donations will go to the charity.  We are totally self funding the trip.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

charity.name: Sightsavers
story:
On 1st June 2018 I will be setting off with my daughter, Olivia, to cycle from home, near Bristol, to Land's End and back - a distance of around 475 miles over 8 days. I am 61, Olivia is 22. 

In September last year I suffered a torn retina, which was repaired by wonderful staff at Bristol Eye Hospital. It gave me an insight into the devastating effect loss of vision can have on ones life. 

In January last year, whilst visiting a village on the Mekong River in Laos, I saw a young boy who had a vision defect that resulted in him being excluded by his fellow peers and destined to a life of poverty.  A simple operation would remedy that defect and allow him to lead a full and active life as he grows up in his village. 

Sight Savers delivers that treatment to those like him and thousands of others.
