eventName: 2018 Bank of Scotland Great Scottish Run 10K
story:
Hi there,

I'm Ila Patricia and I will be running the half marathon event in the Great Scottish Run on the 30th of September - my second one.

I was inspired by Anne Curtis-Smith's dedication and journey towards her London Marathon as she did it for UNICEF to raise funds for the children affected in the war in Marawi City and has helped so much for these war-affected children.

I believe that a difference can be made to help these vulnerable children in dangerous and difficult situations around the world. Homes being destroyed by wars, natural disasters and leaving them with nothing, facing diseases and hunger, just to name a few. For every child deserves a bright future - an education, a childhood, a home etc. 

For 70 years, UNICEF continues to help these children in need by providing them protection from violence and exploitation, food, clean water, medical care, vaccinations and education. 

I always dedicate my running events for a charitable cause as it is an opportunity for me to be a part of something bigger, to help those in need. 

I'm setting my target high for this fundraiser and I hope you will support me in reaching that GBP 590 target, as it could help 160 children continue their education with Unicef's school in a box.

Every pound donated will make a difference, no matter how big or small your donation is:

  • 60 GBP could help 2 families collect and store clean water with an emergency water and hygiene kit
  • 125 GBP could provide blankets for 25 babies
  • 260 GBP could protect 2000 children from polio by providing lifesaving vaccinations
  • 590 GBP could help 160 children continue their education with Unicef's school in a box
  • 1,100 GBP could supply a tent for a temporary school or health centre

My training for the half marathon event will start next week, doing this for UNICEF will keep me fired up and inspired as I push through every kilometre I run.

Thank you for taking your time to visit my page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: Fasting from water for Unicef UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

More than 800 children die every year because they don't have access to safe water and clean toilets. A staggering 16,000 children under the age of five die from diseases that are easy to prevent.

UNICEF provides vaccines to immunise almost half the world's children against preventable diseases. They also have water, sanitation and hygiene teams working in more than 100 countries, keeping children safe by providing better water supplies and sanitation facilities in schools and communities. However, there is still so much more that can be done to help, which is why we at Surrey UNICEF on Campus have decided to focus on this issue for the upcoming semester.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Those of you who know me, will know that I am not the most athletic person. I am not the fastest runner or the most technically proficient runner. I am, however, a determined runner. 

In 2016 I was lucky enough to run my first Half Marathon; The Great North Run for the British Heart Foundation. This was in memory of my beloved uncle (Gert Marynissen), who will always and forever remain the driving force of all my running. 

I was astonished at the kindness and support received a year ago; not only from close friends and family, but also from people who reached out as a gesture of common humanity. That is why I am proud to be running for Unicef UK this time. 

According to Unicef, one in nine children are being raised in war zones. The struggle of placing one foot in front of the other for 13.1 miles is nothing compared to living under these conditions. Therefore, I can only help in the small way that I can and I invite you all to help me in this endeavour. Even the smallest donation contributes to a great and necessary cause. 

If you would like to find out more about the life-changing work that Unicef carries out, please follow this link: https://www.unicef.org.uk. 

In the meantime, thank you for visiting my JustGiving page. Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

As most of you know I have always said no matter what I have been through there is always someone worse off than me.  Well hears  my chance to try and do my bit  for some of the most vulnerable people of the world. CHILDREN most of whom without the intervention and contributions of us that are fortunate would starve to death or die of desies. I am Truely Blessed not only because I live in a country where we have clean running water and help when needed to provide food for our family's but also where we have got a health care system that enables us to get medications to prevent or treat or suppress desies. Could you imagine living without these life line's on a daily basis? Could you imagine your children , grandchildren,  nieces or nephews waking up every day with no one to care for them starving and having slow painful deaths? Neither could I. Please Please help us raise as much money as possible to get the much deserved help these poor defenceless children so Desperatly Need. 

Me and Daniel are going to be doing our fast on my birthday 15th June so there will be no cake or chocolates for me but if it means our friends and family's will get behind us and help us raise as much finds as possible then it's a tiny price to pay. 

Please help us to make a difference lets show we do care not just for yourself and family and friends but about humans in general. Too many humans are killing each other let's start Saving each other instead.

Weather you believe in God or not I'd like to Pray

Dear God please help us to help those far less fortunate than ourselves . Help us to make a difference to someone else's life. Make my fast be hard make our bellys rumble with hunger because even then that will not even come close to how these starving children feel. Make us Truely Thankfull for all our Many Blessings Amen xx

story:
Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. 

Today, children in places like Syria, South Sudan and Yemen are caught up in violent conflict, with millions forced to flee their homes. In 2015, Unicef responded to 310 emergencies in 102 countries. Please donate what ever you can to my fundraiser for Unicef UK. With your help, we can build a safer world for children.

I will be fasting for 24 hours (I'm gonna struggle as I love my food) but it's something I really wanted to do. 

So many children all over the world go 24 hours or longer without food and this deeply sadens me.

Please give what you can much appreciated 

Louise xxx

story:
On the 11th of May; Ben Mckenzie, Beth Gibbs, Matt Yeung, Lydia Cline, Alistair Dalton and Thrinayani Ramakrishnan will be fasting for 24 hours to help keep children safe from hunger.

Through FAST 24, we are going without food to raise money for a vital nutrition programme in Liberia, West Africa, where almost a third of children suffer from chronic malnutrition.

We want to help every child get the nutrition they need to grow up healthy and strong, we would be very thankful if you could support us.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
"CHRISTMAS IS CANCELLED" I never imagined that a day would come when we'd read this headline but if you Google Sierra Leone today (Friday, 12 December 2014) that is exactly what you'd see.

Unlike the many dodgy characters who tried to ruin Christmas in the books and movies we read and watched as children, this evil monster is incapable of repenting. It is cruel, relentless and merciless, not distinguishing male, female, suckling babe or a gentle and wise elderly soul. This monster does not adhere to any rules of engagement as far is it is concerned all humanity is prey. It actively seeks out any holes in our battle strategy and takes full advantage off them.   However we have a few master weapons on our side -
1. Hope that stands against hope itself. For me that's my Lord Jesus Christ, He always makes a way where there seems to be no way.    
2. Love    
3. Brave and courageous volunteers on the front-line.    
4. You and me.    
My husband is from Sierra Leone and we have family that we have not seen in over ten years living 10 minutes away from one of the hospitals treating patients in Freetown. It is easy to feel a sense of dread and helplessness but we are not helpless. We can do something and together we can make a real difference in the lives of some children in Sierra Leone.  
 
According to the UNICEF website "£30 could buy and deliver a hygiene kit to keep children safe from infection." Please help us to raise £600 this will help protect 20 children.
    
To get us started on this target, hubby Michael, the kids and I are all giving up Christmas presents this year.
We will not be impulse buying in the Boxing day sales.
We are getting stuck into some fun sponsored activities and will donate everything we raise to UNICEF. We will keep you posted on how we are getting on.
We can not thank you enough for every penny you donate. May the Lord richly bless you.  

Thank you, Daphne.

P.S. Ebola we know your name, we know what you look like and the nasty stuff that you are made of. You may know human anatomy but you know nothing about our spirit or our maker. We have a Father and in the name of Jesus Christ we stand against you. #havingdoneallstand.
title: Kamandas' UNICEF - Make a stand against Ebola in Sierra Leone

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Award winning composers Daniel and Laura Curtis have launched their charity initiative for 2015, Sing 4 Change. The project aims to raise money and awareness for the crucial work that UNICEF undertakes. The composers have written the song  'Everyone Can Help Someone' and will be seeking vocal and instrumental contributions from across the World. 

Daniel and Laura will be sharing the experiences and challenges of putting together a song with a unique set of limits, starting from scratch with only a small band who have recorded a basic backing track and following strict rules that no singers can be paid.

Daniel and Laura Curtis are hoping create a piece of work that will send out a positive message about trying to make a change in the world, whilst bringing together artists for an exciting collaboration that will see an array of talents, both established and new encourage others to think about how they can support UNICEF in their work.

At several points throughout the process there will be open calls for the public perform sections of song to share and raise awareness in the online community of UNICEF's important work. Many of these performances will included in the finished piece.

When the song is complete it will be available to download for a voluntary donation via the project's JustGiving page which will be open for donations throughout the process. Dan, Laura and their team will put out a blog with updates on the songs progress and with details on the musical material needed for the open submissions.


ABOUT DANIEL AND LAURA CURTIS

Daniel and Laura Curtis in 2014 supported the BBC Children in Need appeal with their album 'Love On 42nd Street' which featured stars of Broadway and the West End including, Ramin Karimloo, Samantha Barks, Lea Salonga, Sierra Boggess, Simon Bowman and John Owen-Jones. The album reached number one on the Amazon Broadway and iTunes Vocal charts in the UK and US. 

In 2013 the composers supported 'The National Coal Mining Memorial of Wales' with their acclaimed A Miners Song which featured over three hundred people including three choirs, 150 school children and a brass band. The song has vocal contributions from Hollywood actors, Jonathan Pryce, Michael Sheen, Matthew Rhys, Sian Phillips, Ioan Gruffudd. Other contributions include winber of Britain's Got Talent Paul Potts, World Champion boxer Joe Calzaghe, the voice of the late Richard Burton and World renowned bass player Pino Palladino.

story:
Hello! 

We are staging a concert: 

  • SATURDAY 15th NOVEMBER 2014 
  • St Anne Church, 363 Kennington Lane, Vauxhall, London, SE11 5QY
  • 19:45 - 21:00
  • Tickets are £10 - all to charity (no monies to us)

It will be an evening of wonderful musical shenanigans. Tunes you know, and some you won't - some Strauss, Handel, Britten, Field, Lloyd Webber and more.. 

We really hope you can come. 

Please donate to buy your tickets - pls let us know how many you'd like in your message, so we can welcome you on the night. Or feel free to donate even if you can't attend.

'We' are Jocelyn Somerville - an award winning and fabulous soprano - http://jocelynsomerville.com/ 

and Philippa Clare - a former music scholar, now keen amateur 


We did this back in 2011 and raised just over £2000 for Help for Heroes and DEC:Somalia - so we (kindof) know what we're doing. This time we are fundraising for Unicef and Teens Unite Against Cancer.

Thank you in advance for your generosity, we really hope to see you on the 15th November.

J&P

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Over the course of 2014 and 15 I am taking part in various events, in order to walk, jog and cycle to raise money for UNICEF.

I am to complete the following events:

- Tough Mudder, 15th June 2014 (stopped 1 mile from the finish due to injury)

- Cycle Millport Coast, Millport, August 2014

- Great Scottish Half Marathon, Glasgow, 5th October 2014

- Tough Mudder, 20th June 2015

 

UNICEF dedicates itself to helping children in need, from all over the world, with both a long-term goal, and by responding to disasters and providing aid in the short-term.

In today's day and age - one where the Western World can sync their television to their computer and internet, in the comfort of their bedroom - the fact that many children live in such poor conditions just isn't acceptable. UNICEF aims to provide care and assistance to such communities, to ensure that all children have the best possible chance at life.

Every child should be born into a world where they have their basic human rights, and needs, met. They deserve the right to be a child - to be heard; to have an education and open doors; to be treated fairly; and to be healthy.

story:
Amongst the many interiors blogs I follow on Instagram, there's also a large handful of foodies I'm checking out daily for a inspiration and ideas!  I love cooking up feasts for friends and family, trying out new recipes and sharing good food. 

By chance, I came across #CookforSyria and wanted to get involved!......... A charity campaign, where I can host a delicious dinner party and brunch whilst asking guests for a small donation to my Just Giving page,  that will help children in Syria this winter and beyond.

We've all been devastated and shocked by the news we hear everyday from Syria, our 'news' is such a small and carefully edited snippet of what's actually happening that we really only hear and see the tip of the ice berg. I took this from the UNICEF page:

"Right now, more than 8 million Syrian children are in danger. Many have lost their homes, schools and even their families. They face unspeakable violence and a lack of food, health care and clean water.
Now Syria’s children face another threat – the deadly cold winter"

http://cookforsyria.com/

This event will be invite only and on a first come, first serve basis due to it being in my house. If more interest is expressed, once I've released the menu, I will host a maximum of 30 guests in a private venue tbc.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Kate x

story:
Hello and thanks for visiting! My name's Cressida and I'm a student midwife based in Manchester.  I've started this JustGiving page as a booster to fund-raise for my chosen charity, UNICEF. As well as hosting a CookForSyria dinner party in Autumn, I'm organising weekly bake sales to complement this. To read more about how the funds are used or how you can help, please visit UNICEF's official page.

"We hope that through the #CookForSYRIA campaign we will not only be able to raise much needed money for Unicef’s Children of Syria Fund, we will also increase awareness of the plight of children in the war-torn country. Through cooking, sharing recipes and the power of social media, we invite everyone to help make a difference and positive contribution towards this important initiative" - Clerkenwell Boy

Winning Observer Food Monthly’s Best Ethical Food Project 2017, #CookForSyria is a nationwide fundraising initiative curated by Clerkenwell Boy SUITCASE Magazine and Gemma Bell, in partnership with Unicef NEXT Generation London, and in aid of Unicef UK. Recently inspired by this initiative, UNICEF NEXT Generation London, Lilly Vanilli, Clerkenwell Boy, Serena Guen and Gemma Bell also created #BakeForSyria.

You can buy the cookbooks here :

https://www.amazon.co.uk/Bake-Syria-Recipe-Book/dp/1527221962

https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/aw/d/1527203344/ref=pd_aw_fbt_14_img_2/257-1533745-6992906?ie=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=S16PMS8F96EZ3JF48EV8

story:
One morning in late January while I was driving to work, the Today programme ran a feature on the "Rohingya Crisis".

The scale of the devastation and utter depravity being inflicted on the Rohingya is almost beyond comprehension and the accounts contained within this feature left an impression on me.﻿

As a result, rather than receive any gifts or go out somewhere to celebrate my 40th, I would instead like to use my birthday as an opportunity to raise a little bit of money to alleviate some of the unimaginable suffering that has been endured by those Rohingya children who have managed to make it to Bangladesh.  

﻿I would appreciate any sum that you chose to donate. Thank you.

Bow

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I've set myself a challenge to workout everyday for 31 consecutive days. I will be posting a picture on social media platform Instagram everyday at 8pm UK time (9pm South African time). For every 100 likes my daily workout picture gets, I will be donating 5 British pounds to UNICEF UK.*

Instagram: gregbriton

I aim to spread awareness about the work UNICEF
does as well as promote the benefits regular exercise can have for your physical and mental health.

I chose UNICEF as I believe every child deserves a chance at life. When one says 'I believe every child deserves a chance', it sounds obvious that that is true. But yet millions of children are in dire need of help in developing nations and yet a lot of us do nothing to help them. If you are one of these people, you need to know that it's not because you are a bad person. It's simply due to a lack of exposure to those in need of our help. If you were face to face with a child who needed a life-saving vaccination and you knew a small donation would be able to pay for it, you would pay for it without a flinch. This is essentially what you are doing by donating. UNICEF is an incredible non-profit organisation. Every small donation counts. So please donate.


*I will have a personal donation cap of 300 British pounds (R5120). This is simply a precautionary measure as I am living off the minimum wage in the UK.

charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: Giving up chocolate for a year
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We live in a dangerous world. Every day children face violence, disease and hunger. They are battered by the chaos of war and disaster and forced to flee their homes. They are denied an education.

Yet with your support Unicef have saved millions of children’s lives. Unicef ensures more of the world’s children are vaccinated, educated and protected than any other organisation. They have done more to influence laws and policies to help protect children than anyone else.

For 70 years they have been there for children in danger. Unicef was created in 1946 to help protect children after World War 2 and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child is the basis of all of our work. Today UNICEF are still helping children in some of the world’s most dangerous places. 

Right now, children in places like Syria, South Sudan and Yemen are caught up in violent conflict. They are fleeing war and disaster in greater numbers than at any time since World War 2.And in countries such as Nepal and the Philippines, children have seen their communities destroyed by natural disasters like earthquakes, typhoons and flooding.In a humanitarian emergency, Unicef responds rapidly and we stay as long as we’re needed.In the chaos of war and disaster Unicef provide life-saving food, clean water and medical care, as well as education and protection from violence and exploitation.

Today, thousands of children will die from diseases that are easy to prevent. Thousands more will die because they don’t have the food they need to live and grow. And yet more will experience unspeakable violence.Millions of children are in danger, every day.Unicef keeps children safe by providing vaccines against deadly diseases, distributing mosquito nets and by promoting safe hygiene in communities around the world. Unicef is the world’s largest supplier of emergency life-saving food for children. And they campaign tirelessly to end violence against children.

Any donations would be warmly appreciated.

Many Thanks,

Team SSF

twitter.com/LilMaximoff

Instagram.com/SebbStanFacts

story:
The idea of this page is to enable you to donate excess credit from your PAYG mobile phone account to an excellent cause. You can do this by texting CPAM47 £n to 70070, where n is 1,2,3,4,5, or 10. So to donate £10, you'd text CPAM47 £10 to 70070.

You'll receive an acknowledgement text which includes a link so that taxpayers can Gift Aid their donation. You'll also be offered a choice between anonymity and having your contact details passed on. Please choose anonymity - I don't want to know who is donating, I just want you to donate to my chosen cause!

100% of text donations and of any Gift Aid goes to the charity. It isn't restricted to PAYG; for Pay Monthly, the donation is added to your next invoice. It is open to users of all UK mobile networks, and the admin is done by JustTextGiving. 

You can also donate by card using the blue 'Donate' link on this page if you prefer, and a small service fee is deducted from your donation.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Right now, children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger
and the chaos of war and disaster. This is wrong and it has to change.
Unicef ensures more of the world’s children are vaccinated, educated and protected than any other organisation. They have done more to influence laws, policies and customs to help protectchildren than anyone else. By sponsoring my cycle, as well as emotionally supporting me through it (which is not a particularly good deed), you are supporting Unicef (which absolutely is a good deed) and you can protect a child in danger, transform their life and ultimately build a safer world for tomorrow’s children.

As an example, any donation that you are kind enough to make may be used to provide:

  • £5 = enough vaccinations to protect 41 vulnerable children from polio
  • £10 = exercise books, pens, pencils, textbooks and other school things to support the education of a child for a whole year.
  • £136 = a school-in-a-box containing school equipment for 40 children to continue with their education during an emergency or natural disaster.
  • £257 = water pump to provide clean, safe water to a school or a whole village or community.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
As part of a team of 14 amazing people who work for the Autovista Group as our employer, we have all been given a once in a life time challenge in September to climb Ben Nevis in Scotland, Scafell Pike in England, and Snowdon in Wales.... that's just the warm up & dry run ;).

In December we climb Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania ascending to 5800 meters over the 7 days of the challenge all to support UNICEF. Reaching my fundraising goal of £1750 will ensure that a 4WD support vehicle can be bought that allows health workers to provide vaccination programmes and medical care to children in remote communities.

Help me help Autovista Group and our charity UNICEF by making a small donation towards my goal of climbing the 3 peaks in the UK and Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania.

"Every pound you raise will make a difference to vulnerable children around the world:

  • £60 could help two families collect and store clean water with an emergency water and hygiene kit.
  • £125 could provide blankets for 25 babies.
  • £260 could protect 2,000 children from polio by providing lifesaving vaccinations.
  • £590 could help 160 children continue their education with Unicef’s school in a box.
  • £1,100 could supply a tent for a temporary school or health center."

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Ok, I know what you're thinking : "Argh !!! ANOTHER fundraising page, for ANOTHER idiot embarking on ANOTHER stupid challenge that really is only going to give this idiot reasons to post "healthy me" pictures and stories and raise her Instagram profile"

So, firstly, only takes a glance at my Instagram content to understand that "healthy" posts aren't really my thing. If the Portman group had a say in the livelihood of Instagram accounts, my profile would be shut down faster that you can say "dirty martini"

Secondly, there is a reason why these fundraising pages keep popping up on our news feeds, and I'd like to think that the reason is not solely to help idiots like me entering genuinely life threatening challenges, but that in the light of recent social, economic and environmental disasters we all feel a little more responsible for each other, a little less selfish and a little more conscious of our duty as...well, simply...humans.

There is no better charity, there are no hierarchy or inequality in kindness and generosity, all causes are worth fighting for. But, those who know me, know that the refugees and immigration conundrum has always been very close to my heart. I believe, this is the one common trait to all humans, wherever we are from or live we really all come from somewhere else. 1st, 2nd, 3rd generation, we are all migrants in one way or another, and it's likely we will be migrants again. It is therefore our duty to care for this issue that, really, is almost as old as the world itself.

This is why I am extremely proud to take on the challenge of finishing the London marathon to raise money for Unicef. Unicef is doing an amazing job in fighting on all fronts for children all over the world, and one program that has (sadly) taken a lot of their resources in the past  few years is the issue of unaccompanied children in Europe. There are more child refugees in Europe than at any point since the end of the second world war. As children flee from war and disaster, borders across Europe are closing and making their journeys even more dangerous and difficult. Unicef has established support hubs across Europe to provide help to refugee children and families. Your donation will help save children from diseases or starvation and will help reuniting families.

So all this blabbering really to say one thing : DONATE PLEASE, there are NO small donation. And if my monologue didn't really move you (I mean, first I can show you the way to the nearest heart store because CLEARLY YOU WERE BORN WITHOUT A HEART  *dramatically exits and slams the door*).... PLEASE donate for the sole purpose of buying yourself the right to comment on the too many drinks I will surely be having way to close to race day....because "self control" is my middle name and I like to make a challenge even more of a challenge :)

That's it y'all ! Loveyou - bisous - merci- bye

Thanks for taking the time to visit my page. I’m aiming to complete the Ride100 this summer, and to make it a challenge I’m targeting a sub 5hr time (there are some hills!). But I need your support to do it, so if you can, please donate and support a great charity. More details on Unicef and their work below...

Unicef is the world's leading children's organisation, working in more than 190 countries. Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk

UNICEF receive no funding from the United Nations budget and rely entirely on voluntary donations from supporters like you.

On behalf of everyone at UNICEF and all those who will benefit from your gift, thank you.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. 

Every day I feel incredibly fortunate to be in a place where I can offer my child everything he needs for him to be healthy, safe and happy. There are so many people who are not so lucky, who have to try and raise their family in a war zone, who are trapped in a cycle of poverty or lose everything in an environmental disaster. 

I've decided to run a half marathon for Unicef because every child in the world deserves to have access to food and clean water, to be protected from diseases as well as violence and have a right to be educated. 

I'd so appreciate anything you could spare to help raise money for Unicef to support vulnerable children all over the world. 

Thanks so much. Julia x

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. 

Kantar is a proud supporter of UNICEF globally, and as a Kantar employee and UK Country Manager, I'm joining the challenge to run a half marathon to raise funds the amazing work UNICEF does with the many disadvantaged, and underprivileged children around the world - and also perhaps improve my own well being in the process!  

Alongside a few thousand others, I'll also be running with several of my Kantar UK and global colleagues, and for me personally, this will be the furthest distance I have ever run. I'm no stranger to the 5k or 10k, but 21k is something quite different. I hope you'll be able to support me and help raise some money for this very worthy cause, and help spur me on through the training and then of course the run itself! Thanks so much in advance for all you give, I really appreciate it!

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Hi Everyone,

So…my biggest challenge to date has finally arrived! My application to run in the 2019 Virgin Money London Marathon has been accepted.
This means that (somehow) on the 28th April 2019, I will be running the 26-mile marathon (…nearly twice the length of Malta!?) for my charity sponsor, UNICEF.

Why UNICEF?

Every day, young children face violence, disease and hunger.
They are battered by the chaos of war and natural disaster and forced to flee their homes.

UNICEF ensures more of the world’s children are vaccinated, educated and protected than any other organisation.

Today, thousands of children will die from diseases that are
easy to prevent. Thousands more will die because they don’t have the food they need to live and grow. And yet more will experience unspeakable violence.

UNICEF keeps children safe by providing vaccines against deadly diseases and by promoting safe hygiene in communities around the world. They are the world’s largest supplier of emergency life-saving food for children, and campaign tirelessly to end violence against children.

I have been fortunate enough to lead a healthy life, been provided with a good education and live in a safe environment, unlike many other children who are forced to live in the chaos of war and poverty. For all
these reasons, this is why I will be running for team UNICEF. 

I will be able to help them continue their vital work for children around the world. My £2,000 in sponsorship could protect over 16,000
children from the crippling effects of polio.

Another reason why I’ve chosen UNICEF is because my late grandfather worked closely with humanitarian services and aided in various charitable work, and I promised myself I would follow in his footsteps.

By helping UNICEF just a little, they can keep providing essential global humanitarian work that in today’s world is increasingly important – so hopefully this is a good start!

I appreciate all donations received, my aim is to raise a minimum of £2,000 by April 2019, 50% of which must be raised before end of
2018.

Thank you so much for taking the time to read and, at the same time; aiding to raise awareness and understanding.

Stan

I will now be doing the Royal Parks Half Marathon in October for UNICEF UK.

There are many children's charities, who do remarkable things for the kids they serve. For me, UNICEF and [UNICEF UK] are in a unique position of comparative advantage that allows them to achieve important objectives around the world. I'm not going to attempt to inform you of this work as UNICEF UK can speak for themselves more eloquently than I ever could. Check out www.unicef.org.uk  Watch some of the UNICEF UK's videos etc.

It is apparent that the range, scope and scale of the work carried out by UNICEF is magnificent. From immunisation programs to war work, UNICEF have a deep understanding of the needs of children in danger. This is unmatched in my view by any other.

If you can, please support UNICEF UK in my name.

Many Thanks

Jimmi James

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I’m running in the Edinburgh Marathon Festival 5K . For those that don’t know it’s up and around Arthur’s Seat the Volcano overlooking Edinburgh. So it’ll be quite a hard run.

Then I’m taking part in the Great North 10k in Gateshead starting at Gateshead stadium then running down to the quayside then Passing under the iconic Tyne Bridge and heading along to the Sage Gateshead and BALTIC before bending back along the Quayside for a triumphant lap of the Gateshead International Stadium track, cheered on by your family and friends.

The latest addition to the 10k course is the now infamous ’Slog on the Tyne’ section, a steady uphill climb that will really put your training to the test.

Finally I’ll be running the River Ness 5K which is a flat course, so I’m hoping for a personal best here.

I’ve paid to enter these events myself so every penny will go to UNICEF to help children in desperate situations all around the world. 

The races take place 25 May, 8 July and 23 September respectively. 

Please give what you can, every pound really does count.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
UNICEF (the United Nations International Children's Fund) operates in over 190 countries to save children’s lives, defend their rights, and strive to improve policies and services that protect all children. UNICEF’s aim is to make the world a safer place for children, operating through a series of initiatives including child protection, child survival, education, emergency situations, and gender equality. UNICEF on Campus – SOAS, University of London, is a student-initiated branch supporting UNICEF’s work. We aim to utilize student resources and capabilities through events to fundraise and raise awareness about UNICEF’s cause in providing emergency and long-term aid and resources to vulnerable children across the world.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

For the first time in my life I am actually taking part in a physical challenge to raise money for a good cause. My work has chosen UNICEF as our charity and for October we are doing a pedometer challenge. My team's goal is to walk the equivilant of London to Timbucto and I have a personal goal to get off my arse and cover 8000 steps a day for the month (more if I can), tracked via my new Fit Bit pedometer (best buy ever). I have been doing this for a week now and already surprising myself. 

Your support will spur me on to do my best for myself and my team 'The walking dead'... we went for the humorous touch. I thought I would be the walking dead after the first week but still going strong. This has been a massive incentive and I am now even bypassing the lift to the 5th floor office and using the stairs as much as I can.

If you can spare a little donation and help me raise some money for our charity and cheer me on for my fitness goal that would be fab.

Tracy xx

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I recently had the opportunity to work with Unicef and visit their child protection program in Malawi.   I was able to see first hand the amazing work they are doing to improve the lives of children as well as hear testimonials from individuals participating in their programs.  

Despite severe poverty and extremely limited resources, the workers and families there remain committed to improving the lives of their young people.  I was, and still am, amazed by the resilience and joy of the people I met there. 

Unicef does a wonderful job of working with the government to design and support a myriad of community programs while also exploring ways of leveraging technology and analytics to continually innovate and design better services for this vulnerable population.

The high degree of dedication, professionalism and warmth I experienced from both members of Unicef and the people of Malawi has inspired me to continue to support them in any way I can.  Please consider donating to my fundraiser to help bring a brighter future to all the children Unicef supports. 

With my sincere thanks,

Lea

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I am raising money for programmes in Bangladesh, Bolivia, Malawi and Mauritania where Kantar’s partnership with Unicef supports more than 80,000 children to help protect them from violence, exploitation, disease and abuse

  • In Bangladesh, we will help to provide shelter and support to 4,500 children living in hazardous conditions, to enable them to go to school instead of work
  • Poverty and HIV drive vulnerability in children in Malawi; your support will help ensure 3,500 children have access to psychosocial support through Children’s Corners community centres
  • In Bolivia, violence against children and adolescents is phenomenal so your support will help protect children against exploitation by improving their legislative rights and creating special support units for victims
  • In Mauritania, your support will go towards a vaccination programme to end preventable childhood deaths from pneumonia and diarrhoea

I'm a passionate advocate of Unicef's work and I have seen first-hand the huge difference we have made in Malawi. I'm doing this challenge as it takes me out of my comfort zone in every which way, but I'm determined to do it to continue helping those children who are still in danger and need ongoing support. Thank you for your kind donation.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Walks for Ollie (and others!)

This year I want to do my own little bit to raise some money for charities that are close to me for a variety of reasons.

I will be walking the distance between where I live (Thame) and where my nephew Ollie lived (Lee On Solent) This is a total of 120km or nearly 3 marathons! I won’t be doing this in one go though as my ankles and feet aren’t made for this distance in one go, so I’ll be walking bite sized distances- tracking my gym and long-distance walking sessions! During my ‘training’ sessions in March /April I completed 44km- so by the time I reach ‘Lee on Solent ‘ distance I will have actually done over 160km!

The reasons for my chosen charities are:

Unicef- As my friends and family know, last November my beautiful,  brave and courageous nephew,  Ollie,  died doing something he believed in.  He died whilst trying to help families get back to some form of normality in Syria. For this reason I want to support Unicef for the work they do to help children in Syria. Since war started in Syria over 1,000 children have been killed and over 2.6m displaced. Unicef works tirelessly to protect Syrian children and give them hope for the future, ensuring they get access to life-saving supplies and longer term support.

Cancer Research UK- need I say more- I have friends and family who have, or are, currently fighting various types of cancer. Whatever you donate will help CRUK to achieve their vision to bring forward the day when all cancers are cured.

Please donate whatever you can, and I will keep you all updated on my progress!

Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
On May 28th I will be lacing up to save lives and with your help we can make it happen. My record finishing time for a 10K is 56.38. I am aiming to better that and try and aim for a 49.59 finish. 

Every child has the right to an education – whatever their background, gender or ethnicity. Unicef wants to see a world where all children enjoy this right.

Yet every day, more than 61 million children don’t attend their primary schools. Without the opportunity to learn, children can’t develop to their full potential. They’re more likely to be trapped in cycles of poverty, poor health and forced labour – often in dangerous environments.

Unicef supports innovative programmes that give the most vulnerable children the chance to learn. We work with governments, communities and parents to enable every child to access a quality education.

Every year we help millions of children get an education – for example by providing textbooks and classroom kits, or by setting up child-friendly spaces where children can keep learning, even during a conflict or natural disaster.

story:
Welcome to my JustGiving page!

You may have seen on social media that I am taking part in an incredible challenge: Trekking Machu Picchu for UNICEF this October. It wasn't a light decision to make but there were only good reasons to do it! Supporting incredible causes, pushing boundaries, going beyond one's comfort zone, a unique personal achievement.

I am raising money for programmes in Bangladesh, Bolivia, Malawi and Mauritania where Kantar - through the Brighter Futures partnership with Unicef - supports more than 80,000 children to help protect them from violence, exploitation, disease and abuse.

- In Bangladesh, we will help to provide shelter and support to 4,500 children living in hazardous conditions, to enable them to go to school instead of work

- Poverty and HIV drive vulnerability in children in Malawi; your support will help ensure 3,500 children have access to psychosocial support through Children’s Corners community centres

- In Bolivia, violence against children and adolescents is phenomenal so your support will help protect children against exploitation by improving their legislative rights and creating special support units for victims

- In Mauritania, your support will go towards a vaccination programme to end preventable childhood deaths from pneumonia and diarrhoea

I am forever grateful for your kind donation!!

Many thanks
Delphinex

eventName: Team 16km Cycle Ride in Richmond Park London
story:
On the 18th of September, the Starwood UK&I Supply Chain team will embark on a 16km bike ride in Richmond Park in support of the UNICEF Road to Awareness campaign. This is our first time to get on our bike to raise money for UNICEF and we hope you will get behind us to support UNICEF. Our goal is to raise £750 for this great cause and would love to smash this figure.

﻿Since the beginning of 2015, all funds raised for UNICEF through Check Out for Children, Make a Green Choice and Road to Awareness are Supporting Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) projects across Africa and the Middle East, helping children and families receive access to safe drinking water and proper sanitation facilities.

Everyday, 1400 children die from disease caused by dirty water and poor sanitation. Yet, just $1 could help provide 9 children with safe drinking water for a month.

You can find further information on UNICEF's WASH strategy at www.unicef.org/wash and Starwood's partnership with UNICEF at www.checkoutforchildren.org

We hope you will be able to support us with a donation.

Thank You

Rose, Martin, Jas, Stephanie & Rama

Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Thanks for clicking!

I know.  I ride my bike all the time.  But I see this as a great opportunity to use a high profile event to raise money for a very worthy cause.

UNICEF (https://www.unicef.org.uk/) is a charity that provides humanitarian and developmental assistance to children and mothers in developing countries.  We live in a dangerous world.  Every day children face violence, disease and hunger.  They are battered by the chaos of war and disaster and forced to flee their homes.  They are denied an education.

UNICEF has saved millions of children’s lives - it ensures more of the world’s children are vaccinated, educated and protected than any other organisation.  It has done more to influence laws and policies to help protect children than anyone else.

Thinking about events of the past few years, it seems quite fitting to support a charity that is focused on supporting vulnerable children that might find themselves in dire situations through the actions of others.  If something as simple as me riding my bike helps their cause, then I'll ride kilometre after kilometre.  If you could join me on those kilometres, by making a donation - no matter how large or small - then I would be infinitely grateful.

And here's the standard print to reassure you that I won't use your donations for Bitcoin and that you won't be spammed by either JustGiving or UNICEF...  Donating is simple, fast and totally secure - the money goes directly to UNICEF.

charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: In memory of Latinos In London X Ecuador Ecuador Earthquake Appeal
story:
A huge earthquake has struck Ecuador, killing more than 250 people and injuring over 2,500. The magnitude 7.8 earthquake was felt by more than 15 million people across the region.

Homes and schools have been destroyed, and thousands of children are injured. Reports include children being pulled from the rubble of collapsed buildings. The Government of Ecuador has declared a national emergency and has requested assistance.

This is one of the strongest earthquakes to hit Ecuador in decades. We must respond to protect children in danger right now.

Your donations will help deliver health kits, clean water kits, life-saving food and tents. Unicef has already delivered 20,000 water purification tablets to Pedernales in north-west Ecuador, the area worst affected by the deadly earthquake.

Unicef needs more than £700,000 to meet the immediate needs of children affected by this devastating earthquake.

Please help Ecuador's children now.

Thank you!

Through FAST 24 UNICEF is asking participants to do without food for 24 hours to raise money for a vital food nutrition programme in Liberia, where almost a third of children suffer from chronic malnutrition.  Throughout the world a staggering 7,200 children die of malnutrition every 24 hours (UNICEF statistic).

Please donate if you can!  Thanks.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I’m delighted and terrified to say that I’ll be running the London Marathon next year for UNICEF. 

Almost a year ago today I woke up in Freetown to see the horrific mudslide from my window under a kilometre from where I was staying. I watched with absolute horror as the death count rose and the city was overcome with grief and panic in how to respond over the following days. It’s estimated that up to 1,000 people died of which over 200 were children. This tragedy was in a country that was still reeling from its response to the E-bola crisis.

UNICEF were rapid to react with post-disaster relief effectively and it’s an honour to be able to raise money for them which will help their ability to respond in future crisis events.

I’ll be doing all sorts of fun fundraising activities which will obviously involve me cooking food but if anyone can donate anything please do.

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Every 12 seconds, a child dies from causes linked to malnutrition. That’s a staggering 7,200 children in just 24 hours. Unicef is on the ground, delivering life-saving food to nurse children back to health. But we can’t do it without your help.
As part of FAST 24, I will go without food for 24 hours to raise money for a vital nutrition programme in Liberia, West Africa, where almost a third of children suffer from chronic malnutrition. Together we can help every child get the nutrition they need to grow up healthy and strong.
By raising £100 we could provide four malnourished children with a month’s supply of life-saving emergency food.
Please donate to my page so that Unicef can help as many children as possible! Thank you!
Every £1 you raise for the children of Liberia will be doubled by The Power of Nutrition, a charitable foundation.

If you're inspired and would like to take part in the FAST24 challenge, sign up on https://www.unicef.org.uk/fundraise/events/other-events/fast-24/

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
'One of the luckiest things that can happen to you in life is, I think, to have a happy childhood.' - Agathie Christie

Many of us have had a childhood that we can look back on fondly, but there are far too many children today who have been robbed of this basic happiness. At Surrey UNICEF on Campus, we have come together as students from around the world to give struggling children the childhoods they deserve. Our campaign for this semester is Clean Water and Vaccines, and our society will be participating in a 12 hour fast from water to fundraise for the cause.

More than 800 children die every year because they don't have access to safe water and clean toilets. A staggering 16,000 children under the age of five die from diseases that are easy to prevent. These numbers are far too great to ignore, and are simply worsened by the fact that they can easily be reduced with intervention from those in more fortunate circumstances. 

So let's all pitch in and raise money for this worthy cause - even the smallest donation can make a huge difference in a child's life! Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Nusaybah Shafi

Surrey UNICEF Fundraising Officer

story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

On the 28th May 2018 I will complete a 10k run for UNICEF, more specifically for the children that sadly do not receive the rights and freedoms that they should. No child deserves to grow up unhealthy and unsafe. I am running to help ensure the safety of these children, but also to encourage others to do the same. Every donation, as small as it may be counts towards helping these families and their children live the protected, vaccinated and educated life that they deserve.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
News for January 2018. Our fundraising efforts for this year are gratefully dedicated in appreciation of Dave Prowse M.B.E.

Dave has been a very kind and generous supporter of our cause and I am keen to acknowledge the difference he has made to UNICEF.

Frustratingly, poor health still limits how much I am able to do but UNICEF UK are always very appreciative our small contribution which, in turn, has only been possible thanks to the kindness of our patrons and supporters.

Read on to learn about my story.

Inspired by the work of Sir Roger Moore, one of my favourite actors, and sensitive to the needs of children I decided to become a fundraiser for this worthy cause.  The question was - how could I help? I am somewhat limited by precarious health so a fun run was not an option but the long days confined to bed had nurtured an affection for film and television.  So if you're going to do something stick to what you know.

Supported by my wife and children, we started by approaching some celebrity actor friends and asking that they sign photographs that could then be sold/auctioned to raise funds. This gradually progressed and we are now very proud to have the kind support of some special individuals as patrons of our group; much loved actors Dave Prowse M.B.E. and Kenneth Cope , writer/broadcaster Richard Hope-Hawkins and showbiz author Graham McCann.  The late Richard Briers C.B.E. was also a supportive patron and a dear friend.  His passing was a deep loss to our cause but also a personal sadness.

Most of our fundraising is via photographs which have been signed by stars of film and television which are then sold at special events and auctioned online. Past events include being part of a Star Wars themed weekend at Spaceport in Wallasey and a Craft & Memorabilia fair with Kenneth Cope working very hard to make the day a success.

This page was created at the suggestion of UNICEF UK to provide some background to our fundraising mission. I don't really do technology and our efforts tend to be offline but we can be contacted at signedphotosforunicef@yahoo.co.uk, should you wish.

Thanks, Glyn

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Last month I was invited to become the Honorary President of Leeds UNICEF, raising funds for Children who are desperately in need.  UNICEF is a really great organisation doing outstanding work worldwide and the Leeds group has been successfully fundraising for many years.  I am very proud to be part of their brilliant work.

Every year now since 2010, I have organised a fundraising charity cycle ride for different worthwhile causes and my friends and colleagues in Parliament are probably fed-up with my endless begging emails which they receive at this time of the year.  However, so many of you have been very generous and I know that your donations have been greatly appreciated by the organisations I have been privileged to help. Please don't give up now.

I will be setting off on Thursday 26th July from Walney Island in Barrow-in-Furness with the local MP, John Woodcock, and two of his friends.  We will cycle across the spine of England to the lovely Yorkshire seaside town of Whitby. Although the 150 mile distance is not as great as in previous years, the ride will be challenging owing to the often mountainous terrain through the Lake District and Pennines.  I hope you will be able to support me again this year – or start supporting my charity if you have not done so before.  John and his friends will be raising money separately for different charities.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
People have always told me that when you retire you need a plan for your retirement, well, I have a plan!! I am taking part in the only amateur Round the World Yacht Race. The race is 8 legs across every ocean and takes 11 months and 40k Nautical Miles.We will visit all continents on our journey, South America, Africa, Australasia, Oceania, Asia, North America and finally back to Europe,

This is a massive challenge both physically and mentally and the knowledge that I am fundraising along the way will act as a source of encouragement when things may not be going too smoothly.

UNICEF is the Official Race Charity and have a boat in the race, UNICEF advocates for the protection of children's rights, helps to meet their basic needs and to expand their opportunities to reach their full potential.

During stopovers along the way we will be participating in various activities to benefit the children of that area and hopefully leave them, and ourselves with many good and lasting memories.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.


Edit

A couple of weeks ago, having sat down and watched yet another news piece highlighting the devastating realities of war and conflict and the horror that people go through in its wake, I decided I wanted to do something, even in a little way, to help sustain the organisations that deliver vital aid to those in crisis. In particular, the children, who, through no fault of their own have to face violence, disease, hunger, and the chaos of war and disaster. 

And so, hearts for UNICEF was born! 

My aim is to bring all sorts of people together to make hanging heart decorations, that will be sold in a variety of shops and venues, with all profits going straight to UNICEF. 

So far I've had an excellent response from my fellow crafters, but I am aware that not everyone is necessarily into making hearts, or, indeed owning hearts! but UNICEF is a very valuable charity to donate to. Here are some UNICEF facts.....

  • Unicef vaccinates over a third of the worlds children. But millions more are still in danger. Every minute a child dies from preventable disease.
  • A child dies every 15 seconds as a result of malnutrition. Unicef provides 80% of the worlds life-saving emergency food. 
  • Every 5 minutes, a child dies because of violence. Unisef helps to provide psychological care for children, and work with governments to strengthen national child protection systems.
  • War and conflict puts millions of children in terrible danger. Unicef provides life-saving food, clean water, medicines, protection and psychological support to children whose lives have been devastated by the effects of war and conflict. 
   With your help, we work to make sure that children get the support they need to stay     safe and strong. 

Thank you for donating to UNICEF.

eventName: Steph and Chantal climb Machu Picchu
story:
On 7th October we will join Kantar colleagues on an epic 5 day trek up Machu Picchu. It’s daunting just thinking about it but it’s all  for a good cause: UNICEF.

Not only is this climb going to be a HUGE challenge for us… so is the amount of money we need to raise. We’ve made a good start and have a World Cup sweepstake, Quiz and Tuck shop already planned. But these alone aren’t going to get us over the line – so we need your help.

Why UNICEF?

UNICEF is the leading organisation working for children. They ensure more of the world’s children are vaccinated, educated and protected than any other organisation and have done more to influence laws and policies to help protect children than anyone else.  In 2010, Kantar established the Brighter Futures employee fundraising programme and staff have raised over $2.7 million and supports more the 80,000 children in Bangladesh, Bolivia, Malawi and Mauritania.

story:
On the 12th to the 13th March, myself and many others from the UNICEF society at the University of Sheffield will be taking part in a 24 hour fast in aid of UNICEF's Liberia appeal.

In Liberia, almost a third of children are malnourished. The initiative aims to reduce malnutrition in children under 5 - the most important years for development in children. The initiative also aims to break the cycle of malnutrition long term. 

Every donation made will be doubled by The Power of Nutrition which is a charitable foundation and will help even more to put a stop to malnutrition in Liberia. 

Thank you for taking the time to read through my page and thank you in advance for all of your donations :)

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I became a father of Josephine in 2015 and it changed my world. I can no longer do nothing when other children are suffering because that's not the world that I want my child to live in. I am honoured to be part of the team DLA Piper where we could make a meaningful contribution to and show our support for UNICEF.

In October 2018, I will be climbing 456,000 meters to make 666,666 meters trek to the historical and ancient citadel Machu Picchu in Peru. Myself and others from DLA Piper team will be trekking 6 to 8 hours for 5 days and sleep in tents at rural villages!﻿

Child protection is a vital yet often underfunded area of UNICEF's work because it is complex and requires long-term support to create systemic change in attitudes and behaviour. With the support of DLA Piper, UNICEF will be able to continue this vital work so that children can: go to school instead of work, avoid child marriage, and be safe in their communities.

Together, we can build a safer world for every child.

I hope that you might donate a little to help me smash my target of GBP 3,500 and support UNICEF's work around the world. Any donation would be most welcomed!

Thanks so much!!!

Alexander (Sasha)

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I'm Paula: slow, clumsy and so indoorsy that I class cushions as wildlife. But, for the past two years, I have been trying all seventeen Glasgow 2014 sports in an attempt to prove that there is an activity out there for even the least athletic among us. 

As the official charity partner of Glasgow 2014, UNICEF will be reaching out to some of the Commonwealth’s poorest children – ensuring the Games’ legacy resonates worldwide, and demonstrating the charity’s famous dedication to the preservation of children’s rights.

With the Games only a month away, it's time to show our dedication to UNICEF and those children they support. Donate £1 or more and I'll dedicate one of Glasgow's best - or worst - landmarks to you, by way of a lovely neon Post-It stuck to its brickwork and a commemorative photo for you to share with your loved ones - or hide in a drawer.

On 20th July, after carrying the Queen's Baton in Glasgow city centre, I'll be abseiling 164 feet from the Finnieston Crane to end the project for UNICEF. And there will be a dedicated Post-It at the top for one lovely person who donates!

For more information - and less of a sales pitch - check out my blog: www.paulamusttryharder.co.uk/alittlededication

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit Jabababy's JustGiving page.
So far we have raised the equivalent of 2478 Vacinations

1309 vaccinations @ end of 2014   

I have supported Unicef for several years now and am donating the equivalent of the cost of one Tetanus vaccine for every £1 in sales I make through my www.jabababy.com and www.sky-dreamers.com websites.

I am also hoping to raise funds through raffles and other charity events throughout the year and would welcome any contribution.

I will be updating this Blog with the progress and the equivalent amount of vaccines we have raised.

My Goal is to raise 10,000 vaccinations.

2015 - 01 - 06  I have donated the £25.00 I saved instead of sending Christmas Cards to friends and family this year - Thank you all for your understanding and thank you for helping add to this year's tally!

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Hi, friends and family, I am running in the VitalityLondon 10000 for the 2nd year on the 28th May 2018 for UNICEF UK. 

I am running for UNICEF UK, to help them support children that are in danger. That face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. This is wrong and it has to change. Unicef ensures more of the world’s children receive life-saving food, vaccines, education and protection than any other organisation. They have done more to influence laws, policies and customs to help protect children than anyone else in history. Today, by supporting Unicef, you can protect a child in danger, transform their life and build a safer world for tomorrow’s children.

Please help the children of the world by donating as much as you can on my JustGiving page, link attached.

Thank you very much for your generosity.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
In South Sudan — a country reeling from conflict, poverty and insecurity — famine was declared on February 20, 2017. More than 270,000 children may starve, and the humanitarian situation in this country continues to deteriorate. 

"Children are already severely malnourished," said UNICEF official Jeremy Hopkins. "If we do not reach these children with urgent aid, many of them will die."

The smallest donation will save a child who is incapable of helping himself.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am running to raise money for Unicef as i want to help the children who are suffering or in danger in the world right now. I had a daughter in 2017 and looking after her has been such a great joy in my life. It breaks my heart to think of the babies and children around the world who aren't safe and warm and who are less fortunate than we are. I am raising money for them. They are our future and I feel It's important to do something to help them.  I hope you agree and will help me fundraise for the kids. Whatever you can spare is greatly appreciated. 

I'm a fairly seasoned runner and running a half should be ok although I am a bit worri. I would like to thank my wonderful Andrew for encouraging and supporting me to do this. You are the best and I love you with all my everything, thank you. Xxx

About UNICEF



How your donation will be spent

On average over the last five years, for every pound spent by Unicef UK, 70p went towards our work for children around the world, 29p was spent on raising another pound and 1p was spent on governance of the charity.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
After 3 years of conflict more Syrian children than ever before need our help. Millions of children have experienced or seen brutal violence. Many have lost everything - family, friends and homes. Children have been killed, orphaned and suffered life-changing injuries. 

UNICEF will not rest until we reach every Syrian child affected by this terrible tragedy. They are working around the clock in Syria and the surrounding countries to provide children who have suffered so much with crucial and life-saving supplies such as clean water, medicine and psychological support.

But there is much more to do, and with no end in sight for this conflict the future for Syria’s children is uncertain. 

Find out more at: childrenofsyria.info

Who are UNICEF's Next Generation London?

A group of young professionals aged 21 to 40, who share a commitment to UNICEF and the children the organisation supports.

Hey everyone,

Thanks for taking the time to click the link!

UNICEF provide 80% of the worlds live saving food.  They also support children with keeping them safe in some of the worlds more volatile areas, help millions of children every year get an education and provide vaccines in over 95 countries for preventable diseases that are killing children.

It’s only a half marathon, but anything you can donate, however small, to help with things like the above (and so much more) would be absolutely incredible and hugely appreciated. Please help reach my target.

Cheers,

Michael.

story:
Hello,

My name is Mustafa Khan I am ten years old. I will be starting my
new school, Kings Edwards Five Ways Grammar school in September 2017. My new school has set me a series of challenges over the summer break, one of challenges is to raise as much money for a charity of my choice. My chosen charity is UNICEF UK. I chose this charity because UNICEF UK help vulnerable children in many regions around the world, especially those impacted by war and famine.

I love baking cakes so for my first fund raising activity I plan to bake
lots of lovely cakes (Chocolate cake is my favourite!) and have a cake sale to raise as much money as possible. For my second activity I am planning to climb Mount Snowdon in Wales at the end of August. Through these two activities and of course your help, I hope to raise at least £250, hopefully more!

It’s a very good cause so please donate as much as you can.

To keep you updated on my progress I will be posting pictures of
my fund raising activities on this page – so don’t forget to drop by for updates!

Thank you very much

By Mustafa Khan.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I have little legs - my good friends often remind me so! They are not designed for distance running.....so I have decided to run a half marathon for Unicef. Why?

Unicef helps children in dire need all over the world, with emergency crisis response, education, medicines and vaccinations and much more.

I recently watched a BBC documentary about the Myanmar Refugee crisis where Unicef was helping an 11 year old boy and his 8 year old sister who had been orphaned when their parents were murdered... Unicef was providing counselling and urgent financial and medical support....a sad but common story.

Please help me with anything you can by sponsoring me if you can. Every little helps. And my company has agreed to match any donations that I get.....

Thank you very much in advance if you are able to help.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Hello Friends!

Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Throughout  May 2018 I will be running three 10K races to raise money for UNICEF The United Nations Children's Fund. These will be on consecutive Sundays starting with the Great Birmingham Run on 6th, followed by the Great Bristol Run on 13th and culminating in the Great Manchester Run on 20th. 

For me this is a huge challenge as for the last 31 years my idea of exercise has been pulling corks out of red wine bottles! :) UNICEF is a charity that has long been very special to me since I met a UNICEF volunteer at primary school when I was 6 years old - since then I have done small stints of work for them but have always wanted to do something special!

From a life-saving vaccine to school books in a rural village classroom, the money you donate could protect a child from dangers like disease and abuse, and help them grow up safe and healthy. Every year UNICEF helps millions of children get an education – for example by providing textbooks and classroom kits, or by setting up child-friendly spaces where children can keep learning, even during a conflict or natural disaster.

UNICEF is part of the United Nations but not funded by the UN, only by individual donations, any donation you can give, no matter how large or small can make a difference. Not only will you be supporting a great cause for children both in our own country and around the world - you'll be making sure this dejected, wobbly-bottomed old git gets off his backside and, thanks to your support, does something to make a difference.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thank you!

Alan x

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Today I made a decision to once again don my running shoes to raise funds for a charity that is constantly in need of support; UNICEF.

I am going to take part in the Bath Half Marathon 2018; a fantastic event for runners of all ages and abilities! Once again I will be taking part in the event dressed up as........well the picture below might give some indication to what it might be!

Please support me in raising funds for this incredible charity that supports children throughout the world in times of emergency and crisis; unfortunately in this day and age their services are needed more and more! 

Every penny raised in sponsorship goes directly to the charity; please remember to gift aid if possible. Thank you for taking the time to read this message and I hope you can support me in this venture.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I love technology. I drool over smartphones, smartwatches, smartmetres, games consoles, sound systems... We're living in the future, and I love it.

But, being permanently connected has consequences, and not all of them are good. I've noticed that having an infinite world of entertainment at my fingertips makes me feel anxious, like there's too much to consume and not enough time. Being permanently contactable means that the challenges of work follow me home, and the challenges of home follow me to work. Having 500 friends online makes it easier to forget about the half-dozen friends and loved ones who actually know me. And, having constant background noise means that I've become uncomfortable with silence, and I believe that God is revealed in silence.

In other words, the internet can impair my sense of gratitude for how lucky I am. I'm conscious that there are currently innumerable children who have been displaced by war and violence, and that simply having a roof over my head places me in a position of privilege.

So, in terms of virtual reality, I'm going to go into the desert for a while. I've unplugged my router, put it away, and I'm not going to plug it back in for 90 days - until the 20th July. I'll still be online at work, so I'll still have access to emails, Facebook, etc. Just not at home.

Please donate to UNICEF, who do life-changing work with children all over the world. In a time when our political leaders are building walls instead of bridges, UNICEF's work needs to be supported, not least to remind us of our shared humanity.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Recent coverage on the news has made us aware that over 20 million people (men women and children) face starvation in Yemen, Nigeria, Somalia and South Sudan, possibly the worst humanitarian crisis since World War 2.

Chantelle's team are doing a 12 hour fast, from 8am to 8pm on Thursday the 23 March 2017. Giving up food, but are allowed water (Yorkshire Water of course) only whilst doing the fast.

All money raised will be donated to Unicef,  Unicef responded to 310 emergencies in 102 countries. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving
food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else.

We hope that our small sacrifice will make a different to some of those affected by this horrible crisis, we hope we have your full support on this and would love to see how much money we can raise to help.

Please donate whatever you can to our fund-raiser for Unicef UK. With your help, we can build a safer world for children.

Dear all, 

As you know, Joan Melling (Granny) is having her 100th birthday in April - what an achievement and what an inspiration she is! After to speaking to Joan, she has expressed a wish for charity donations in lieu of presents. 

Her favoured charities are Unicef and Amnesty. 

I have set up two Just Giving pages for both charities. Please see the links below:

Amnesty:  https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/joanmelling100

Unicef: https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/jmelling100

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
Fast24. Sounds easy? Think again. This is serious fasting for no less than 24 hours. One day and one night. 
Although this is seen as an extremely difficult challenge in our society, millions of people across the world are faced with starvation everyday. 
Imagine the uncertainty of not knowing whether you were going to be able to eat today, no matter how hungry you feel?
A group of us at Birmingham University have decided to take on the challenge to raise awareness for the current food crisis in West Africa and Liberia. We will fasting on Monday March 20th.
Every 12 SECONDS a child dies due to malnutrition. We are now into 2017, the new sustainable development goals have been formed, the world is becoming more globalised and yet certain parts of the world are being left behind. It's easy to think of countries in general; a low HDI value, poor levels of sanitation and high levels of malnutrition. However these facts are representing people. They are people in the 21st century who are still living in poverty, but we have the ability to help change this. Every donation big or small will make a huge difference. UNICEF supply's 80 percent of the worlds emergency food, it's not just a bundle of aid being given to a government. This money will be spent directly on the people who need it and they do. So please help us and donate to making a difference together.

story:
I've joined team Soccer Aid for Unicef! 

Soccer Aid brings stars, football legends and all of us together to raise money so that more children around the world can grow up healthy, happy and safe. 

Over the last 10 years, Soccer Aid has raised over £24 million to help millions more people get access to clean water, safe toilets and life-saving medical care. 

Sponsor me today and together we can change and save lives.

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I'm challenging myself to run the Royal Parks Half Marathon in London, October 14th. This is a huge goal for me, in many ways - it's a source of inspiration in order to regain time for myself to run (which I used to love, before the kids came along and somehow took up all my time) and to spend energy helping a good cause.

I've decided to help UNICEF, and I hope you'll like to chip in! UNICEF works in 190 countries and territories to save children’s lives, to defend their rights, and to help them fulfil their potential. Around the world 7000 newborns die every day, and UNICEF works to give all babies a healthy and safe start to their lives!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, all the money will be sent directly to the charity.
