charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
1 in 9 don't have clean water close to home.
1 in 3 people on the planet don't have a decent toilet of their own. 

We are so lucky to live such comfortable lives so we're going to put ourselves through the challenge of cycling 100 miles (160km for all our European friends out there) to raise money for the great work that WaterAid does.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty, and change their lives for good.

100 miles would be challenge enough over a few days, but the mad people at RideLondon have planned a route to be completed in under 8 hours, including the picturesque but daunting hills of Surrey!

A bit of background:

  • You should sponsor Rebecca because she's only been on a road bike once before. We hope that her cycling genes, inherited from her grandpa who once rode from Germany to Rome, will eventually reveal themselves...
  • You should sponsor Max because his patience and intense coaching is what's going to get us across the finish line. 

We'll be posting updates of our fun training rides, so watch this space.

Your support means a lot to us.

I'm taking part in the Prudential RideLondon-Surrey 100 for WaterAid. 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped. WaterAid has teams in 34 countries across the world, working with their partners to transform millions of lives every year by improving access to clean water, toilets and hygiene.

The Prudential RideLondon-Surrey 100 is a 100mile / 160km route on closed roads through London and into Surrey’s stunning countryside, with leg-testing climbs and made famous by the world’s best cyclists at the London 2012 Olympics.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
After two and a half years bravely battling Ovarian Cancer, Janet passed away peacefully on 13th July.  Cancer really is the cruellest of diseases: it takes someone who is full of life and reduces them to a shell of their former self.  We are well aware of families who have been given weeks or less after a diagnosis, and so are incredibly grateful for the time we've had; time we've spent on family holidays, reminiscing about good times in the past, and being there for each other through gruelling treatments.  We spent mum's final day laughing, joking and thinking of all the good times, in amongst the tears.  She knew it was her last day and the team at St Barnabas hospice ensured it was the perfect send-off, if there ever is such a thing. 

Janet wished for people to donate to WaterAid in her memory as they are a charity who provide clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene to those less fortunate around the world.  Thank you for donating to this page in her memory.


Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

The Yorkshire Three Peaks are situated in the Yorkshire Dales and the challenge consists of walking 25 miles whilst climbing the summits of Pen-y-ghent (694m; 2,227 ft), Whernside (736 m; 2415 ft) and Ingleborough (723m; 2,372ft) in less than 12 hours.

A crazy challenge but we're taking it on in support of a great cause.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
On the 3rd of August 2018 I will join a team of my fellow HSBC colleagues to trek 100km within the Arctic Circle in Greenland in just 5 days. With no access to typical facilities, (including social media!), we will each carry our own personal equipment and camping gear for 5 days, sleeping rough in one of the most remote parts of the world in order to rasie money for WaterAid.  Currently 663 million people, (10% of the world's population), live without safe water and over 800 children die every single day from diseases caused by dirty water and poor sanitation.  WaterAid aims to transform the lives of many of the poorest and most marginalised people by improving access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene facilities.

This will be no easy task - I will reach the grand old age of 50 in September 2018!  Throughout that half century I have had constant access to clean water. This is just a small part of my effort to 'give back' - PLEASE dig deep and donate!  It will encourage me to train hard and your donation will go to a very good cause.

To help fund raise for WaterAid I will be cycling 1000km from Bangkok to Phuket on 17 November 2017.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Every year since 2005, DPEA has entered a team for the WaterAid Challenge. This year, on 16 June, we are fielding our biggest (and cumulatively oldest) team ever!  (Tim Brian - leader, Frank and Rachel Cosgrove, Mike Croft, Malcolm Mahony, Janet McNair, Chris Norman, Martin Seddon and Andy Sikes)  And we are heading further south than ever - to climb the spectacular summit of Ingleborough in the Yorkshire Dales, where we will, hopefully, dodge the chasm of Gaping Gill and numerous pot holes on the way. 

We are once more hoping asking you to dig deep and sponsor us in aid of a very worthwhile charity that provides wholesome water supplies and sanitation to some of the world's poorest communities.  You can find out more about their work on their website at https://www.wateraid.org/uk/

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

WaterAid do incredible work in some of the world's most disadvantaged communities to provide sustainable water infrastructure and hygiene education.  This allows people to spend less time gathering water and more time in school, work and play - all of which are instrumental in ensuring effective economic development.  Imagine life without on-demand running water and you'll quickly see why their goal is for "Everyone, Everywhere" to have hassle-free access to clean water by 2030.

Right now 650 million people are living without safe water.  Two and half billion people don't have regular toilet access or sanitary sewerage facilities.  Children miss school to get water.  Adults can't work to provide more for their families because they need to spend the time getting water.  Entire populations are trapped in poverty for want of a tap and toilet.

Our trek will raise money to support projects in Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan, Ghana and Nigeria.  The group's aim is to provide clean water for 26,000 people in these countries through this fundraising venture.

I'm lucky to have been selected to take part in this amazing expedition to raise funds for this worthwhile cause.  The trek will be remote and physically challenging as we traverse 100km (62miles) of Greenland wilderness over five days carrying everything we need on our backs.  The trip itself is entirely self-funded - every penny you sponsor me will go directly to WaterAid!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.
title: Arctic Challenge for WaterAid

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
This is Het & Andrew. They love the mountains. They used to go hiking in the mountains all the time. Now they have kids. Three kids. And they go hiking occasionally, but it involves lots of bribery with sweets and cake, and certainly no photos of them together in the mountains. Only photos of the kids.

One day, Het said 'Team SES Water are doing the WaterAid mountain challenge. It's in Yorkshire - we have babysitters close by, we could spend the day together in the mountains and we can raise money for WaterAid. Shall we join?' and Andrew, amazingly, said 'Yes'.

Then, not very long ago, Het said, 'do you think we ought to start training for the mountain challenge? It's 24 miles and 1650m climb.' And Andrew said, 'well, about 10 years ago, when we were fit and had no kids, we attempted something similar and couldn't walk for a week afterwards. What could possibly go wrong?'

So, we've been training - probably not enough - but we are determined to raise much needed funds for WaterAid, so 9th of June, here we come!

Our kids have clean water, decent toilets and good health. So should everyone. Access to clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene allows people to live dignified, healthy lives, to break free from poverty and change their lives for good. Children are born healthier, they get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Yorkshire 3 peaks, we're coming to get you!

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit the Sweco Leeds teams JustGiving page for WaterAid.

Sweco have previously undertaken the WaterAid Mountain Challenge numerous times. This year we are planning an alternative Mountain Challenge, where we plan to complete a big route in the Yorkshire Dales that includes at least one of the three peaks.

If you don’t want to sponsor us for the walk, then how about sponsoring us for braving the weather? Our track record is not good in this respect. Previously we have reached our chosen peaks on our hands and knees due to the storm-force winds and experienced constant, monsoon-style rain, returning with waterlogged phones to broken or submerged tents.  Just take a look at the photos at the bottom on this page!

Maybe it will be 4th time lucky, or maybe it won’t be? However, it turns out, you will be helping us support WaterAid, which transform lives by improving access to safe water, hygiene and sanitation in the world's poorest communities.

Thank you

Sweco Leeds team (Harriet Carlyle, Karen Scott, Lukasz Pietrzykowski, Matt Powell, Johnny Burns, Stuart Marsden, Chris Millward, Lucy Pietrzykowsk, Kathryn Nolan, Peter Grant, Christine Anderson, Caroline Ball and Stephen Hughes).

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿Me and Inma are going to travel to Tanzania on 24th August, we are going on a 10 day trek, climbing 5,895m to the summit of Kilimanjaro.

This is going to be ridiculously tough, a challenge of a life time.

We are motivated to get to that summit to raise money for WaterAid, a fantastic charity working in some of the toughest places in the world to enable entire communities to unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. The money we raise will go towards providing basis human rights; clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, which will save lives.

Here is a link to our video: https://youtu.be/BRPoWYepiM8

To kick off our fundraising I have drunk just water for January! That's no coffee no tea and absolutely no alcohol!! And.... I made it. At times I actually thought climbing Kilimanjaro would be easier than drinking just water for a month, but I made it!

﻿We have had a Laboratory WaterAid Quiz night hosted by the fabulous Mr T. which was a huge success, a very entertaining evening.

﻿﻿﻿We have bake sales, football tournament and many more fundraising events coming up.

Not to forget our Kasia Lis, incredibly brave, she will shaving all her beautiful hair off in support of mine and Inma's trip to raise money for Wateraid!

﻿﻿﻿So please give generously and thank you for your support.


Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped. ﻿

By donating this winter you are helping reach 250,000 people around the world with clean water. Every £1 donated to Untapped between 1 November 2017 and 31 January 2018 will be doubled by the UK Government, up to £5 million.
﻿
Together we can change lives.
title: Michelle & Inma are climbing Kilimanjaro to raise money for WaterAid

charity.name: WaterAid
eventName: Bath to the Wash for WaterAid
story:
For the last few years I've been wondering how many miles I could cover by bike, riding from dawn to dusk on the longest day. However, as the training required for such a selfish ambition seems a bit unfair on my family, I was looking for a more valuable project to make this worthwhile.

During a pub conversation with a mate, the idea of a ride from Bath to The Wash, raising money for WaterAid, seemed to have a pleasing poetry to it. As I finalise details, I may even be able to include other places with water or ablution-themed names on the route, as long as I can cope with the extra mileage (the current route is in the region of 200 miles long). The exact date probably won't be 21st June, but it will be within a week of that date.

Only time will tell whether dusk finds me triumphantly surveying the Wash whilst filling my face with junk foods - or crying like a baby in a Cambridgeshire ditch.

I like WaterAid because clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and to grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living and run micro-businesses rather than wasting hours every day fetching water. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal - and it should be normal.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Wateraid are doing tremendous work in establishing clean water and sanitation in areas of the world that are in desperate need of it - life-changing and often life saving work.

Our walk may not be the most arduous (should take us 3 - 4 hours) but it could still be fraught with risks - will we get lost? will we still be friends by the time we complete it? will it rain?!! So many risks, I'm already getting nervous.

Any contribution would be greatly appreciated. It's truly a good cause.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
The big day is here, Stantec UK are hosting a national WaterAid Cyclothon starting today - 23rd April 2018. This will be the launch of the Stantec UK wide “Be Active” campaign and is aiming to be the biggest WaterAid fundraising event of the year. Two static bikes are set up in the kitchen of our office for maximum embarrassment for each rider to cycle as far as they can in the time allocated. I have a late afternoon slot, just in time for people to have an afternoon coffee and be amused by the strange faces I pull whilst cycling! The aim is to go as fast and as far as possible - with a little inter office competition thrown in. And the reason for doing this; 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Thank you in advance of any amount you may feel able to donate.


Martin.

story:
Following a few ill advised drinks I found myself agreeing to take part in London 10,000 for WaterAid as part of a team from LoDEG. 

Although I may question my sanity in agreeing to run what I consider to be a driving distance, I am sure we all agree that clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped. I am therefore putting myself through the pain and tears of running 10km on the 28th May so please help by sponsoring me to do this?

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
It was December 2017, and a group of Flood Risk Engineers from across London were meeting in a public house to celebrate the upcoming festivities.  The beers flowed.....and talk turned from drainage and rivers to other matters......the beers continued to flow.....

And THAT is how I got roped into running a 10k race - let that be a lesson to you all as to the dangers of beer!

I started (for the umpteenth time!) a 'couch to 5k' programme in January - to see whether I could possibly be able to take part in this event. I've never been able to run - I find it SO hard, and have only ever lasted until around week 4 of training, when I've just found it too difficult to continue.  This time, I joined a running club, and with their incredible support, along with the support of a running buddy who has been on this journey with me, I managed to RUN 5k on the 3rd April this year!!  I never really believed I'd be able to run (no stopping or walking!) that far. I've continued training for this event, and whilst it hasn't got any easier (believe me - I sound as if I'm dying for the first 15 minutes!), on the 11th May I managed to run 10k for the first time in my life!!.  I've worked really hard to get myself ready for this race, and I would appreciate anything you can possibly spare, however little, in sponsorship, very very much.  

As a group of flood risk professionals we have come together to run the Vitality London 10k, and in doing so raise money for an incredibly worthwhile charity; one which is close to our hearts, given the industry we all work in - Wateraid.  Even better, Thames Water have agreed to sponsor us as well, so we really hope to be able to make a worthwhile contribution to this important charity.  Water is vital to life, however it is so cheap and accessible in the UK, that we only ever think about it if there's too much or too little of it; but those events are thankfully rare.  We flush water down the toilet that is of fantastic quality; in a surprisingly large amount of the world, people can't even dream about having water of such quality to drink, let alone to flush away.  Your contributions can make a real difference.  Thank you.  

And now something from Wateraid.....

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
WaterAid help the world’s poorest communities to transform their lives with clean water.

1 in 10 people don’t have access to safe water and 1 in 3 don’t have access to a decent toilet. We want a world where everyone everywhere has these basic human rights by 2030. Together we can make that happen.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I visited Northern Ethiopia on holiday last year and was humbled by the conditions the majority of the population lived in - often in single room dwellings which they shared with their livestock and chickens, with no proper sanitation.

Ethiopia is one of the countries where WaterAid is active so I'd like to do a little to help them with their work.

Like last year, I'll be cycling 80 miles with 5,740 ft of climbing including a few big hills (http://www.watercyclechallenge.com/sportive-2017/romp-route/)



Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be. 

https://www.wateraid.org/uk/where-we-work/ethiopia

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
On the 6th of June we're going to walk Meikle Bin to support WaterAid Scotland.

Team members:

Martin Mathers; Brian McCulloch; Michael Vernon; Athena Fotiou; Alan Brownlie; James McPhail; Pauline McDermott; Anthony Higgins; Fergus Band; Mark Tench; Daniel Szymczak

Please help us raise lots of money for a great charity.

783 million people in the world are without safe drinking water and 2.5 billion people do not have access to adequate sanitation. We are fundraising to help WaterAid create a world where everyone has access to safe water and sanitation, basic human rights.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity and make sure Gift Aid is reclaimed on every eligible donation by a UK taxpayer. So it’s the most efficient way to donate - I raise more, whilst saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

So please dig deep and donate now

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Message from Cat & Tony

The most important present for us is to have you there on our wedding day. As we already live together, our flat is well stocked with everything we need (and more!).

If you would like to give us a gift to mark the occasion, rather than a host of toasters, please consider a donation to one of the charities that mean a lot to us, to help us spread the celebration of our marriage.

Why WaterAid is important to us

Living in Scotland, we take abundant clean water for granted, but that's not the case for terrifyingly large parts of the world. Decent toilets in schools make it more likely that more children stay in education for longer. It doesn't sound very exciting, but it does have a huge long term impact.

What WaterAid Do

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped.  

By donating this winter you are helping reach 250,000 people around the world with clean water. Every £1 donated to Untapped between 1 November 2017 and 31 January 2018 will be doubled by the UK Government, up to £5 million.

Together we can change lives.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
A while ago my friend Hattie suggested doing the Jurassic Coast challenge, a long walk along the south coast which takes place on 21st and 22nd July. I like walking, the coast is beautiful and it is for charity. What reason could there be not to?

Well, turns out it is quite a long way (100km/62 miles). And quite hilly. And it involves not sleeping for over a day. I think there's a fair chance we might not be friends by the end of it. 

But it will be worth it. 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

WaterAid does great work in over 30 different countries making this happen.  Any donation you feel able to give, no matter how big or small, will make a difference to this great cause.

Thanks so much for your support!

Helen
title: Helen's Jurassic Coast walk for WaterAid
pageSummary: I am walking 100km in 30 hours (hopefully!) because everyone should have clean water.

WaterAid believe clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be. 

We have a modest goal and hope to smash it. Please support us with whatever amount you can spare. We appreciate and thank you for your support.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Donate £100 and I (Pete Faulks) will wear either the tap or toilet outfit as the Run Director on Saturday.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Many of my colleagues at Scottish Water run at different Parkrun’s across Scotland. We also have local colleagues who have never been to Parkrun before. We are getting together at Falkirk for a volunteer takeover. WaterAid is a charity we support a lot at work and we would like to tell you a bit more about it. We will bring some water and cake for after your run on Saturday.
title: WaterAid Falkirk Parkrun volunteering

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I work for WaterAid but I also believe that what we are trying to achieve for the poorest people in the poorest areas of the poorest countries in the World is the most important thing anyone can do to help. Everyone needs water and  toilets before they can improve their lives and prospects. It's just not fair that so many people live without these basic human rights. I can't bear that children are dying every minute because their tiny bodies cannot cope with the disease in the water they drink. I can't bear that mothers are giving birth without water to drink and to clean themselves and their baby. I can't bear that so many lives are taken up with the drudgery of spending hours carrying heavy loads of water every day just to survive.

We can fix this thing and need to do it for Everyone, Everywhere by our target of 2030.

Please help me support WaterAid to make this happen.

thank-you SO MUCH! We are all involved in this.

story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped.  

By donating this winter you are helping reach 250,000 people around the world with clean water. Every £1 donated to Untapped between 1 November 2017 and 31 January 2018 will be doubled by the UK Government, up to £5 million.

Together we can change lives.

story:
The Tartan Trail is a team based walk, cycle or climb to raise money to help make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene become a normal part of life for people around the world.

Peter and his management team are completing 50 miles of the Great Glen Way on 6&7 June as part of the Tartan Trail for WaterAid.  The majority of the team are non cyclists so it may not seem far, but believe me, it'll be a challenge.

John is completing his part of the challenge in sunnier climes and in a quarter of the time from the rest of us !!

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

For my Bar Mitzvah I have chosen to support WaterAid. WaterAid is a charity which works to provide access to clean water and sanitation for the world's poorest communities

I have chosen to support it as it is a great charity and I believe they do outstanding work.   My brother went to Zambia one year ago to see the work they do and I was amazed to hear all about it, and to see his photos and the videos so I have decided to support them too.   

I would be delighted if you were able to donate as every £15 raised literally saves a life - it's the average cost of providing access to clean water per person for their lifetime - so your money will really make a big difference and go very far.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I am Iona Reid and I am doing a Charity Sailing Challenge. This challenge will take place the entire 2018 sailing season. I am hoping you would like to support a girl and her dog to raise money for two great charities: Water Aid and Guide Dogs.

I am a keen sailor and started sailing five years ago at the age of 7. My crew mate is my dog Popcorn, she will sail with me on races, if the weather is good. I will sail up to 3 times a week and hopefully more, I will also do special events such as courses, junior sessions, and casual sailing. 

I am not asking for your support for free, I am willing to work for your donation. I will advertise your company in the following ways. 

- T-Shirt with your company Logo on it over my wet suit worn during a race 
- Sticker (supplied by you) on my dinghy 
- Baseball cap with company logo (worn on non-windy days) 
- On my website 
- If you have stickers that will go on a sail I would be willing to put them on. 
- Sticker on my Helmet (worn on windy days) 

I will also mention you on my website, Instagram, Twitter and Facebook page.

We are located next to the Attenborough Nature Reserve, Every weekend hundreds of families, dog walkers, runners and cyclists pass by us, so they will see your logo. 


You can choose which of the two supported charities we are supporting to donate to: Popcorn's chosen charity is GuideDogs and has its own page. This page will donate to WaterAid.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I'm Tasha and I am raising money for WaterAid by falling out of a plane! Thank you for visiting my page.
I have wanted to do a skydive for many years now, and to have the opportunity to raise money for such a great charity at the same time is amazing. Every £2 that goes to WaterAid is a rainwater collection system and every £15 gains one person access to safe water and improved hygeine and sanitation. WaterAid is a charity that I have always wanted to donate money to and I am so excited to have the opportunity to raise a substantial amount of money for such a deserving cause.
My aim is to achieve £400 by July 2016.
I really do appreciate all your support and am extremely grateful for any donations made; all will be extremely valuable and will make a difference to someone's life.
title: Skydive for WaterAid

Name: Skydive for WaterAid

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
During the month of January, I will be taking part in Just Water. this means that I will only be able to drink water. No Beer, Coffee or soft drinks. Currently, I drink approx. 4 cups of coffee a day and my fair share of beer. so this will be a challenge. 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped. By donating this winter you are helping reach 250,000 people around the world with clean water. Every £1 donated to Untapped between 1 November 2017 and 31 January 2018 will be doubled by the UK Government, up to £5 million.Together we can change lives.

Not only will this be beneficial to people all over the world but also for health and fitness. So I would really welcome any donations and please feel free to take part in the journey with me and many others.

WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
As a personal and team challenge I will be taking part in the Yorkshire 3 peaks challenge along with 27 colleagues.    ﻿﻿ The 24 mile route  and 5200ft ascent is estimated to take around 12 hours and is not for the faint-hearted!

We will be walking for the wonderful charity wateraid. ﻿Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.  With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Thank you for taking the time to look at my fundraising page.


Anna x

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
The Long Drop 2018

Employees from Scottish Water will face their fears by bungee jumping or swinging from a bridge in support of WaterAid!

In a combination of two activities the Highland Fling Bungee and the Highland Fling Bridge Swing at Killiecrankie a group of brave individuals will be raising money through sponsorship for WaterAid.

If you want to support the fantastic work that WaterAid does meanwhile sponsoring a friend, colleague or family member to do one of these daring activities then please donate to this page.

Why?

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped. By donating this winter you are helping reach 250,000 people around the world with clean water. 

Every £1 donated to Untapped between 1 November 2017 and 31 January 2018 will be doubled by the UK Government, up to £5 million.Together we can change lives.

Just £15 can help provide one person with access to safe water.

Your donations make a huge impact, thank you for your support!
title: The Long Drop for WaterAid

story:
Hi all,

I'll be at Southbank Centre, Bristol Christmas Market selling some amazing South West artists work to help fundraise for the cause and help communities in need in Madagascar and Sierra Leone.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped. By donating this winter you are helping reach 250,000 people around the world with clean water. Every £1 donated to Untapped between 1 November 2017 and 31 January 2018 will be doubled by the UK Government, up to £5 million.Together we can change lives.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Over Christmas, I was affected by the stories about children not having clean water. Water is one of the things that keep us alive. I am 9 years old and one of the people who feel really sad about that. If I were one of them, I would go and find water for my family and friends. It's also really difficult for the girls and boys to get water because they have to miss 5-6 hours of their day getting water and it's usually dirty! That's why I'm raising money for WaterAid.  https://www.wateraid.org/uk/. 

I will swim the distance of the English Channel, 21 miles (appx. 34 km) between now and February 2018. Please sponsor me! 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped. By donating this winter you are helping reach 250,000 people around the world with clean water. Every £1 donated to the WaterAid #Untapped campaign between 1 November 2017 and 31 January 2018 will be doubled by the UK Government, up to £5 million.Together we can change lives.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
WaterAid's aims:
 
Between 2009 and 2015 our ambition is that a further 25 million people will have access to safe water, improved hygiene and sanitation as a direct result of our work; and that by influencing the policies and practices of governments and service providers we will have reached a further 100 million people.
Our four global aims are:
 
To promote and secure poor people's rights and access to safe water, improved hygiene and sanitation.
To support governments and service providers in developing their capacity to deliver safe water, improved hygiene and sanitation.
To advocate for the essential role of safe water, improved hygiene and sanitation in human development.
To further develop as an effective global organisation recognised as a leader in our field and for living our values.

story:
Hi everyone,

Every day, 844 million people across the globe have to travel miles to access clean water and one newborn dies every minute as a result. That's a devastating 1440 babies every day. So, this Sunday I'll be walking 15 miles in the Glasgow Kilt Walk to raise money for WaterAid. . Donations of any amount are welcome and are greatly appreciated! 

Thank you all so much in advance, Sam x

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
On 3rd August 2018, I will be trekking over 100km within the Arctic Circle in Greenland as part of a group of 100 HSBC colleagues. With no access to a shower, 'proper' toilet or the outside world, I will be carrying all of my personal equipment and camping gear for 5 days and will be roughing it in one of the most remote places in the world to raise money for WaterAid.

Currently 663million people (10% of the world's population) live without safe water and over 800 children die every single day from diseases caused by
dirty water and poor sanitation. WaterAid aims to transform the lives of
the poorest and most marginalised people by improving access to safe water,
sanitation and hygiene, and hopes to give everyone safe access to water by
2030, so please dig dip and sponsor this worthy cause!

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

As part of our commitment to raising money for Water Aid, PBA are hosting our own 'Water Aid Mountain Challenge' in 2017.  It is the same as the official Water Aid event just on a different weekend and in a different location! However, despite its unofficial nature, we have some notable challenges planned for this year.  Our home for the weekend will be in Ambleside set within the Lake District, home to England's highest mountain and deepest lake, which has also just become a World Heritage Site.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
To celebrate Water Aid’s 36th birthday on Thursday 20 July,
we’re having a dress down with a difference. It’s a chance to wear your
best summer gear for one day only for our ‘shorts and shades’ dress down day.

Why not slip on your colourful Hawaiian shirts or shorts, or put on your shades to celebrate WaterAid’s great work over the last 36 years? Over this time, WaterAid has gone from strength to strength to become one of the most respected organisations dealing solely with water, sanitation and hygiene issues.  

By donating a suggested £2 to dress down on 20 July we can help support WaterAid’s continuing great work. Don't forget to add Gift Aid!

Thanks for your support!

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I really care about WaterAid,

It does such amazing work in the communities it works in. It transforms people's lives. They stop living their entire days around finding water & just existing. Wateraid helps families & towns start focussing on more. With sanitation & water facilities people can take their first steps into so much more.

Farming, markets, education, LIFE. The list goes on. It all starts with the things we take for granted.

I've written a cookbook - Its called Eat With Alex, and I'm donating every penny to WaterAid.

It's the kind of food I love, and the things I think everyone should know a bout. From the perfect cinnamon loaf for that weekend brunch, homemade pizza, to a few festive treats to impress the family with at Christmas.

Thank you for taking the time to read my page.

Alex

eventName: BDO Islamic Network's Fasting Challenge 2018 - WaterAid
story:
﻿﻿﻿﻿With Ramadan approaching, the BDO Islamic Network thought it would be a great idea to challenge people to take part in a dawn to dusk fast whilst raising funds for a great cause!

All proceeds will go towards WaterAid's fight against the global crisis of poor water sanitation, hygiene and low prevalence of clean water across the globe.

We chose this fund because WaterAid offer life-saving work to those in poor regions. We also felt that those taking part in the challenge will have a newfound love and appreciation of water!

More details can be found at https://www.wateraid.org/uk

﻿﻿And a big thank you to everyone at BDO taking part in the challenge or donating - your help is greatly appreciated!

If you have any queries, please contact Kinza.Sheikh@bdo.co.uk or Israh.Shabbir@bdo.co.uk

Thanks,

BDO Islamic Network

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
• 1 in 10 people don’t have access to safe water and 1 in 3 don’t have access to a decent toilet. 
  • 2.4 billion people in the world – one in three – do not have an adequate toilet.
  • 663 million people in the world do not have access to safe water.
  • If everyone everywhere had clean water, the number of diarrhoeal deaths would be cut by 34%.
  • 42% of healthcare facilities in Africa do not have access to safe water.
  • WaterAid help the world’s poorest communities to transform their lives with clean water
  • We want a world where everyone everywhere has these basic human rights by 2030. Together we can make that happen.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
On Wednesday 22 March, Triflow Concepts will be celebrating
World Water Day by fundraising for WaterAid.

Clean drinking water is an essential daily requirement, however 1 in 10 people around the world still do not have access to safe drinking water and 1 in 3 do not have access to a proper toilet.  

Through fundraising and community projects, WaterAid transform lives by working with the world’s poorest communities to improve access to safe water, hygiene and sanitation.

During 20 – 24th March, cake sales, dress in blue and a 5-a-side football match are just some of the ways we will be raising money for WaterAid. We hope that you too will find the time to support this worthy cause, wherever you are!

For only a few pounds, you could be helping to supply access to safe water. Any contribution to WaterAid will help them to change lives.

Together, let’s make a difference.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am joining a group of fellow WaterAid supporters in a trip to WaterAid's Madagascar country programme.

We will see the work that is being carried out to help bring clean water to a country where almost half the population does not have access to water and access to toilets and sanitation are at an even lower level.

We will see how WaterAid involve the communities in their transformation. It's not a case of giving & then leaving; WaterAid ensure the communities are able to maintain their new resources and make the very best of the opportunities these offer.

WaterAid will lobby councils and governments to ensure they realise the importance of 'everyone, everywhere' gaining access to water before 2030.

As such, this is not an appeal for money but a raising of awareness. A chance for their story to be told and for differences to be made.

However, if you are moved by the stories that I will come back with and recognise the magnitude of the problem, then yes, please feel free to contribute because WaterAid really do make your donations work for these communities. Communities that will benefit for years & decades to come.

Thank you! Mike.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Hi everyone, 

Thanks for taking the time to visit my page.

Earlier this year I joined this great initiative at work called Water Innovators. The aim of the initiative is for corporate company teams to come together and do two things :

Firstly, to propose a creative solution to real world challenges involving accessing water in some of the world's poorest areas. This year we've been focusing on Cambodia, and we're well on the way to our final submission at the end of September!

Secondly, to raise awareness and funds for this fantastic cause. There are so many reasons why this is important. Access to safe, clean water is a basic human right and we should be ashamed if in the 21st century we still can't collectively get this first, simple step sorted.

To raise awareness for this cause, I will be abandoning any other type of drink for 7 days from Monday 15th - Sunday 21st August. No tea in the morning, no coffee to get me through the day, no glass of wine after work. Just water.

Now, I know this isn't climbing a mountain, or swimming the channel, or running a marathon and you may be wondering why to sponsor someone just to drink water. So instead of thinking of this as sponsoring me, check our the WaterAid website (http://www.wateraid.org/uk) , read more about the Water Innovators programme and instead think of this as a gentle prompt to donate to a cause that is already worth donating to, with or without a mountain.

That's all from me, thanks for any donations!

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Scouts have been collecting and purifying river water to raise money for Water Aid – an international charity that transforms lives by improving access to safe water, hygiene and sanitation.

Boys and girls from 2nd Stamford Scouts walked from their headquarters in Empingham Road to Stamford Meadows where they used plastic containers and bottles to collect as much water as possible from the River Welland.

After walking back again, they set about purifying the water by pouring it through hand-made filters made from tights, sand and gravel before starting a fire to boil it.

The exercise was intended to mirror the journeys made daily by many children in poverty-stricken countries around the world.

He said: “We asked the scouts to collect as much water as they possibly could, and after around four hours of work they were left with just a small pan full.

“That really drove home how tough life would be if you had to transport enough water for your family to drink, use for cooking, cleaning and bathing. It’s easy to take for granted the fact we have instant access to clean, safe tap water whenever we need it. A lot of people aren’t that lucky.”

Barbara xx

story:
The Raffle  - One of our colleagues has paid for four nights accommodation (double bedroom apartment and shared bathroom) at Casa de Santos B&B in the centre of Lisbon from 9-12th May 2016. Unfortunately he can no longer go and the accommodation is non-refundable. He has offered the accommodation as a prize to raise money for WaterAid. The Hotel has approved this. Please note , travel to Lisbon is not included with this offer 

How to enter It’s easy to buy your ‘virtual raffle tickets’ by donating through our JustGiving page. Raffle tickets are £5 each and all the money will go to WaterAid. You buy  as many tickets as you like. Just select an amount with a denomination of £5, £10, £15 etc.

Make sure you include your name on your donation so that we can contact the winners. Please do not Gift Aid as this is not allowed for raffle donations.

The raffle closes at midnight on Friday 4th March . The draw will take place on Wednesday 9th March.  The first name picked will win the accommodation. We will notify the winners by email, and publish the total amount raised and announce the winners in Weekly Buzz.

WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Hello and thank you for visiting my JustGiving page.

On 2nd October 2015 I will be climbing Mount Kilimanjaro for WaterAid.

WaterAid is an international organisation whose mission is to transform the lives of the poorest and most marginalised people by improving access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene. The scale of the problem is sadly huge - globally there are 650 million people living without safe water, and 1 in 3 without a decent toilet. Improving access to these basic services for these people can in turn help improve health, educational opportunities, and the ability to make a living, which facilitates sustainable economic development in growth markets.

Climbing Kilimanjaro is a going to be a big personal challenge. I will be taking the Lemosho route which approaches the mountain from the west, and will involve 7 days of hiking and camping on the mountain, at altitudes of up to 5,900 m and temperatures as low as -15 °C.

I would very much appreciate your generous contributions please to help support WaterAid’s fantastic work.

(Please note that your kind donations will go directly towards supporting WaterAid as the trip costs have already been covered.)

My Apis co-founder Matteo Stefanel is also doing this challenge and raising money for WaterAid - his page can be found at: https://www.justgiving.com/Matteo-Stefanel/

Thank you for your support.

Uday

charity.name: WaterAid
eventName: Ravi is climbing Kilimanjaro for WaterAid!
story:
Hello!

Thanks for visiting my JustGiving page.

On 2nd October 2015 I’ll be climbing Mount Kilimanjaro for WaterAid!

WaterAid does fantastic work - their mission is to transform the lives of the poorest and most marginalised people globally by improving access to safe water and sanitation. I often find myself taking these things for granted as they’re always within reach for me. Sadly this isn’t the case for everyone and I’m sure you’ll agree that that's not ok. 

Climbing Kilimanjaro is a massive personal challenge. Far from your typical walk in the park, this will involve 7 days of hiking and camping on the mountain, at altitudes of up to 5,900 m and temperatures as low as -15 °C. To raise the stakes a bit more I’m also doing the Thames Path Challenge - a 50 km walk from Putney to Runnymede in September.

Hopefully you’re convinced this is an effort and cause worthy enough to generously support WaterAid’s amazing work - I’ll be forever grateful!

(Please rest assured that all of your kind donations will go directly towards supporting WaterAid as the trip costs have already been covered.)

Thank you for your support.

Ravi
title: Ravi is climbing Kilimanjaro for WaterAid!

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Some areas in the North West of England have recently been inconvenienced by having to boil or buy safe drinking water due to the contamination of our water supply.

Whilst I appreciate this is a difficult situation, it really has brought home to me how lucky we are and how much we take this for granted! Is it really such a hardship to have to boil drinking water or take a trip to the shops to buy bottled water?

Compare this to the 650 Million people around the world who live without safe drinking water.

2.3 Billion (that's one in three!) people do not have access to adequate sanitation.

500,000 children die every year from diarrohea, caused by unsafe drinking water. That's 1,400 deaths every day.

But it's also the other implications that affect these communities, the process of collecting water is so time consuming and exhausting they have little time or energy left for anything else. That's hours every day that could be spent much more productively. WaterAid also reports that many girls who are fortunate enough to attend school are forced to drop out when they begin to menstruate, this is purely due to the lack of basic sanitation.

United Utilities have promised to compensate every household and business affected. This compensation is estimated to be around £45.00 per customer, with the total bill expected to be about £15 million. If we can raise just a fraction of this it will save lives, transform communities and give children around the world a chance for a better future.

So I'm asking that, when you receive your compensation from United Utilities, you consider using a little to change or save a life and donate it to this cause.

Also, when all the money is in, I will be writing to Steve Mogford (the CEO of United Utilities) to ask that his company match our donation.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
While we're all rightfully freaking out about a water contamination scare... it kind of puts things in perspective to think about those living in parts of the world where finding safe, clean drinking water isn't just a problem for a few days.

Yes it's a pain having to fight for the last bottle at the supermarket, or fill your fridge with jugs of boiling water that take longer than you ever realised to cool down... but it could be much worse.

If everyone could spare a few quid for WaterAid, together we could make a huge contribution to a cause we suddenly have a little more appreciation for :)

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
WaterAid works in 27 countries to help poor communities establish sustainable water supplies and latrines, close to home, and to promote safe hygiene practices. I would encourage you to have a read about their success stories in the link below.

It is a fantastic cause and along with hiring a boat and drinking anything we can find that isn't water based, we are raffling off some fantastic prizes donated by local businesses and clients to raise funds for those who would prefer a pint of fresh water (presumably, Clayton).

Some of these prizes include:

  • One nights stay at St. Pancras hotel
  • £400 travel voucher from Flight Centre
  • Cocktail making masterclass for 5
  •  A weeks free lunch from Abokado

The cost of the raffle tickets are £5 for one and £20 for five. We ask that you purchase your raffle tickets by making a donation and we will hand deliver the appropriate number of tickets.

Thank you, Social Squad :)

Link: http://www.wateraid.org/uk/what-we-do/stories-from-our-work

This is the 11th year we have organised Sing and Swim  and  we have raised over £22,000 for WaterAid since we started. charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I am a student from Manchester who spent time as a volunteer in Africa over June/July 2014. 
Before I went I expected too see poverty, but I was shocked to see, with my own eyes, children and families drinking dirty water knowing full well it could kill them. But they had no choice.

Since being back I have wanted to do more to help them. So therefore, I have set myself 7 tasks I aim to complete over the next year, these include:

1. Skydive.
2. Bundgee Jump.
3. Climb Britain's 3 peaks: Bennevis, Helvellyn and Snowdon.
4. Spending a night in one of Britain's most haunted houses. 
5. I will get a small tattoo designed by somebody else (A pupil at Charity School, Tanzania, where I volunteered as a teacher).
6. Abseiling a building.7. A bike ride from Manchester City Centre to Blackpool pier.
I need as much support as I can get, so please please please donate to help make a difference to people lives. We are all human beings.

We estimate that £15 can help bring one person safe clean water, so by fundraising for WaterAid you’ll have the opportunity to help transform the lives of real people all over the world.

Thank you for your donation :)

eventName: JJ's Armacell ES Wateraid - Yorkshire 3 Peaks Challenge
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. 

Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. 

It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I have decided to set myself a challenge to raise money for a good cause.

Most people know how much I love a drink, so I have decided to lay it on the line and give up alcohol for a whole year…

It’s not climbing Everest but for a Tequila lover like myself it won’t be easy. I am raising money for the Wateraid project in Bahi, Tanzania . I started on 24th July 2014 and not on the home straight yet – so your support on the way will be appreciated :)

Earlier this year I was lucky enough to go to Tanzania and travel around the country. It’s an amazing place and a lot of good things going on there but in the rural areas especially there is a lot of hardship and people are missing quite a lot. They don’t have Mojitos at the weekend or in many cases even any running water or sanitation – so I thought I should see what I can do to help make a difference. 

Tanzania is the largest country in East Africa, with a population of 45 million people. It’s technically advanced but is also one of the poorest countries in the world. Due to the hot, dry climate, safe water is scarce and growing enough food is often difficult in rural areas. Only 12% of the population have somewhere safe and hygienic to go to the toilet and only 47% of the population have access to safe water.

There are lots of good people helping to change this, including Wateraid – who are having a big impact working with local communities to provide water and sanitation services.

In the last 2 years Wateraid have been working in the Bahi district in Tanzania bringing improved safe water and sanitation to seven rural communities. This has reduced the time taken by local people to fetch water from an average of five hours to a maximum of 30 minutes making a massive difference to their lives. It’s a great start but there is still lots more to do and the project is running short of funds. A small donation can go a long way to helping people in Tanzania have access to fresh water - something that we are all lucky enough to take for granted.

I am keen to see an impact from my dryathalon and we still have a long way to go helping level out the basics around the world. Any donation you make to this page will go directly to the Bahi district project where it will make a real difference.

 

Me giving up a luxury is nothing in comparison to missing a basic need like water – something it’s easy for us to forget when we live where we do and have never experienced it ourselves.

 

Your donations and support will be most welcome. Instead of buying me a pint this year buy a pint for these guys - they need it more than me!
title: Going dry for a year

story:
Cardiff Singing
I've been running the community page www.cardiffsinging.info for a number of years now for free, helping people find singing groups in and around the Cardiff area. I dearly hope you find the site useful. If you have, please consider making a donation to save lives. 

Digital Life Support
I often find myself doing little favours for people - particularly helping them with IT and all things digital! I love doing this stuff, and realise that charging small amounts of money wouldn't make much of a difference to my life. 

But small contributions really can make a difference to someone who doesn't have clean drinking water. Every £1 helps improve the lives of the World's poorest people. I have chosen WaterAid because clean water and sanitation is absolutely fundamental in improving the lives of the World's poorest people.

story:
Ramadan is the ninth month of the Islamic year, during which fasting is observed from dawn til sunset. It is also a time for Muslims to think of those who are less fortunate than themselves and a time for Muslims to give to charity. 

The feeling of thirst during Ramadan becomes particularly intense in Summer but when opening my fast I am blessed enough to be able to drink clean water, however millions of people all over the world aren't as fortunate as myself and do not have access to clean drinking water, I have therefore decided this year to raise as much money as possible to support the charity WaterAid.

WaterAid work with local partners to deliver clean water, sanitation and hygiene to some of the poorest communities in the world. They aim to reach 'everyone everywhere by 2030'.

Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. Donating through JustGiving is simple, once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity.

WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. I'm running a 10K marathon! Please donate, any small amount would be greatly appreciated! It's easy to be cynical about fundraisers and be suspicious the real reason for running marathons is to tone that booty for summer. But seriously. I'm doing this for a vital cause.

I know what happens behind the scenes at WaterAid, the organisation does fantastic work. Its goal is to bring everyone, everywhere clean water by 2030. We've got iPads and all the tech, yet still 1 in 5 young children worldwide DIE from illnesses like diarrhoea caused by dirty water. In 2016 that is diabolical.

Globally, the lack of clean safe water kills more people than malaria and AIDS combined. For those unfortunate to be born into extreme poverty the need to address water and sanitation inequality is urgent.

We're lucky to have sewage treatment works, clean tap water, hygienic hospitals if sick, have a medical condition or to give birth. It all comes down to clean, safe water! WaterAid brings drinking water, toilets and hygiene education to some of the world's poorest communities.

So please, donate and I'll run this 10K marathon for the 2.3 billion people without the dignity of toilets and the 650 million people without clean drinking water. Your donations will provide clean water pumps that will transform lives. Thank you so much!

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
We are WaterAid Edinburgh, a society at the University of Edinburgh. 

Right now 650 million people in the world live without safe water. Furthermore, around 315,000 children die every year from diseases caused by dirty water and poor sanitation. WaterAid is making massive differences to many lives across the world, and we would like to play our part too!

So, for an entire week, the society has pledged to only drink water, just water, in the lead up to World Water Day on the 22nd of March. For students nearing deadlines this, as you may have guessed, will be a challenge. Our diet coke and coffee addictions are being put aside for a great cause (and we will be celebrating the end of the week with relish!) 

WaterAid's mission is to transform the lives of the poorest and most marginalised people by improving access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene. 

Please give anything you can, every penny will help WaterAid change lives. Feel free to contact us at our email address (wateraid.edinburgh@gmail.com) and see the WaterAid website for much more information. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.


Hi guys, as you may have gathered by now, I like to fundraise money for charities, especially one's to do with enabling access to safe water across the globe for those who do not have it.

I have decided to closely shave my hair on the 22nd April 2016 to fundraise money for WaterAid. For those that know me personally, you will know that I love my hair, and this is exactly why I have decided to do this challenge, because it will be tough but completely worth it. All money that I fundraise will go directly to WaterAid, and this money will be used to give villagers across the world the skills and tools to access water, by enabling them to build wells and extract water from the land. This money will go towards helping these people become sustainable by giving them the skills to work themselves, creating jobs and giving villages access to safe drinking water.

I want to do this because I think that safe water is one of the most basic human rights, and there are millions who still do not have access to it. Thousands of girls and women are neglected an education and work due to having to walk miles to collect water, and it's not necessarily clean water either. 900 children a day die from diarrhoeal diseases due to drinking dirty water - so I want to help get this statistic down by fundraising money to help others.

*** My hair will also be getting donated to the Little Princess Trust, that make wigs for little boys and girls that have sadly lost their hair due to cancer treatment ***

I hope that you can all support me as this is a massive leap from my last fundraising event, and it will ultimately help so many other people.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
For some reason, on a cold, wet, Tuesday night last December I signed up for the Great North Run, not thinking I would be successful.

I was. Bugger.

So, 10 years after running it for the first time as a fit and healthy 25 year old, I'm trying it again as a slightly overweight 35 year old. Originally I set myself the challenge of beating my 2008 time of 1 hour 52mins. As we get closer to the race, my goal has changed to just finish the race alive!

I've decided to run for WaterAid. Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
At a time when Lancashire is experiencing a water contamination crisis, many of us are thinking about the millions of people around the world who can't simply go to the shop and buy bottled water or boil their water to make it safe.

Facts and Statistics

650 million people in the world do not have access to safe water. This is roughly one in ten of the world's population.
(WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) Report 2015)

Around 500,000 children die every year from diarrhoea caused by unsafe water and poor sanitation - that's over 1,400 children a day. 
(Committing to Child Survival: A Promise Renewed - Progress Report 2014, UNICEF, September 2014)

One study estimates that funding for water and sanitation infrastructure is lacking by US$115 million a year in Sub-Saharan countries. (Africa Infrastructure Country Diagnostic (AICD) Study), while WHO gives a global estimate of $535 billion needed in new capital investment to reach universal access, or $26.75 billion per year between 2010 and 2030. (Hutton, WHO, 2012)

Just £15 can help provide one person with access to safe water.
(WASHCost and WaterAid, 2014).


Water aid are carrying out amazing work helping over 2.1 million people last year get access to clean water. Their goal is to get safe water, sanitation and hygiene to everyone, everywhere by 2030. So please help make this happen by donating anything you can and sharing with everyone you know.

Lets show all those that need it, some Lancashire support!

story:
Hi, my name is Dustin Bridger and I am 8 years old. Like Thor, i hadn't cut my hair for 3 years. These are some things I like in life:

1) my hair
2) my football
3) my art
4) my family
5) animals (I've been a vegetarian since I was 3)

Until a few weeks ago my life was normal. Then I began to get sick, as I had a lump in my chest and found it hard to breath. About 4-weeks ago I was diagnosed with Leukemia and went to Great Ormond Street Hospital.

I have started chemo and am responding very well to treatment. But one of the side effects of treatment is that my hair has begun to fall out.

Today I decided to shave my hair and raise money for charity. For the time being, I am more Picasso than Thor.

I want to raise as much money as possible for WaterAid, Macmillan Cancer Support and the RSPCA. The other two charities are on my other JustGiving pages.
