charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I will be travelling to Uganda in June to be part of Welsh Water’s continued support to WaterAid.

All donations raised will help towards finding appropriate and sustainable solutions to the poor sanitation and lack of clean, safe drinking water by working with local community organisations to support them to build their own solutions, to encourage people to take ownership of projects to ensure they are in control of changes to their environment. If you would like to get involved or learn more about how WaterAid are making a difference in Uganda and other countries, check out WaterAids webpage www.wateraid.org.

In Uganda alone 9.2 million people don't have access to safe water; this is a quarter of the population. As a result, over 12,000 children die every year from diarrhoea caused by unsafe water and poor sanitation.

Uganda is growing fast and many small towns develop without adequate access to clean water and sanitation. Welsh Water is looking to support this provision in the township of Namalu in Northern Uganda.


Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thank you for visiting my page and giving to a great cause!

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Many of you will know I travelled to Uganda in November 2014 to see first hand some of the fantastic work that WaterAid do. The communities we met, and the staff at WaterAid Uganda are a true inspiration. If you want to learn more about this please read my blog at

https://adamuganda14.blogspot.com.

http://player.vimeo.com/video/117912648

This year I will be:

January: #Justwater January I have given up all drinks apart from water for the whole of Janaury, this was a massive challenge and every morning I woke up wanting a coffee. I cant believe I managed to do it, for the whole month I had tap water, 2 hot waters and one bottle of sparkling water.

June 6th - The Corbett Challenge Along with a team of others I will be climbing Dove Crag in the lake district as part of WaterAids 'Corbett Challenge. I have done this event three times in the past, this year will be the hardest year for sure.

Please sponser me to complete both these events and help raise money to make sure that Everyone, Everywhere has access to clean safe water by 2030

story:
﻿﻿THE DRAW WILL TAKE PLACE AT 5PM ON MONDAY 20TH AUGUST - you can still donate to the page after this time, but you won't be in with a chance of winning the tickets!

Thames Water have been given 7 pairs of Guest tickets for Reading Festival, which we are raffling to support our Thames Loves Malawi campaign for WaterAid. These tickets give you access to better facilities and food than the normal tickets!

Each entry to the raffle is £5, and you can win a pair of tickets for the festival! There is no limit to the number of entries per person.

This is only open to Thames Water employees (but you can bring a family member if you win!) - you'll need to show your ID badge to prove you work for TW.

Please include your name on your donation, so we can contact you!

﻿Good luck!

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

eventName: WaterAid transform lives with safe water
story:
I wish to raise funds for WaterAid in a variety of ways throughout 2017. I know my family & friends will be very supportive because we all wish more people had safe water. So far I took homemade buns, cookies & flapjack into the office. I plan to: drink only water for 48 hours; accompany (or possibly be accompanied by!) Bethan, my eldest daughter, to #FinishThirst in Newcastle's Great North Run which will be Bethan's first half marathon.

"WaterAid help the world’s poorest communities to transform their lives with clean water.1 in 10 people don’t have access to safe water and 1 in 3 don’t have access to a decent toilet. We want a world where everyone everywhere has these basic human rights by 2030. Together we can make that happen."

story:
We will be walking The Yorkshire Three Peaks route for WaterAid charity. The 38.6 km (24 miles) route is estimated to take around 12 hours.

WaterAid’s mission is to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere. We all know that 844 million people living without clean water shouldn’t be normal. That 2.3 billion people not having a decent toilet shouldn’t be normal. That poverty shouldn’t be normal.

By working together, we can enable entire communities to unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. With the help of amazing people like you, we can support WaterAid for making it happen.

Thank you for being part of it!

Oana

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

I came back from Nepal earlier in the year with Giardia, and was off work for nearly 3 months (having been stupid enough to eat unwashed salad).  I lost over a stone and a half in weight, having been in the "normal" weight category to start with.  We tend to rather take our clean water supply for granted - imagine having no clean water for drinking, washing everything from ourselves to vegetables to clothes, and no clean toilets (holes in the ground can still be commonplace in Nepal).  Giardia causes cognitive problems and stunted growth in children (particularly in India, Nepal and some African countries), and I can now begin to understand the distress having it causes having had a particularly resistant strain myself and 8 lots of antibiotics (which I'm also fortunate to have had access to).  I'm now clear, and have left training for this event until later on as I needed to see whether I would be well enough, and my sciatica is quite bad at the moment.  But I am gong to dose myself up on painkillers, and go!!

Please donate towards someone, somewhere in the world less fortunate than ourselves, having a clean water supply.

story: My name is Olivia-Leigh. I am 9 years old and it makes me feel so sad when I see children from other countries drinking dirty water and being so poorly. story:
This is a memorial page for James O'Connell set up by his family. James died on Sunday 8 September 2013 at the age of 87 after a short period of illness. 

We have set up a memorial fund to remember him - and to receive donations in lieu of funeral flowers.

We would like the donations to be split between WaterAid and St Joseph's Hospice. The only way to do this on JustGiving is to set up two separate donation pages.

This page is for WaterAid donations and the page for St Joseph's Hospice donations can be found here #mce_temp_url#.

Wateraid was one of James' favourite charities. Having lived and worked for 18 years in Africa, James had seen first-hand the hardship and illness caused by a lack of access to safe water. Clean water is essential for life, but one in ten of the world's population does not have access to it. Just £15 can enable one person to access a lasting supply of safe water, improved hygiene and sanitation.

Many thanks for your support and donations,
The O'Connell Family
title: In Memory of James O'Connell for WaterAid
rememberedPersonSummary.name: James OConnell
Name: In Memory of James O'Connell for WaterAid

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
When I was researching various charities before my barmitzvah, I called WaterAid and found out that for just £15 a life could be saved.  That put things into perspective.   I can think of many things we can get for £15, whether it’d be a pizza or a cinema ticket, an Xbox game or a taxi ride. Those luxuries of life are things we tend to take for granted.  Could you imagine not being able to take fresh water for granted? Forget the pizza for a minute, someone’s dying and you can do something about it. Millions of people in Africa have no choice but to drink contaminated water which is killing a child every 15 seconds. However, we are so lucky that we do have a choice, and for me it was an obvious one.  Now, whenever I pay for something at the counter, I think to myself: “Hold on. Why am I buying this? Is it because I need it? No. There’s nothing I need. Could I be doing something better with it? Yes.” And there lies the answer.  They say that a life is priceless, but if you look at it this way, there are a virtually an unlimited number of them for £15. Just £15.   I hope that through selling more CDs and continuing to perform live (visit www.the4sons.com), we will be able to continue to save1000s of lives. If that’s not a good enough substitute for Fifa17, what is?   George Rosenfeld, The 4 Sons

Don't forget to email music@the4sons.com with your address if you'd like to receive a copy of our CD.  Visit www.the4sons.com to find out more about us - we'd be delighted to hear from you!

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
eventName: I will skydive to raise money for wateraid!
story:
Hello to all those beautiful souls, 

My name is Nasreen, I recently went to east Africa and saw a very different world to the one most of us are accustomed to! I saw children, women, frail men and women walking hours and hours in the dry heat just to get some water to drink, but the even sadder part is this was not even clean water it was dirty water. Most homes do not even have a toilet and have no choice but to use the bushes. 

I have decided therefore to raise as much money by doing a skydive on the 26th August 2016, Even though I am petrified of heights!! Please help me raise as much money in any way you are able to. 

"There is no safe water around so we just go to the waterhole to fetch some water to drink I think this brings about diarrhoea" (adama a school pupil).

The quote above is from a girl in Burkina Faso, Africa, she wants to become a teacher when she grows up, but she has to miss a lot of school because she's Ill most of the time due to lack of safe water. She says it's impossible for her to wash her hands. The problem is made worse by the fact she doesn't have access to a toilet, meaning she has to go to the bushes even at night making it harder to stay safe and well and contaminating water further. 

42 million people in ethopia do not have access to safe water. Only 20% have access to a toilet. Up to, 2,000- 4,000 children under the age of 5 die a year!  This is in most places in Africa, (Burkina Faso, ethopia, Mali, Tanzania, Rwanda)! 

Work is hard to find for most, most make a living through farming, without water it's difficult for them to grow crops they need to support themselves and their families. In addition to this when work is available it's difficult to work due to the many hours they have to walk just to access water (over 2 hours at the very least). 

What really saddens me, is that diarrhoea is a preventable disease. We really can make a huge difference to each person by donating to wateraid so everyone can have access to clean water and toilets. A basic human right that we take for granted :( 

From the bottom of my heart I request for you to donate and make a difference. 

Thank you so much for your support ❤️

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life.... 

But it (clean water) being within reach just the turn of a tap away is taken for granted when all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped. 

So to help raise awareness and hopefully get some funds for resources to those that need it, I, Laura 'Lora' Stephens, am doing JustWater Aid - because Dry January needed a next level...

No Tea. Coffee. Squash. Fizzy. Cider. Wine. Shots. Beer. Milk.... you get the picture. Only water will be drunk. (I'm still allowed to eat) 

AND By donating this winter you are helping reach 250,000 people around the world with clean wateR BECAUSE Every £1 donated to Untapped between 1 November 2017 and 31 January 2018 will be doubled by the UK Government, up to £5 million.Together we can change lives.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Every now and again its good to do something a little challenging and for a good cause.

On the 14/15th September, myself and 40 other fine colleagues will be Cycling, Walking, and Canoeing 80miles from North to South Devon across the beautiful but challenging moorland.

This year as a group we have selected Water Aid as a Charity - the rational is simple  and below. 

In addition.  Some of you will be aware of the challenges faced by my oldest friend and his family. He has received excellent support from Clik Sargent (and other charities) while his 6 month baby boy undergoes chemo for LCH. I want to say thank you to them helping one of my dearest friends. I will match 25% of whatever I raise here and donate to this marvellous charity.  Dig deep people - make me pay.

In case you are not aware of the brilliant mission of Water Aid its pretty simple, and very compelling.  Especially when you consider what we take for granted.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

P.s All donations will go to charity.

eventName: Betsy's Big Water Carry for Water Aid
story:
Betsy has decided she wants to fund raise by doing a water carry.

Betsy  decided she wanted to do this during a conversation we had when she was in the shower, I told her to hurry up and stop wasting water. Betsy asked about the Water Aid adverts on the TV and was quiet concerned about young girls carrying water over long distances and was concerned that these children didn’t get to go to school. 

We looked into this and Water Aid told us that girls started carrying water from the age of two. 

Betsy decided to do a water walk in the hope that she could raise some money and perhaps help girls her age in other countries get and education and also get clean water.

Betsy’s water walk will start at Narberth Foos Festival on Sunday 23rd September at 11 o’clock. 

We will walk a route around Narberth covering 4 miles , ending at the Food Festival, hopefully around 2pm.

Please help Betsy, who is only 9 years old, raise some money!

You can give here on her just giving page, or sponsor her at the food festival, meet her on her walk and put some pennies in a bucket or give in any way you want to!

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

story:
Hi Everyone!

In mid-September, a group of work colleagues and I are setting off to try to traverse Devon by foot, bicycle and canoe (they are excusing me the cycling bit because I'm not sure mid-challenge would be the best time to try to learn). Our charity challenges have been very successful in the past and I would really like to contribute to the fundraising goal of £25,000. 

Any support from you, my lovely friends and family, in achieving this would be very, very much appreciated. If you like hugs, I will give you a hug. If you are a crossfitter and don't like rowing, I will do your rowing for you. If you like chocolate cake, I will bake you one... you get the idea :)

I will let you know how it goes!

Sophia

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
﻿﻿Every year I try to join a big challenge while helping a worthy cause. This year it is going to be a physical challenge! :)

Together with my colleagues I will cycle 60 miles across the Wales countryside, hike 10 miles through hills, and end in a dragon boat from North Devon to South.

The charity I have chosen to support this year is WaterAid because while water is the most important thing for humans' survival and health, there are still many places in the world where it is a luxury. 

C﻿lean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. This affects especially children. With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier and get a chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive.

Help me raise some money for this worthy cause!

Thanks!

Alicia

eventName: Shaved like a mole rate for Wateraid
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Please give generously I know these days we get bombarded with just giving pages but by doing something a little different and letting you guys control how far this goes, we are all giving something. You guys give the money and I give my body hair :)

As you will see from the future pics + vids I think you will agree it will be a fair trade.

KEY Milestones before moving to another body part:

1.Lower Left Leg - £100

2.Lower Right Leg - £200

3.Upper Left Thigh - £300

4.Upper Right Thigh - £400

5.Lower Left Arm - £500

6.Lower Right Arm - £600

7.Upper Arms + Shoulders - £800

8.Chest - £1000

9.Stomach - £1200

10.Sack+Crack - £2000 (good luck people)

As the money rises the body will start to get filled in above.

We're learning the songs for Sing for Water West and raising money through donations for WaterAid.

Our 12 Sing for Water Singers are working hard to raise sponsorship from their friends and families - thank you so much to all those who have donated so far.  Other fundraising events have been a bring and buy sale at choir which members of the choir have organised, a cake sale in Pill precinct on Saturday 7th July 10.30 - 12.00, where the choir will be singing at 11am.  We are also having an end of term concert at Christ Church, Pill on Tuesday 10th July.  £5 on the door. Come along if you can!  

We are also having a disco with supper at Somerset Hall, Portishead on Friday, June 29th.  Tickets are £10 and are available at Morgan-Westley on Portishead High Street or e mail sergeant.wendy@gmail.com

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I recently spent time in refugee camps in Bangladesh and Iraq and have seen firsthand the importance of clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene in order for people to live a dignified and healthy life. WaterAid is running amazing projects around the world to support communities in accessing these things that we take for granted. For every pound donated to WaterAid, 77p go straight to projects. If you would like to know more, read up here: https://www.wateraid.org/uk/our-fundraising-promise

I am running the Berlin Marathon this year to raise awareness and funding for WaterAid's great efforts to continue. Any donation, big or small, in support would be greatly appreciated.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit Ingleton Wood's JustGiving page for WaterAid, our Charity of the Year 2016.

WaterAid transforms lives by improving access to safe water,
hygiene and sanitation in the world’s poorest communities.

We kicked off our fundraising with a Chilli and Cake day at our Colchester office, raising £140 by selling portions to staff throughout the day, thanks to Denise and Alex for cooking up a storm!

We have registered with WaterAid Events and were allocated several places at events such as the Vitality London 10k run and the Prudential Ride London-Surrey 100 mile cycle ride. We have also recently taken on the Yorkshire 3 Peaks Challenge again this year as well as a potential sponsored Sky Dive later this summer which we are currently in the midst of organising - Wish us luck! For updates on all these events plus more, see our Ingleton Wood blog here: http://www.ingletonwood.co.uk/blog.php.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Toby saw an advert when he was 4 that really upset him and he asked if I could send money to help the children that he witnessed crying and dying from a lack of clean water. I explained that when he was older he could raise money for this and he has persisted in asking about it. I chose the activity with him but he will be fundraising alone and if you could spare a few pennies to help him achieve his goal we would really appreciate it. It has made me think about how much I take for granted and how I don't have to worry about where my children's next drink is coming from - just to keep them alive.

wish me luck too! - #outofmycomfortzoneentirely

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
A bright future begins with a healthy start. By sponsoring me you can help WaterAid deliver life and make sure no child arrives into the world without the clean, safe water they need. Every £1 donated to WaterAid’s Deliver Life appeal between 10th November and 10th February will be doubled by the UK Government – meaning we can help twice as many mothers and babies stay safe and well.

This summer, Dale Office Interiors designed and built a new HQ for eCommerce specialists, Visualsoft. The workplace transformation team worked swiftly to make Visualsoft’s ideal workspace a reality in less than 4 months.

In the weeks after the grand opening, a chance conversation between Visualsoft’s Human Resources Manager and one of Dale’s own Business Development Managers revealed that their children had been expressing interest in championing access to clean water through WaterAid. With one child designing a poster and the other writing to Her Majesty the Queen on the subject.

As both of our companies regularly support charitable causes, Dale were pleased that Visualsoft has chosen to use the seasonal hamper they sent to raise much needed funds for the charity.

WaterAid is an international organisation whose mission is to transform the lives of the poorest and most marginalised people by improving access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene.

According to their website, WaterAid reached 2 million people with safe water and 3 million people with sanitation last year. Dale Office Interiors and Visualsoft are proud to raise funds in support of WaterAid’s mission to get safe water, sanitation and hygiene to everyone, everywhere by 2030.

All donations no matter how small will have their name put into a hat and drawn at random at the end of January. We will contact the winner to present the hamper. Good luck and thank you!
title: Hamper Raffle to raise money for WaterAid

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
The Great British summer heatwave has been one to remember however it has made training for the Great North run even harder than it would usually have been. 

Instead of sipping on a refreshing drink in a sunny pub garden I have spent many evenings running up and down the banks of the Thames in 30 degree heat.

However at the end of each run I have had clean water readily available to me, where many people do not. As a lot of you will already know, WaterAid is doing everything it can to get water to everyone, everywhere by 2030. And every step of every training run I have done is worth it knowing who I am trying to help. 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
We've had a brief Hiatus since conquering Snowdon in 2015, but we're back for more!! 

On the 8th September 2018 Seb and myself are attempting a 105 mile Coast to Coast crossing of Scotland. This entails 21 miles of running, 83 miles of cycling (on and off-road) and 2 miles of kayaking... All at the mercy of the Scottish elements, into the prevailing wing and with 2 miles of elevation to contend with..!! Its going to be a long day..

We'd love your support and would encourage and gratefully welcome financial gifts to a superb charity. Water Aid aims to ensure clean and healthy drinking water to be made available for all, please help if you can..

Seb and Hugh

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Last year, my school friend Jane and myself ran the Great North Run for the first time. If we could go back in time to our teenage selves, I’m not sure we would have believed  that it was possible. It was such a wonderful and inspiring experience. That great hub of people all heading towards South Shields, all with their own reasons for doing it. It was very humbling, and wonderful to be a tiny part of such a big event. We felt proud of our region, and very happy to be part of it. People tell you how the local support along the route is unwavering, but it really is, it’s marvellous. 

This year we are very proud to be raising money for Water Aid. This is why. 

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
We're taking part in the Royal Parks Half Marathon for WaterAid. Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights.

I (Laura) am lucky enough to be able to visit some of the communities in which we work and I have seen first hand the devastating impact that a lack of clean water and decent toilets can have. 

We've set up a joint fundraising page because while running 13 miles will be a MASSIVE undertaking for me, it is something Pie does for fun. She has offered to run alongside me and offer supportive words - for two hours. TWO HOURS. Now that deserves payment, one way or another.

Also - whoever donates the most money can choose Pie's costume.
title: Laura and Pie take on London Parks Half Marathon

story:
Frances is turning 40 in July and is looking forward to celebrating. 

If you can't make the " Strictly Come Dancing " charity ball she is organising at the De Grey rooms ballroom in July there are other ways you can support. 

Frances is aware that 500,000 children die each year from diarrhoea caused by unsafe water and may never reach their 40th.  Their parents never get the opportunity to see them thrive and grow.  Together we can make a difference. 

Please give generously.  Thank you.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. I'm looking to raise some money for a wonderful charity called Water Aid, a charity I have supported since I worked on a project at university. The project brought this organisation to my attention. I learnt of the ways this charity successfully supports communities all over the world to try to provide them with clean, save, drinking  water. 

Water-aid  are now  working hard to help the people of Nepal and their priority is to provide water and sanitation to those most in need during this crisis. 

I will be trading in any other form of beverage , no teas, juice, beers or wine... to hopefully raise a little to give to this brilliant charity.  I'm aware it isnt a huge sacrifice for me and I am truly grateful to have the water I will be drinking over the next 20 days. If you do feel like sponsoring me for just a  £1  I really would appreciate the help. My target is £100 so I just need 100 friends! Easy!

In light of the #icebucketchallenge I've read and quite a few people have said it seems wasteful to throw water around, when in other countries they aren't lucky enough to always have enough to drink. I've long since thought WaterAid is a great charity, so thought I'd set up this page and donate to them too. In light of the ice bucket challenge I’m raising money for Motor Neurone Disease Association (UK version of ALS) too, see www.justgiving.com/renataice. Give what you can to these great causes.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am working as part of a fantastic team to create exciting events and projects over the next year, which will allow us to raise money for WaterAid, in particular, their current work in Madagascar to provide clean water and sanitation for as many people as possible who do not have these basic facilities.

For my personal fundraising challenge, I will be holding an Afternoon Tea event in Bath on Saturday 23rd September 2017. More information will follow and you will be able to book tickets via donation on this page so save the date in your diary and come along to an enjoyable afternoon with colleagues, family and friends and enjoy some sweet treats with me and my team!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

eventName: Hands Across The Water laundry pressing donation through text giving.
story:
Updated Feb 2017

Because WaterAids projects use technologies that are appropriate and affordable for people living in some of the world's poorest countries a small amount really can make a difference to our work. For example, just £15 is enough to help one person gain access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene education.Our collection at WalkforWater achieved this and more so please help too.Information sourced from WaterAid UK

Why WaterAid?

WaterAid is an international charity that in short is a life saver.

It transform lives by improving access to safe water, hygiene and sanitation in the world's poorest communities. For more information please visit http://www.wateraid.org/uk

  How you can help ?

 Txt HATW77 to 70070 to donate £2.00 ,£5 or £10 (networks do not charge for this) 

Or, follow the links to use to use a Debit or Credit card. 

Thank You

 

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity and make sure Gift Aid is reclaimed on every eligible donation by a UK taxpayer. So it’s the most efficient way to donate - I raise more, whilst saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

So please dig deep and donate now.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Did you know that collectively, women and girls spend 200 million hours fetching water every day? That’s according to a Unicef study, which also described the figure as a “colossal waste of their valuable time.”

When water is not piped to the home the burden of fetching it falls disproportionately on women and children, especially girls. The opportunity costs of collecting water are high, with far reaching effects. For both boys and girls, water collection can take time away from their education and sometimes even prevent them attending school altogether.

The UK-based charity WaterAid has teams in 34 countries across the world who work with partners to transform millions of lives every year by improving access to clean water, toilets and hygiene. 

We’re supporting WaterAid by undertaking our own walk, coast-to-coast across England, following the impressive Hadrian’s Wall built in AD122.  At 135km (or 84 miles) that’s a long way for little legs, but with your help, we hope our efforts will make just that little bit of a difference to children and families less fortunate than us. 

Thank you,

Ruby Creen (aged 7)
title: Ruby Walks Hadrian's Wall-2018
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: Ruby Walks Hadrian's Wall-2018

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
My second favourite auntie and I (for some unknown reason) have decided to take part in the Great North Run. For those that aren’t aware, it is a half marathon in and around Newcastle (why aye!) with Mo Farah leading the pack!

Both Sarah and I are incredibly competitive and although our training has been some what questionable and varying so far, we are determined to run together and in a respectable time.

As well as competitive, we are hugely immature around each other. To put our relationship into perspective for you all, last time we were together she threw a dart into my hand after a few tequila shots! So although we are taking this seriously, we also aim to have fun in the process!

On a serious note, with a month to go it’s time to step up to the challenge. We are running for Water Aid - a charity that aims to provide people with clean water, safe sanitation and hygiene education. Clean water is something that we take for granted everyday, but for many people around the world it is an unrealistic concept that isn’t a part of their daily lives. This needs to change so please give as generously as possible!

Lots of love and we appreciate even the smallest of donations xxxx

Please note, we are unsure who will be dragging who at this current time. We thank you for your patience with regard to the matter.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
We're learning the songs for Sing for Water West and raising money through donations for WaterAid.  Our 23 Sing for Water Singers are working hard to raise sponsorship from their friends and families - thank you so much to all those who have donated so far.  Other fundraising events are a raffle which members of the choir have organised, a concert at the Folk Hall where we practise on Monday 9th June at 11am where there will also be a cake sale.  Come along if you can!  

We are also having a disco with supper at Somerset Hall, Portishead on Friday, June 29th.  Tickets are £10 and are available at Morgan-Westley on Portishead High Street or e mail sergeant.wendy@gmail.com

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped. By donating this winter you are helping reach 250,000 people around the world with clean water. Every £1 donated to Untapped between 1 November 2017 and 31 January 2018 will be doubled by the UK Government, up to £5 million.Together we can change lives.

eventName: NCS The Challenge Real challenge Action Sutton
story:
We are Team Ward and we are working with Water Aid because we believe everyone should have easy access to safe, clean water. Girls would be able to get better education as they wouldn't have to travel miles to find water. By raising awareness and money, we can help people in places like Africa and Asia by building wells and taps.

This is important because it can help reduce chances of diseases like cholera and therefore deaths. More young girls can even get better education to have a more secure future.

story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Those who know me well know my addiction to water - I can drink litres of it in a single day. As a runner, it's my fuel and hydration. Imagine a world with no water... well, that's everyday life for some. So let's get clean water to those who need it! Anything you can give is a blessing, and I thank you from the bottom of my heart for your help.

Love always,

Serap xxx

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
With Ramadan approaching,  the BDO Islamic Network thought it would be a great idea to challenge people to take part in a dawn to dusk fast whilst raising funds for a great cause!

All proceeds will go towards WaterAid's fight against the global crises of poor water sanitation, hygiene and low prevalence of clean water across the globe.

We chose this fund because WaterAid offer life-saving work to those in poorer regions. We also felt that those taking part in the challenge will have a newfound love and appreciation of water!

More details of the project can be found at: http://www.wateraid.org/uk/what-we-do/the-crisis﻿﻿

And a big thank you to everyone at BDO taking part in the challenge or donating - your help is greatly appreciated!

If you have any queries, please contact Tahir.ebrahim@bdo.co.uk or Faheed.chaudary@bdo.co.uk

Thanks,

BDO Islamic Network

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
"2.1 billion people lack access to safe, readily available water at home, and 6 in 10 people, or 4.5 billion, lack safely managed sanitation" (WHO/UNICEF report, 2017)

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily existence. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can break free from poverty, realise
their potential, and change their lives for the better.With all three, children are born healthier, have an improved chance of reaching school age, and growing up to become adults. Whole communities start to thrive. 

And we CAN help make this happen... :D

eventName: Robin James WaterAid - Aveda Earth Month
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit the Robin James JustGiving page.

Robin James is helping Aveda UK support WaterAid during Earth Month 2016. To date, Aveda have donated an incredible £629,000 to the charity, supporting projects in Ethiopia, Nepal and, most recently, India. This year, Aveda will once again be fundraising for WaterAid’s project in India, which focuses on provided water, sanitation and hygiene education to women and young girls in a small village in Andhra Pradesh. Thanks to everyone for all your fantastic efforts in making this Earth Month the biggest one yet!

eventName: Jacobs Shrewsbury Clyde Marine Challenge 2015 for WaterAid
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Jacobs has a long history of fundraising for WaterAid, following the success of recent sailing events on the Clyde over £30,000 has been raised for WaterAid and other charities.

This year, for the first time, a boat from the Shrewsbury office will participate in the Clyde Marine Challenge.  We will sail from Largs on Friday 11th September for Rothesay then Tarbert braving fair weather or foul returning on Sunday 13th September.

WaterAid works in partnership with local organisations to help communities establish sustainable water supplies and sanitation close to home. However, with one in eight people worldwide are living without safe water – there is still much more to do.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thanks very much,

Andrew, Ali, Keith, Robert and Steve

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
At the end of August I'm going to be taking on the world's tallest freestanding mountain, Kilimanjaro. At 5,895 metres/19,341 feet this may be a struggle, so I'm going to need all the support I can get to help push me to the top.

I'm going to be raising money for WaterAid, which works to provide clean water and improve hygiene in countries across the world, including Tanzania.

Stats speak for themselves - nearly half of the population in the country has no access to clean water, and a quarter have no decent toilet. Across the world a newborn dies from infection caused by lack of safe water every minute; a child under 5 dies from diarrhoea every 2 minutes. 

WaterAid does some amazing work to help fight this, encouraging governments to change laws and funding life-changing projects - last year they provided 956,000 people with clean water and 1.1 million people with decent toilets, and they couldn't have done it without donations from people like you. 

Any donation, however big or small, would therefore be hugely appreciated (you don't have to dig deep to have a real impact - £18 can provide an entire family with clean water).

As well as supporting a great cause you'll be helping motivate me to reach the summit when I'm on my last legs/severely depleted of oxygen/done with camping at 5,000m... You get the gist. Time to get training...

Thank you :) 

Laura

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Thank you for visiting my WaterAid fundraising page! 

Water is fundamental to life and access to it is a basic human right. However, 844 million people globally do not have access to clean water.  Climate change is exacerbating the problem with extreme drought and flooding events particularly effecting poorer communities. With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene children are born healthier. They get the chance of a decent education and grow up to become adults.

I have chosen to support Water Aid in order to help give people a chance to take back control of their lives and thrive as communities. Basic but life changing infrastructure doesn't have to be expensive either. £20 pays for a pair of taps and £37 pays for a hand pump to provide clean drinking water.

I am raising money for Water Aid by completing the 100km (62 miles) South Coast Challenge in a continuous walk/jog/run (or maybe even crawl) from Eastbourne to Arundel along the beautiful South Downs Way. This will be a daunting challenge over day and night but it will be well worth the effort!

Many thanks for your donation and best wishes from me!

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
In December of this year, it will have been 10 years since my Dad passed away, at the untimely age of just 52.

I wanted to honour my Dad’s memory by raising money for a great cause on his behalf. So, on 2nd September 2018, I will be jumping out of a plane at 15000ft - the highest point for skydiving in the UK.

All proceeds will go to WaterAid; a global organisation dedicated to reducing extreme poverty and saving lives by providing everyone, everywhere, with clean water and sanitation. (details about the charity follow the story below).

Why this is so important to me

I love to write. Writing is my passion, my peace and my freedom. It usually comes so naturally and easily to me; it is not abnormal for me to write a poem with one hand whilst blow-drying my hair with the other, or to pen a whole chapter in a week of train journeys into work.

The relevance of that? Well it is now day 3 of pacing up and down my living room, the time is 3:21am and I still haven't found the right words for this story. Writing this is damn hard. Writing the paragraph above was a nice distraction. I have spent my entire life concealing my emotions and vulnerabilities behind confidence, vibrance and laughter. So believe me, the thought of sharing some of my heart with everyone I know is 100 percent more daunting than jumping out of that plane can ever be.

The truth is I didn't really know him.

My parents divorced when I was 8 years old, after which I, alongside my 3 elder siblings, was brought up single-handedly by my mum.  I won't delve into the circumstances surrounding the divorce. However, I will say that I was a child who, at that age, had witnessed more turbulence than most adults I know. I remember feeling emotions that children shouldn't.  I felt rage, anger towards my father, a deep sadness, worry, fear, anxiety, instability, insecurity. I could go on.

My Dad didn't keep in touch. For the rest of his life, until very near the end, he played no part in mine. I pretended I didn't care at all, but deep inside, I blamed him and hated him for everything.  I powered through my teenage years suffering with undiagnosed PTSD and depression, all the while performing well at school, both academically and socially. My Dad was never at the forefront of my mind - I didn't know what a father was to miss one. All I felt towards him was contempt, which, as the years rolled by, started to become indifference.

I was wrong.

Yes, I had every right to be angry. But I completely failed to comprehend my father's intricacies. I failed to understand his reasons, his demons, his own turbulent past, the state of his mind, the fact that he basically had no support system and was completely broken himself.

I still try to tell myself that I couldn't possibly have known any better at such a young age.

Early in 2008, my eldest brother had started to try and rebuild a relationship with our father. By then, at the age of 20, I was becoming more mature and starting to realise some of the complexities above. I strongly considered joining my brother, but could never quite bring myself to go along.

In December 2008, my Dad was hospitalised with various health issues. At this point we all pulled together and spent time with him in the hospital. Unfortunately by the time I told him I was sorry, and that I would make it up to him, he had already lost his consciousness. I will never know whether or not he heard what I said that day.

On 23rd December 2008, my Dad lost his life.

The next few days, weeks, months, I felt numb. I couldn't grieve - how can you grieve for such an abstract relationship? I continued with my life as though nothing had happened, whilst in self-destruct mode, suffocating inside.

I felt wholly responsible for having never done anything to help my Dad. The pure, intense guilt was so overwhelming for such a prolonged period of time. It had a massive effect on both my physical and mental health.

I could barely process it, let alone talk about it. To this day I may have told this story to a small number of very close friends. I have never spoken about it with my siblings. I think it's just too painful for us all.

I am now 31 and I am stronger than I have ever been. I think now, be it 10 years too late, it's about time I acted on that promise I made to my Dad about making it up to him. What I am doing here is a first step, a small thing. My intention and commitment now, is to continue taking positive actions in his name for as long as I am able.

I have chosen WaterAid after much contemplation, as the work that they do provides sustainable, rather than one-off help, to people suffering extreme poverty. This means that their projects affect generation after generation, so each donation stretches further. Hopefully this will also mean that my Dad will continue to receive prayers and blessings from people long after I have gone. 

1 in 3 people on the planet don't have a decent toilet of their own. 1 in 9 don't have clean water close to their home. Your donations can help to change that for good. Here are some examples of how far your money could go:

  • £15 3 bags of cement to build a life-saving toilet in Nepal
  • £24 A year's hygiene education for one child in Uganda 
  • £50 An accessible toilet in Bangladesh
  • £103 7 hygienic hands-free taps to help a hospital in Tanzania
  • £509 A hand-dug well and pump serving 120 people in Malawi
  • £700 A public tap stand for a whole community in Ethiopia
  • £1,050 A school sanitation block for 250 children in Bangladesh

Finally, thank you so, so much for taking the time to read this, I know it was a long read. It is now 5:12am if that makes anyone feel any better?! But at least today, my crazy insomnia has been put to good use.  I could probably have stopped typing after the opening few lines, but honestly, I needed to do this for myself.

The skydive has already been booked and paid for, so all donations will be going directly to the charity. It would mean the world to me if you could make a donation, no matter how small.
title: In memory of my Dad
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Mohammed Abid
Name: In memory of my Dad

story:
Personally I would only ever raise money for a charity that spends most of its donations in the developing world, as that's where need is greatest.

WaterAid are one such charity, that help poor communities establish sustainable water supplies and toilets, they work across the world including Africa and India, where I have seen first hand the levels of poverty the people there have to endure.

I would really appreciate it if you could spare a few pounds for this great charity and you really would be making a difference.

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I've always wanted to do a fundraising event for Water Aid ever since I was part of a school choir event at Jesus Green Lido and it occurred to me that Water Aid was helping people who didn't have water. I remember how the thought of someone not being able to have clean water and have to go such a long way for dirty water and even then being able to only take a sip about once a day to make it last, really made a big impact on me. 

Lots of us take water for granted as it feels so normal to have it, yet some people in the world don't have water. It makes you realise how lucky you are to be able to have clean water that you can get every time you feel thirsty. 

It doesn't seem fair to me that the world can create so many phones and electronics and provide so much food that half of it is thrown away and yet there are still people who are homeless, starving and are dying from dehydration. 

I wanted to try and fundraise for all the charities that support people who are homeless and hungry and I will someday try to help all of those charities, but I thought I would start with Water Aid as water is such a basic need and is the most longed for by those who have nothing.

story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

I’m a student living in Manchester/Cornwall who has been very lucky to never worry about accessing water in life. However, people in less fortunate circumstances than my own are unable to access clean water, causing a domino effect on every other aspect of their lives. After studying water pollution in various modules in university, I know that charitable aid is one of the only ways to tackle water issues in less developed countries. Please take the time to donate, as this is an amazing charity which really does succeed in changing lives.

story:
As part of our fundraising efforts for WaterAid, we will be putting on a whole host of events in Cambridge and Shifnal over the summer, including a Dr Bike bike maintenance scheme (suggested donation £10-£15),  car wash and lunches in Cambridge and Shifnal offices. We have a target of £2500 to meet by 30th September, which will go towards WaterAid's vital water and sanitation work around the world.

We will also be co-hosting a WaterAid ceilidh with the Cambridge local WaterAid group from 7:30-10:30pm on Friday 25th September at St Barnabas on Mill Rd  - get your tickets here by donating £10 per person and writing 'Ticket' in the message box - please remember to include your name too! Tickets will be £12 on the door.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thanks!

Mott MacDonald WaterAid Innovators Team 4 & the Cambridge Local WaterAid Group

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I am trekking across the Arctic in Greenland as part of a bank-wide charity trip - this is in aid of Wateraid.  This trip will include carrying all our own equipment (tent, clothes, etc) across the ice for 5 days!  I hope to also raise awareness of climate change and our impact on our environment.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. But all over the world, communities are living without these essential human rights, leaving their lives at risk and their potential untapped. By donating this winter you are helping reach 250,000 people around the world with clean water. Every £1 donated to Untapped between 1 November 2017 and 31 January 2018 will be doubled by the UK Government, up to £5 million.Together we can change lives.

story:
CS2 team members from across the Nation will be joining together to complete the Yorkshire 3 Peaks Challenge. With so many fantastic causes to support, we struggled to choose one, however with the untimely passing of CS2 Director and colleague, Vince Owen; we thought there was no better way to pay tribute than to support one of Vince's many favoured charities 'WaterAid'.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be. This is what WaterAid strive to achieve.

The team will be taking part in this challenge on the 28th of September so any support between now and then will be massively appreciated!

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
I am very lucky. I have a mummy, a daddy, a brother. I have a house to live in, food to eat, and toys to play with. I also have fresh water, unlike other poor children around the world. I am trying to raise money for these unfortunate people over the summer holidays, doing all sorts of things. I have lots of plans, like...                            

  • Helping people with jobs.      
  • Doing a cycle challenge.
  • Baking cakes.
  • Knitting twiddlymuffs

If anyone has any more ideas, they are welcome to share!!   

Please help me raise money by letting me know if you want a job done or a challenge completed. I will update my webpage whenever I do something for charity, which means you will also be able to see what I've done. Please keep checking back!!

To get things started, Mummy is going to donate £10.00 every time I knit a twiddlymuff before the beginning of next term.

This is why WaterAid is so important:

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

Thank you!!

story:
Thank you for taking the time to read this page.

On Sunday 29th July I will be riding 100 miles as part of the Prudential RideLondon-Surrey 100.

As such, I am aiming to raise a minimum of £500 for WaterAid, which is a fantastic cause.

Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good. With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

WaterAid do amazing work providing some of the world's communities with access to clean water and sanitation. A tap and a toilet seem like such a basic right but worldwide 748m are without clean water and 2.5bn without sanitation.

I appreciate any donation you can make. Don't forget to gift aid! Thanks,

Jon

charity.description:
WaterAid is an international charity. Our mission is to change normal for millions of people within a generation – by getting clean
water, decent toilets and good hygiene to everyone, everywhere.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
As I started to think about which charity to run the Great North Run for this year, we were entering a lovely spell of hot weather.  The garden needed watering and it was no problem to turn the tap fill the watering can and water the new apple tree.  Over the coming weeks as the warm weather continued there was talk of hose pipe bans, and this brought my mind back to the availability of water.  For us, the most difficult decision we’ll have to make is whether to water the garden or wash the car, but for millions of people, having clean safe water for the basic daily requirements is not so simple.  1 in 3 people on the planet don't have a decent toilet of their own and 1 in 9 don't have clean water close to home.  Just to give more of an idea of what those numbers mean, that’s 2.3 billion people who don't have a decent toilet of their own and 844 million people who don’t have clean water close to home.  And what’s the result of these numbers

  • Diarrhoea caused by dirty water and poor toilets kills a child under 5 every 2 minutes. 
  • Every minute a new-born dies from infection caused by lack of safe water and an unclean environment.
  • Around the world up to 443 million school days are lost every year because of water-related illnesses.

Please help me raise money so that WaterAid can do something about these numbers.  Thank you


Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.With clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene, children are born healthier. They get the chance to go to school and grow up to become adults. Women and men get to earn a living. Whole communities start to thrive. It sounds normal and it should be.

charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Thank you for visiting our Raft Race Team’s WaterAid fundraising page.

Since 2016, Thames Water has been working together with WaterAid to transform lives in two towns in Malawi – the world’s poorest country. Currently in Malawi, 10 million people have no safe place to go to the toilet and 1.7 million people have no access to safe clean water.

As part of the fundraising campain, Thames Water are for the 21st year holding the annual Raft Race.The Energy & Carbon Team are once again taking part in the one mile race! Up to 40 themed rafts will battle it out on the river Thames in this annual legendary event. Each team will design, build and decorate their raft and wear fancy dress based around the theme of It’s our 21st birthday

Please dig deep and sponsor us online, it’s secure and easy! Your money makes such a difference to peoples lives.

Please come along and enjoy the evening. This year's race takes place on Thursday, 26 July 2018 from 6pm at Reading Rowing Club near Caversham Bridge.

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
ISG is supporting CARE International to help people find routes out of poverty.The money we raise will help CARE fight poverty and injustice in more than 80 countries around the world. CARE also delivers emergency aid to survivors of war and natural disasters, and helps people rebuild their lives in the aftermath.

Every donation counts and at least 83% of all donations is spent on CARE’s poverty fighting programme so please dig deep and donate now! 

As part of our global CSR initiative in raising money for our partner charity, CARE, we are raising money by seeking sponsorship for our staff to run a variety of distances in the 100 Plus Out Runner race. We have 32 staff running a combined distance of 260km.

We would like to seek your commitment to make a difference by sponsoring our staff for every km they successfully run. Please donate online or email outrunner@isgplc.com for more information on donating in cash.

With your generous support, we can all make a difference. 

- - - - -

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
Instead of being glued to a sofa this Easter holiday I’m going to be walking 10,000 steps (about 5 Miles) everyday for a week (16th - 22nd April) as part of Care International UK’s ‘Walk in Her Shoes 2018’ campaign.

I thought my commute to university was time-consuming, but women all over the world don’t even get a chance of an education because of the time they must spend everyday walking to collect water for their family. Often this water isn’t even safe to drink or use. 

By sponsoring me ‘walking in her shoes’ you can help Care International’s initiative to build sanitary water pumps and wells in remote villages worldwide, helping these women participate in education, become employed and break out of the cycle of poverty.

Thank you for looking at my page, I’m so grateful for anything you are able to donate towards this cause!
title: Rebecca fundraising for CARE International UK
pageSummary: Walking 10,000 steps a day 16th-22nd of April because Women’s lives are more than walking for water.

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story: This December I will be shaving my head to fundraise for Care International, a charity that works around the globe to save lives, defeat poverty and achieve social justice, with a special focus on women and girls to fight for their equal rights and opportunities! Furthermore, the hair I shave will be donated to The Little Princess Trust to create free wigs for children and young adults who have lost their hair due to cancer treatments and other illnesses. Care International work alongside people and communities on long-term programmes, that tackle the underlying causes of poverty to deliver lasting change! With at least 85p of every £1 going directly toward fighting poverty, and only 15p going toward fundraising and support, Care International is a phenomenal charity whose long-term goals makes EQUALITY SEEM POSSIBLE! After speaking with the charity, I am hopeful that by October I will be fundraising for a specific appeal surrounding women’s maternal and sexual health in developing countries. After recent research surrounding gender-biased neglect, rape, child brides, domestic abuse, female genital mutilation, death due to childbirth/miscarriages/abortions and so much more, this is a subject I find personally challenging and upsetting. Every woman deserves control over her own body, to understand her own body, and to be looked after and supported both medically and emotionally when needed. With Care’s top aim for 2020 being that 100 million women and girls exercise their rights to sexual, reproductive and maternal health and a life free from violence I thought there was no reason not to start fundraising NOW! Any donation will be MUCH APPRECIATED! If you aren’t able to donate, or just want to do more, please get in contact with me to help fundraise, spread awareness, or share your own fundraising tricks and tips with me!

eventName: Stairs And The City Women's Stair Climb
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am climbing stairs to support women and families displaced by war. Women rebuild the community and hence the men also benefit in the longterm:  the family is the future. We are seeing too many images of families being displaced under the unimaginable horror of conflict. 

I will be attempting to climb 48 flights of stairs (@1250 steps) at the Leadenhall building, as fast as I can. Please sponsor me to spur me on to help to make a difference. 

Every little bit helps, and so this is my ‘bit’.Thank you for your support. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

CARE fights poverty and injustice in 86 countries around the world to help the world’s poorest people find routes out of poverty. CARE also delivers emergency aid to survivors of war and natural disasters, and helps people rebuild their lives in the aftermath.

CARE’s mission is to create lasting change in poor communities and put money where it is needed most: 94 pence in every £1 goes towards our poverty fighting programmes. That’s one of the highest rates among all the UK aid agencies.

We particularly like the work of Care International because its work ranges from providing education and shelter through to providing medicine- it is not restricted to one type of support. Additionally, it is not prejudiced in the type of people it helps; regardless of sex, race, gender, and religion it aims to help all those in extreme poverty.

We are particularly interested in the work that they are currently doing for Syrian refugees. The Syrian crisis is worsening day by day and I think its paramount that individuals and charities do all that they can to alleviate the suffering experienced. We also think that their work for one-off crisis' such as the Phillipines hurricane is significant; providing humanitarian aid quickly and efficiently for events such as these, is paramount to saving lives.

Your donations will go to those in need of education and to programmes helping small businesses, so communities can, in the long term, can get on their own feet. They will also go to those needing medication, water and shelter supplies so that in the short term suffering and poverty can be diminished. We also think that the way they work with businesses and Governments ensure that you donations definitely go to the right places.

Visit

http://www.careinternational.org.uk/ if you want any more info!

We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
I am fundraising for CARE International whose work around the globe supports vulnerable people living in poverty, affected by war or natural disaster. CARE provides emergency food and shelter, and helps communities create sustainable solutions to poverty. 
Women and girls are most affected by poverty, so CARE puts them at the heart of what they do and works to tackle issues of inequality and support them to reach their full potential. Your sponsorship will help CARE reach more people and achieve a world of hope, tolerance and social justice.

charity.description: CARE International is one of the world’s leading aid agencies working in over 80 countries around the globe. We seek a world of hope, tolerance and social justice, with  women and girls at the centre, where poverty has been overcome, and people live with equal opportunities in security and dignity.
charity.name: CARE International UK
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Every day thousands of women and girls, all over the world, have no choice but to walk many miles to fetch water for their families. Water that is often dirty.
Their daily routine deprives them of the chance to have an education, a job, and traps them in a cycle of poverty.
The money you raise can help build wells and water pumps closer to rural communities so that women and girls don’t have to spend their days walking for water, and can plan for a better future.
